**The Dongxuan Jin Yu Collection**

**Title:** *The Dongxuan Jin Yu Collection*
**Author:** Jin Mazu
**Ten fascicles**
**Source edition:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Taiping* Section

**Table of Contents**
Fascicle One: Seven-character quatrains
Fascicle Two: Seven-character quatrains
Fascicle Three: Seven-character quatrains, Seven-character regulated verse
Fascicle Four: Seven-character extended verse, Five-character quatrains
Fascicle Five: Five-character extended verse, Five-character regulated verse, Chants, Eulogies
Fascicle Six: Six-character poems, Songs
Fascicle Seven: Lyrics
Fascicle Eight: Lyrics
Fascicle Nine: Lyrics
Fascicle Ten: Lyrics

---

**Fascicle One of The Dongxuan Jin Yu Collection**
*Composed by the Perfected of Pure Serenity and Non-Action of Kunlun, True Man Ma of Danyang*

**Seven-character quatrains**

The Perfected of Wondrous Conduct and Compassionate Transformation of Chongyang, while dwelling in a hut on Mount Kunyu, fashioned a headscarf from a bolt of blue cloth three and a half feet in length, folding it nine times and stitching it nine seams. In a dream, he once beheld it, calling it the *Ninefold Transformed Huayang Scarf*. His master’s bearing was majestic, resembling that of Zhongli, and with this scarf bound upon his head, his radiance and refinement only deepened—truly a man beyond the world of things. Thus, these verses were composed in praise:

His countenance mirrors Zhongli’s treasured form,
Naturally poised, his spirit refined and bright.

**How could one know he is not a wanderer of the red dust?**
*It is the Ninefold Transformed Huayang Scarf of blue cloth.*

**In Praise of Chongyang’s Perfected of Wondrous Conduct and Compassionate Transformation**
A cloud-wrought crown, a rosy cape, a crimson sash—
His form enters the radiant sphere, apart from the Purple Clarity.
The Perfected of Wondrous Conduct fulfills his primal vow,
Rescuing the imperiled, saving the suffering, ferrying all beings.

**Following the Rhyme of Perfected Chongyang**
He dwells not in towns nor villages,
Thinks not of wife, son, or grandson.
His resolve lies in circling the walls to cultivate the Great Dao,
Turning the jade gate to enter the golden portal.

**Expressing My Thoughts**
Thirty years within the gate of Confucian learning,
Yet not one word as vast as heaven did I know.
By chance, I awakened to the principles of the Wind Immortal—
Suddenly, numinous clarity filled the boundless cosmos.

**Again**
A realm of immortals, vast and formless,
Lofty and vaulted, a heaven of one’s own.
In broad daylight, at ease without trivial affairs,
One soars through the cinnabar clouds, riding the mist.

**Again**
A carefree wanderer of the Three Mountains,
An unbound immortal, at ease and unconstrained.
In purity, one turns the scenes within the pot,
In non-action, one treads and shatters the heavens within the cave.

**Matching the Rhyme of the Second Young Master of the Medicine King of Chang’an**
Cloud-roaming, I crossed waters past Zhongmou,
Where I met the great praise of Master Chongyang.
He permitted me to return in perfect clarity,
Among the thirty-six Perfected of the Grotto-Heavens.

**[Ten Quatrains]**
When Perfected Chongyang wished to journey to Ninghai, he personally drew a painting and entrusted it to his disciple, Master Shi of Liquan County, to keep in secret.

Yu dreamed beforehand of a crane emerging from the earth in the Southern Garden. A month later, Master Chongyang arrived, pointing to where the crane had risen and instructing that a hut be built there.

Yu further dreamed of following his master into a mountain. The next day, his master bestowed upon him the childhood name *Shantong*.

Xuan followed his master to Nanjing. As the year drew to a close, the master prepared to depart the world.

Yu sought to leave the world in distress.
The master said: *"I have already written of this beforehand on the wall of Lü the Daoist’s hut in Guanzhong."*

Yu informed the master of his three wishes:
First, to print and circulate the *Complete Perfection Collection* of the master.
The master replied: *"It is already settled in Chang’an."*
Second, to observe mourning for the master for three years.
The master said: *"The old hut site in Liujiang Village will suffice for your dwelling."*
Third, to exhort parents of all directions to cast off the mundane and cultivate immortality.
The master said: *"Enough. Ascend in rosy clouds."*

I parted ways at Daliang, passed through Luoyang, entered Tong Pass, crossed Mount Hua, and visited Jingzhao. A Daoist friend urged me to stay, and I lingered for several days in Master Kong’s hut.

Master Shi of Liquan came seeking me, and we met at the tea house by the eastern gate. When asked his name, he said: *"I am Shi Fengzi of Liquan, also a disciple of Perfected Chongyang."* Hearing this, I rejoiced greatly, for the master had often spoken of his worth.

After tea, I strolled idly beneath the Taiping Tower. Daoist friend Yang the Second invited me to stay, and as we sipped tea, Master Shi arrived. He again offered bows, but I reproved him: *"Since you are a disciple of Master Chongyang, why so many courtesies? How can a Daoist live by bowing two or three times a day?"*

I knew beforehand that this gentleman feared begging in the streets, so I sought to provoke him. I wished to share a pot of wine with him, but the host was unsure. Master Shi drew coins from his robe, but I said: *"No need for these. Go to the streets, beg for money, and buy wine."* After staring for a while, he went to beg and returned with wine. I drank alone, and when he asked for a poem, I composed ten quatrains to bestow upon him:

*What shame is there in a walking corpse and moving bones?*
*Do not let clothing and food stir up needless sorrow.*
*Learn from me—stretch your arms in the streets,*
*Begging as you go, most free and refined.*

**Again**
*Wealth and honor are but trifles,*
*While life and nature are as vast as heaven.*
*Fire, wind, earth, and water are like floating bubbles—*
*First see through this illusory body.*

**Again**
*Today, I truly meet a worthy one,*
*Do not let household affairs create karmic debt.*
*Subdue your self and go begging—*
*Daily life will naturally become effortless.*

**Again**
*Ma Feng does not love the wine in the cup,*
*But leads you to stretch your hands idly in the streets.*
*Pass the days as you will, aiding the Dao’s growth,*
*No need to concoct medicine to idle away your mouth.*

**Again**
*Take this coarse wine to aid my spirit,*
*Rely on the jade nectar to nourish your celestial truth.*
*Who knows that the drunker one becomes, the more clear and free?*
*One day, your merit complete, you’ll be a person of the Three Isles.*

**Again**
*No wife, no son, no daughter—*
*Heaven grants you carefree ease; best to awaken.*
*Do not deceive your heart or mock others,*
*For unseen spirits ever watch over you.*

**Again**
*Let go of all you once cherished,*
*Hasten to withdraw and seek beyond the world.*
*What you seek is not apart from the inch-square of your heart—*
*Be selfless and upright, and you’ll find a true friend.*

**Again**
*The celestial mechanism dare not be lightly imparted,*
*Observe carefully whether you awaken or not.*
*When hardship comes, forget your home—*
*Then I will point you to the path of longevity.*

**Again**
*Fleeting fame and profit are hard enough to seek;*
*Once gained, you’ll lie in an earthen mound.*
*Do not think immortality a trifling matter—*
*It requires merit and conduct to reach Yingzhou.*

**Again**
*To become an immortal, you must awaken fully,*
*Cast aside the ten thousand worldly ties in one stroke.*
*Always find even your shadow too much—*
*Then you’ll naturally have an immortal to guide you.*

**For the Daoist Friends of Chang’an**
At every household’s gate, the Dao of Chang’an,
In every courtyard, the Land of Ultimate Bliss.
With a single step unmoved, one transcends the dharma-realm,
With three faces all-pervading, one attains cool clarity.

**Matching the Rhyme of Guo Zicong’s Instruction for Chang’an**
Luminous and pure, the divine radiance shines abundantly,
Naturally, the monkey and horse are not driven.
Turning deeper, one awakens to the path of mysterious penetration—
I wonder if Fen Yang has received the message.

**Matching Magistrate Lu’s Rhyme**
A single body becomes the circling wall,
A carefree spirit-child dwells within.
Though mute, it speaks words of profound mystery,
Do not let the monkey and horse run wild.

**For Kong the Elder and His Brother Peng Ziyuan of Chang’an**
At forty-eight, I came to Chang’an,
Seeking the regard of various gentlemen with discerning eyes.
Today, I extend myself to those who know me—
Speaking of cultivation, I reveal the coiled dragon and tiger.

**Again**
Hut-master Kong and Peng Ziyuan,
Along with all Daoist kin, early sought the mysterious.

Within the body, the fire of long life nourishes,
Within the crucible, the everlasting sky is perfected.

**Again**
Heart clear, intent pure, nature roams free,
Unfettered and unbound, the waist unburdened.
If you wish lead and mercury to conjoin within the furnace,
First harmonize the inner elixir of the cauldron.

**Again**
Cast aside worldly ties, let all affairs cease,
Naturally, the true cause is grasped.
The vital and harmonious essence pierces the cinnabar cave,
The awakened spirit-child ascends the jade tower.

**Again**
Unmoved by external pleasures, untouched by greed or wrath,
Blending with the world, radiant in speech and laughter.
I only wish that all gentlemen share my resolve—
Together we cultivate and ascend as immortals.

**Again**
Roaming beyond the mundane, the spirit is fortified,
Free from care, forgetting schemes, uniting with the supreme truth.
Realize that non-contention marks the highest adept,
Ever embracing forbearance, one becomes an immortal.

**Again**
Daoist joy is most fitting,
Passionately fond of song and revelry, utterly enchanted.
In purity and stillness lies true delight,
Naturally, sleeves dance into the clouds.

**Again**
On Sanji Mountain, the rustic refines the great elixir,
Within the jade furnace, snow blankets all.
Awakened, one no longer flaunts a bearded might,
But humbly invites others to look with discerning eyes.

**Again**
Awakened, one feels no shame in begging for scraps,
How could fame or profit sway my being?
I urge all gentlemen to relinquish attachment,
And swiftly follow Ma Yu in seeking the formless.

**Again**
Swiftly focus the mind, restrain the monkey-heart,
Circulate the pure and void, let metal and wood flow.
Through ninefold refinement, the great medicine is perfected,
Forever as immortal kin, dwelling on Yingzhou.

**Inscribed at the Hall of Reverence for Antiquity, Office of the Military Commissioner of Jingzhao, for Secretary Wang Qingu**

Master Wang’s nature ever reveres antiquity,
Within his hall, dragons and tigers idly harmonize.
Day by day, month by month, inversion is achieved,
Naturally, the embryonic immortal dances forth.

**Again**
Master Qingu’s visage is ancient,
Having awakened to the lofty dragon and the watery tiger.
He submits to the wondrous mystery within the supreme principle,
Daring to dance with Ma and Feng upon the streets.

**Again**
Master Qingu upholds the primordial,
Before heaven and earth, the true dragon and tiger.
Emerging from height, entering the depths, east or west at will,
Startling the elixir-child to dance in response.

**Again**
Master Qingu comprehends the eternal,
Nurturing dragon and tiger within the formless.
Clear and pure, the primordial origin is revealed,
The carefree spirit-child dances before all.

**At Mafang, Visiting Lecturer Li the Younger Reading the *Nanhua Jing***

To seek texts and trace antiquity is to know much,
Yet awakening to the *Nanhua* deepens the mystery.
Better to cast aside the ten thousand entanglements,
Struggle free to grasp the one and ascend the celestial ladder.

**For Abbot Liu of Mafang Hermitage**

With whole heart enter the Dao, reaching the journey’s end,
The two qi harmonized, gathered with utmost care.
The three treasures—essence, spirit, qi—conjoin,
Through the four seasons, converging toward Yingzhou.

**For Little Zhang of Hu County**

When the young one asks of the Dao, the Dao remains wordless,
Yet purity sustains the most wondrous mystery.
Rely on this ancestral way, ever preserved,
Naturally, one has the destiny to become a divine immortal.

**For Little Wang of Hu County**

Young one, listen to the nurturing of the spirit-child,
By karmic cause, you follow the Ma-Feng lineage.
Through non-action and purity, awaken fully,
Naturally, your cloud-steps reach Penglai Palace.

**For Xu Qingshen of Qingzhen**

Ever entangled in the fiery household, never seeing the end,
A single body vainly bears a family’s sorrows.
Even if you settle all for them, it remains unsettled—
Better to still the heart and cease at once.

**For Wu Jieyuan of Hu County**

I encountered immortals, others encountered me,
Yet they remain like me, consumed by smoke and fire.
Nurturing qi, preserving truth, unstained by dust,
Naturally, one has the destiny to bear immortal fruit.

**For Duwu the Fifth of Hu County**

To cultivate immortality, first subdue self and ego,
Then within the waters, nurture the true fire.
Intent diminished, heart forgotten, without a speck of dust,
The elixir of nature congeals, the fruit of success ripens.

**Passing the Hanpi Verdant Hall in the Hu Countryside, Composed for Liang the Maiden of Yaozhou**

Form is emptiness, emptiness is form,
Form and emptiness both forgotten.
Since awakening to the form within emptiness,
Suddenly, the heart-lotus exudes jade-green fragrance.

**For Magistrate Pei of Li Springs**

Before your eyes, children grow into adults,
Their whiskers and beards like tarnished silver.
Do not blame my haggard and worn appearance—
They have stolen my finest spirit.

**For Master He of Chunhua, Gift of a Mottled Bamboo Staff as Travel Provision**

A single stalk, truly a dragon-transforming timber,
Struck to vanquish the three corpses, demons, and specters.
Blood-stained, mottled like tortoiseshell,
I gift it to you, to bear on your journey to Penglai.

**On the Lower Prime Day of the Ding-You Year, Exiting the Encircled Wall**

Dancing thus, truly hastened,
Recognizing the eternal origin’s true visage.
Master Father and Master Uncle descend to the world,
The auspicious moment directly pointed to the northwest.

**Reunion**

Master Father Chongyang, the Wondrous-Acting Perfected of Compassionate Transformation,
Master Uncle Yuchan, the Pure and Serene Perfected of Universal Clarity.
Having just passed Fufeng, I turned back in haste,
Specially visiting Qiyang to boast of my discerning eyes.
Again encountering my original master, obtaining the great elixir,
He instructed me to establish east, west, south, and north.

**On the Twenty-Eighth Day of the Mid-Winter Month, Re-Entering the Encircled Wall**

The wind howls, the wind-horse departs,
Roaming the northwest clouds for over a month.
Yet longing for my former retreat, I return,
Leaping once more into the encircled wall.

**Sealing the Doors and Windows**

From Kunyu, Sanji, and Ma Mountain, the rustic,
I firmly seal the doors and windows ninefold.
Revolving Kan and Li, Geng and Jia,
Unconcerned with south or north, east or west.

**[Quatrain]**

In the early winter of the Wuyin year of the Dading era, I journeyed from Longmen to the Taihe Hermitage in Huating, staying over ten days, intending to brush my sleeves and head for Kongtong.
On that day, I lingered only in the eastern quarters, staying one or two days at Master Gong’s hermitage.
At the time, there were Liu Zhaoxin, Pei Daqi, Li Dacheng, and over ten fellow Daoists from the city and suburbs.
I exhorted them through the night, yet not one turned their heart toward the Dao.
The next day, about to depart, I left this quatrain:

The cinnabar-refined Yang’s jade nature unfolds,
Cloud-roaming the northwest, selecting immortal timber.
The brocade-scaled fish eludes the empty cast,
I reel in my line and return.

**Li Dacheng of the Fishing Middle, Again Using the Previous Rhyme**

The foolish one’s nature suddenly opens wide,
A single spark of numinous yang, called chosen timber.
Let no dust or grime dim the heart,
In clarity, transmit the wondrous mystery.

**Four More Poems for Li Dacheng**

You’ve hooked the lost from the sea of suffering,
Together we walk and sit, freely roaming.
Entrusting the true within the heart, refining nature,
Attaining the wondrous, penetrating the mysterious, we wander the ten isles.

Once more, joyful that the worthy turns their head to join the current,
Awakening to wander the world within the gourd.
Clouds and waters require no toil of foot,
Naturally step by step one reaches Penglai Isle.

Once more,
Unfettered and carefree, flowing as one with the Dao,
Not following fame or profit, roaming beyond the dust.
Before returning to the cinnabar clouds of the celestial grotto,
First tread the Jasper Isle within the gourd.

Once more,
How fares the Great Vehicle’s harmonized essence?
Unattached, far surpassing all else uncelebrated.
Nature like a solitary cloud or lone crane,
Free and at ease—nothing surpasses this.

**Returning the Black Cap to Magistrate Zhao**
Carving through darkness, cleaving ignorance, no longer foolish,
Able to distinguish black from white, the jade nature crimson.
Master Wumao awakens to the bright moon,
The Red Pine Immortal scorns the pure wind.

**[Quatrain]**
Li Jichuan dreamed of receiving a quatrain from Master Cuan, and I thus matched it in praise:
Master Cuan once bowed to me as teacher,
His will steadfast, never for a moment wavering.
After the cicada’s molt, roots clearly seen,
By chance he descended to the world and left behind these verses.

**To Abbot Zhang Dawu of Huating County**
Upright words must be heeded,
Refine the root, solidify the source, qi steadies the spirit.
If the horse and monkey remain unruly,
Guard against unforeseen calamity befalling the body.

**To a Daoist Friend of Huating County**
Horse-like wind, compassionate vows emulating Vimalakīrti,
Ever grieving for the multitudes suffering deeply.
Exhortations in verse, if awakened to,
Spare them from rushing into fire like moths.

**To Madame He, Wife of Jiao Gong**
Youth has passed, yet still clinging to the boudoir,
Pity the deluded, unaware of autumn’s approach.
Before becoming utterly withered and worn,
Seek the wondrous mystery early, don the lotus crown soon.

**On the Winter Solstice, Gifting Charcoal to Vice Prefect Li Zhenguo of Longzhou**
Yang revives, the year renews,
I laugh at the poet’s excessive toil.
Breathing on the brush, madly chanting, inscribing jade slips,
Every thought and impulse—charcoal for dark fuel.

Once more,
Heaven’s Dao offers two paths to humanity,
In winter’s month, none are spared.
Scorching heat, proud qi mingling with ice,
In a poor hut’s cold stillness, even fire feels chill.

**Thanking Liu Sanlang of Longzhou for the Sheepskin Robe**
Frost clouds uniform, no variation,
Six-petaled flakes drift, sealing the old pass.
Deep gratitude to the true Daoist friend from Pengcheng,
Gifting me this fur robe to withstand winter’s cold.

**Parting from Longzhou**
Water and clouds wander by rule,
Flowing or reversing, none can fathom.
Within, revolving the mechanism of heaven and earth,
Comprehending the root source, truly one attains.

**On the Twenty-Ninth Day of the Seventh Month, Gengzi Year, Inscribed on the Eastern Wall of the Southern Dipper Pavilion at Taiping Palace, Zhongnan**
Fleeting as wind harms a speck of dust—gone,
Who would rush about like me?
The awakened turn their heads, grasp the wondrous,
Naturally, Penglai Isle is the journey’s course.

**On the Twenty-Fourth Day of the Eighth Month, Gengzi Year, Praying for Rain in Chang’an**
Barefoot, horse-like wind, praying for rain,
Heart’s incense curls toward the immortal court.
When will the plow receive its due moisture?
Five fives never stray from twenty-five.

Once more,
Shoots wither, the myriad people grieve,
Burning heart’s incense, auspicious qi rises.
Praying again, the Three Perfected descend together,
A sudden downpour—autumn’s harvest assured.

**Encountering a Crane While Visiting Gu Moke’s Study**
Cloud companions, rosy friends attend the feast,
Step by step, Gui Peak before me.
I seek the guest by the green lotus pool,
Others see the yellow crane’s immortal from the grotto.

**[Quatrain]**
Abbot Wuchang of Wutai came to serve tea, asking:
“They say clouds drift in azure skies, water rests in a vase—how so?”
The Moon Master spoke of ancients’ words,
“Clouds in azure skies, water in a vase.”
I understood: water and clouds reversed,
A stream’s wind and moon, wine just sobered.

**Matching Rhymes with Zhao Dianshi of Qiyang Town**
Ox, deer, and sheep carts overturned,
Few hold discourse, few act.
Having met and received direct transmission,
How could I deceive the parents of the ten directions?

Once more,
Two wheels swiftly come and go,
I ask myself—how many years?
Studying the *Yi*, past the age of hearing,
Yet stubbornly refusing my old wife’s deceit.

Once more,
Different names must be discussed in many ways,
Do not say they are unrelated to the mysterious.
If a scholar is swayed by wind and horse,
Naturally, he will not heed the pillow’s deceit.

Once more,
Nine-turning effort lies in the workings,
Do not say delving into the wondrous is irrelevant.
The profound principle is hard for people to grasp,
Before attaining clarity, endure the deceit.

Once more,
Abandoning that, clinging to this,
Loving the immortal’s essence, enduring shame.
Wood and metal’s threefold mystery,
Not wild words or clever deceit.

Once more,
Kan and Li exchange positions, circulating,
Coming and going, not externally.
I wish to confide in those who know me,
But others cling, calling it foolish.

Once more,
The Dao’s law is naturally distinct,
The wondrous mystery attained through sincerity.
Heaven’s mechanism is profound, not the common Dao,
Without meeting a true teacher, all is deceit.

Once more,
I have awakened to this and that,
Regardless of others’ concern or indifference.
Learning the Dao stems from true attainment,
Deceiving others is self-deception.

Once more,
Dragons and snakes rise from land, qi surging,
Sun and moon share a palace, not the ten stems.
Following this cultivation, immortality is certain,
Do not say Ma Yu deceives others.

Once more,
Immortal scriptures speak of refining and holding,
Yet deluded people refuse to act.
Managing household affairs in the mundane world, boasting of enlightenment,
Clearly, one deceives one’s own heart.

**Matching Rhymes with the Silver Brothers of Yaozhou**
Meeting the profound, interest endures,
Heart opens, awakens—best to leave the world.
Indolent at ease, forming true delight,
Laughable, the busy unaware of their busyness.

**Matching Rhymes Again, Purchasing from the Hou Brothers of Hezhong**
Within the gourd, refining, emerald clouds lengthen,
Repairing gardens and pavilions, no night in that land.
Seizing the flying crow and running hare,
Naturally, sun and moon are unhurried.

**Matching Rhymes with Magistrate Lei of Shuzheng County**
Your reputation surpasses Su Qin’s,
Unlike those who conceal their light, hiding their names.
Beyond things, carefree and truly unconstrained,
From the beginning, a single point is naturally bright.

Once more,
Stillness and clarity are the elixir of longevity,
Abandoning wife and children, no oral transmission.
After awakening, knowing emptiness, not clinging to existence,
Naturally, good causes and conditions are attained.

**On New Year’s Day**
Spring and summer return, autumn also shifts,
Last night’s lingering year-end swept away by the wind.

New Year’s Day, people say we gain a year,
I say this floating life loses one instead.

**For Liu Mengsong, Palace Examination Graduate of Gaoling**
Dreaming aright, you kept the eighteen elders whole,
Yet how could this compare to one spiritually attuned?
Majestic and radiant, worldly dust cannot stain,
Vast and dignified, your nature remains unvoid.

**Admonition to Spring Excursionists**
Seeking blossoms, chasing emeralds in lavish display,
How could you pause to sigh for falling flowers?
If you awaken to the truth of flourishing and decay,
Turn back beyond the world to refine cinnabar.

**Matching Xiao Pu’s “Affairs of the Garden” – A Warning to Sightseers**
Within the gourd, refinement yields eternal spring,
Yet you, in the fourth month, chase blossoms and green.
Cease your infatuation with butterflies’ frivolous dance,
Lest the flower’s allure ensnare your very being.

**Again**
Diligently tending the fire, you cling to grafting,
Never ceasing the sweet nectar upon lips and teeth.
With resolve, cultivate truth and banish sleep’s demon,
Without attachment to the false, tend the primal leaf.

**Inscribed on a Paper Fan**
Emotions severed, passions forgotten in stillness,
The heart bright, the spirit manifest—white plantain.
As jade-like radiance sways, a pure breeze arrives,
No need for frost-white silk to dispel summer’s heat.

**On Pomegranate Blossoms**
The courtyard ablaze with pomegranates red as fire,
Mocking peach and plum that chase fleeting bubbles.
Who knows that chrysanthemums by the eastern fence at frost’s dawn
Will blaze in fragrant splendor, claiming autumn alone?

**Quatrain**
For the Lord of Jingye Manor by White Horse River, who bestowed a crooked bamboo staff
Crooked and curved, destined to become a dragon’s timber,
Deep thanks for your noble gift to me.
One day, when the work is complete and truth fully realized,
I’ll ascend the clouds to visit Penglai with it in hand.

**Quatrain**
Lamenting how people only know to eat and defecate,
Never pausing to attend to their nature and life.
The grain cart enters, the dung cart departs,
This endless cycle—when will it end?
Even if granted a lifespan of a hundred years,
It amounts to no more than thirty-six thousand days.

**Quatrain**
People cling to a couplet from the ancients:
*“First, you must experience all worldly affairs,
Then seek the mechanism of transcendence.”*
Yet this principle is not entirely sound.
Worldly affairs are boundless, without end,
To claim you’ve “experienced them all” is itself a fallacy.

Do better to see through all attachments as nothingness,
Then naturally you penetrate the mysterious and grasp the wondrous mechanism.

**Admonition to the Foolish**
Alas, how foolish people are—
Dwelling in a fiery house, they seek a red-hot furnace.
Not only do they fail to reach a place of coolness,
How can they escape the stench and filth of the ditch?

**Admonition to the Wicked**
A deep sigh for the wicked,
Who rely on power to bully others for their own amusement.
Day by day, their stubborn hearts breed evil;
In the end, how will they withstand the torments of the evil realms?

**The Sixteen Battlegrounds**
Fire, wind, earth, and water bind the skin-sack;
The four demon-kings of eye, ear, nose, and tongue.
Self and others, right and wrong sow the seeds of karma;
Qi, wealth, wine, and lust—these are the execution grounds of men.

**Distinguishing Right from Wrong**
Wind, flowers, snow, and moon bring no true benefit;
Wine, lust, anger, and wealth are all enemies.
Self and others, right and wrong summon ghostly destinies;
Only in pure tranquility and virtue does the immortal’s boat ferry one across.

**Urging Resolute Entry into the Dao**
Silken blades, felt arrows, paper spears—
How can these seize the immortal’s banner and join the Dao’s current?
A true man of resolve and courage,
To escape life and death, must turn his gaze at once.

**To Fellow Daoists**
If your heart is set on entering the Dao, do not delay,
Lest procrastination age the worthy before their time.
Today’s affairs are unknown by tomorrow;
How dare one presume upon next year?

**Again**
The path to long life is worth pursuing,
Yet impermanence is better for stilling the heart.
Roaming like clouds and water, seek good companions,
And naturally, you will encounter true kindred spirits.

**Instructing Disciples**
Every thought and worry harms the spirit;
How dare one linger in the dust of entanglements?
Cutting off the ten thousand conditions, all is illusion;

My vow transcends the mundane, to ferry others,
Rising in mercy, saving the afflicted—greater sorrow.
I urge all to shun karmic debts of foe and kin,
Learning from me, to gather the Dipper’s handle in spring.

**Forgetting Thoughts**
As a pillar of the Dao’s gate,
I grieve for others’ woes—deeper still my grief.
Gazing at the passes, Qin’s river scenes,
I recall no more the fields of my native spring.

**Instructing Disciples**
Break free from fame’s reins, profit’s chains,
Escape the fiery household’s myriad pains.
In water, fire arises—banish the heart’s illusions,
Amid snow, flowers bloom—extinguish desire’s spring.

**Again**
Ever diminishing, a heart unstained,
Leisurely nurturing qi, speaking no pain.
Ninefold clouds manifest heaven and earth’s auspice,
A single yang stirs—spring across the land.

**Again**
The Three Corpses, Six Bandits—all demonic men,
Waging war, toiling in hardship, pain upon pain.
Slaying demons with the sword within the heart,
Perfecting wondrous visions—spring in the cavern’s depths.

**Exhorting the World**
Wine, lust, wrath, wealth—four poisons of men,
In suffering, the bitterest pain breeds pain.
Ensnared by the world’s fleeting splendor,
Unenlightened to the immortals’ eternal spring.

**Again**
Fire, wind, earth, water—briefly make a man,
Why toil endlessly in labor and pain?
Awaken to the immortal blossom, blooming in all seasons,
Cease delusion in the common flowers’ fleeting spring.

**Again**
Farmers, scholars, artisans, merchants—four ranks of men,
Each covets achievement, suffering in pain.
Unknowing that fleeting scenes hasten old age,
How to grasp the eternal truth that benefits one’s spring?

**Again**
I urge butchers, hunters, and scholars,
Expending my spirit—greater still my pain.
Seizing non-action, hard to grasp being,
Promoting the Great Dao surpasses wandering spring.

**Again**
Beyond the world, carefree and joyous,
Cultivating without suffering, without pain.
Phoenixes soar to Penglai’s scenes,
Tigers roar in dragon palaces—spring in the sea’s depths.

**Again**
As one who polishes the heart’s mirror,
Why speak of deep suffering or deep pain?
In play, finding play—scenes beyond the wall,
Amid dust, dustless—spring of transcendence.

**Again**
A heart entangled in thorns deceives,
Burning incense in vain, enduring pain.
Sever worldly passions, dissolve karma,
Accumulating harmony—spring’s growth renewed.

**Again**
Mysterious words benefit all beings,
Upholding pure precepts, avoiding impure pain.
Ever drinking the nectar of enlightenment,
Forever beholding the lotus—no spring’s illusion.

**To My Hometown Kin**
I am no base man of my village,
Never have I borne suffering or pain.
Meeting my master, he taught the principle of non-action,
Freeing me from delusion in this finite spring.

**Again**
A man of the world’s farthest corners,
Naturally leaving suffering, leaving pain.
Leisurely observing the eight rivers’ subtle currents,
Delighting in the three regions’ brocade-like spring.

**Again**
Learning the Dao, cultivating immortality—an extraordinary man,
Wholly shunning suffering, enduring hardship.
Tiger and dragon exchange places—profound joy,
Sun and moon intertwine—radiant spring.

**Again**
A resolute man, bold and generous,
Fearing neither toil nor pain.
Mastering creation, wielding divine power,
Reversing yin and yang—all transforms in spring.

**To Xu, Registrar of Jingzhao Prefecture**
In the fiery household, vainly entangled,
Calculating vain suffering, vain pain.
How much better to seek the path of longevity,
Than to cultivate without end—spring unceasing.

**To Liu, Legal Officer of Jingzhao**
Fame and profit like drunken wine,
Lost in suffering, deeper in pain.
Knowing only the fleeting pleasures of renown,
How to awaken to Penglai’s enduring spring?

**Again**
Life’s limit no more than a hundred years,
Why add suffering to suffering, pain?
Withdraw swiftly from the golden fetters,
Resolve to diligently cultivate the jade cavern’s spring.

**To Old Lady Zhang of Huxian and Fellow Daoist Sisters**
An extraordinary woman, unlike others,
Mastering the Three Wonders and Six Pains.
Jade trees ever flourishing, ever nourished,
Jasper flowers never fading, untouched by spring.

**To Lady Wang of Huxian and Fellow Daoist Sisters**
Leisurely and serene, nurturing the true,
Needing no wine, meat, or pungent pain.
Three cups of nectar—thousand-year longevity,
One peach of Penglai—ten thousand springs.

**To Lady Zhao of Huxian and Fellow Daoist Sisters**
Cultivating the elixir in non-action and purity,
Spared from the red dust’s myriad pains.
In the Mystic Garden, planting the fruit of no-leakage,
In the watery realm, withering all remnants of spring.

**To Elder Liu and Jiang of Willow Village**
Who is the kind-hearted man?
Elder of Willow Village, bearing pain.
Awakening to the Dao, hard to be deluded by worldly scenes,
Cultivating the true, easily seeing the cavern’s spring.

**To Wang Wude, Young Lady of Qin Town’s Wine Bureau, on Her Leaving Home**
Entering the mystery, delighting in heaven,
Refining qi—never enduring pain.
I realize what cannot be gathered,
Naturally, it is not the spring of mountain peaks.

**Again**
Beyond the world, carefree and at ease,
Neither heart’s suffering nor heart’s pain.
In the furnace, nurturing the cool flame,
In the cauldron, forging the great medicine’s spring.

**To Little Zhang, Registrar of Xianyang, and Fellow Daoists**
On Xianyang’s paths, men of past and present,
Lured by profit, bound by fame—bitter pain.
How does it compare to mastering the Three Ravines’ snow?
Or cultivating through the four seasons’ spring?

**To Gao Changshan of Qianzhou**
To become a man of Penglai’s three isles,
No need to speak of suffering or shun pain.
Reflecting on heaven’s two or three years,
Already exchanged for a million springs on earth.

**To Master Shi of Wugong**
I serve the Wind Immortal, transforming and guiding,
Spared from life and death’s suffering and pain.
A heart serene, spirit luminous,
Breath harmonized—eternal spring.

**To Little Immortal Li of Fengxian**
Neither covetous nor attached—a man beyond the ordinary,
Serene and carefree, how could I endure pain?
Jade trees branch in a thousand splendid forms,
Golden lotuses bloom for ten thousand springs.

**To Clerk He of Longzhou**
Ten thousand, a thousand men of fame and profit—
Who among them knows suffering, knows toil?
If you grasp the wondrous subtleties of my Dao,
Unseen blessings bring spring to your noble household.

**To Prefect Shang of Longzhou**
Cast aside the man of golden willows, jade bracelets,
Awakened at leisure—would you bear hardship and labor?
Perfected yet without a place of perfection,
Seize the Void, and you seize spring.

**[Quatrain]**
Once more I leave Longhan,
Revisiting Dragon Gate Mountain.
Li Zihe, Provincial Graduate, sees me off—
Together we lodge at the Goudou Fortress inn.
That night, I hear a neighbor’s death, grief unending.
I compose this to gift him:

Ears ever hear the wailing of the dead,
Nose unwittingly drips with bitter sorrow.
To mourn another—how unlike mourning oneself!
Seeing the Dao surpasses eternal spring.

**[Quatrain]**
Li Zihe of Longzhou, Provincial Graduate, enters the Dao,
Given the Dharma name *Great Stem*, styled *Master Spirit-Root*.
Cease mourning those who have passed,
Mourn yourself, sigh at vain toil.
Hasten to cultivate long life and eternal vision,
To gain the reward of Jade Terrace and Penglai’s spring.

**To Physician Gao Xiaoshu**
Gao, refined scholar, wise healer of men,
Handles bitter *ku shen* and fine *xi xin*.
How does it compare to perfecting Penglai’s path?
Or delighting in the grotto-heaven’s spring?

**To Xu Xuanji of Longzhou**
Pure and still, a true Daoist,
Free from bitterness, free from toil.
Three thousand merits fulfilled in three thousand days,
Twelve celestial cycles—twelve springs.

**To Dan Shanrou of Longzhou**
Sever ties to wine, lust, qi, and wealth,
Spare yourself suffering and toil at home.
Resolute, turn back—a guest of the Three Isles,
Cultivate to drink from the Ten Continents’ spring.

**To Guo Shanneng**
Unfettered, carefree, a man beyond the world,
No sorrow, no suffering, no hardship.
Secure the eternal treasure of the Three Fields,
Delight in the primal four seasons’ spring.

**To Wei Daoqing**
Singing with a full belly, a man joyful in the Dao,
Naturally free from suffering, free from toil.
Within the gourd, a scene unlike common scenes,
In the grotto, spring harbors a spring apart.

**To Zhang Xuancheng**
Unrestrained, untethered, a man of leisure,
Shaking off the toil of labored life.
Stroking the heart’s zither, golden phoenixes dance,
Probing the jade tree, jade hall’s spring.

**To Zhao Balang of Longzhou**
Astute, clever—yet the most foolish of men,
Toiling for family, enduring bitter labor.
Heed not the century that slips through your hands,
Vainly chasing fleeting glory’s transient spring.

**Seven Poems to Magistrate Xin of Longzhou**
Magistrate Xin of Longzhou, three months in office,
Meets me and urges the study of the Dao.
He says: "I’ve only just received three months’ salary."
Thus I compose these verses.

I. Crane’s cry before the cliff, a man of the thatched hall,
Glad to see one who passed the imperial exams’ toil.
A scholar seeks promotion to the first rank,
A hermit gains no thousand springs of life.

II. Horse and wind—poems from a man of letters,
Each with his own family’s ways, each recounting toil.
A new official’s three months’ salary,
An old friend beyond the world, through countless springs.

III. I shake my head, heedless of others,
Why offer poems and songs with such labor?
Friends of cloud and mist, bound by past vows,
Mending and perfecting the grotto’s spring.

IV. Horse and wind, clinging to past affinities,
Often reciting verses, braving the toil of study.
I urge you: seek early the path to Penglai,
Naturally you’ll gain the reward of Dongting’s spring.

V. These subtle wonders—whom shall I entrust?
Speak to the true friend of former lives’ toil.
Lotus steps open the path of red snow,
Cloud traces lead to the peach blossoms’ spring.

**At Prefect Xiao of Longzhou’s Request, Also Presented to Magistrate Xin**
A man whose heart is tempered and refined,
Speaks to the prefect and magistrate of toil.
One day, should you ascend the Three Isles’ path,
Today you meet the advent of yang’s spring.

**To Zheng Chengde, Magistrate Xin of Longzhou, with Three-Character Lines**
□□ on the Dao’s path—who is permitted?
□□ the Three Dukes, guarding Zheng’s toil.
□□ when promises are made, literary prefaces arise,
□□ singing in harmony with Wuling’s spring.

**To Ma Xuanzhong of Huating**
Shedding family ties, leaving the vulgar,
Naturally spared the toil of suffering.
The Dao cultivated, a thousand layers of karma dissolved,
The elixir refined, ten thousand kalpas’ spring complete.

**To Dong Yushi of Huating, Who Entered the Dao at Thirteen**
Young man, cease calling others strange,
Truly cultivate—do not shrink from toil.
Boast not of black hair before others,
How can you know the mirror’s fleeting youth?

**To Lu Zhourui of Baiyan Town**
Joyful in the Dao, carefree and expansive,
Naturally without labor, without toil.
In the grotto, refine the golden cauldron’s medicine,
Within the gourd, delight in the jade tower’s spring.

**To Zhu Xuanjue of Huaping County**
Clearly I tell the one who leaves the household:
Renounce the foul, spurn the five pungents’ toil.
Cease seeking long vision from me,
Return beyond the world to inquire of eternal spring.

**To Zheng Shanxin**
Beyond the world, carefree and at ease,
Harmonizing *jia*, *yi*, *geng*, and *xin*.
In the grotto, ever with the immortals,
Within the gourd, idly observing ageless spring.

**To Zhao Zhirou of Huaping County**
Fiercely turn back, a man beyond the world,
Spared ten thousand sorrows, a thousand toils.
In the furnace, summer’s nine days cool as water,
In the tripod, winter’s three months warm as spring.

**To Cao, Provincial Graduate of Fangzhou**
I urge you: recognize purity, shun worldly men,
Why cling to karmic toil and suffering?
Do you not know the years hasten man’s aging?
One spring passes—no spring returns.

II. Burdened by family, deluded by cares,
Too hasty in pursuit, too hasty in toil.
Dying in bitterness, not knowing bitterness is bitter,
Spring gone—how can spring return?

III. Alone bearing the family, providing for all,
No one to share suffering, share toil.
Wearying the heart with illusions, aging in vain,
Awakened, I grasp the true and hold spring.

IV. Awakened, shedding the vulgar—not a fool,
Spared the toil of labored life.
Life transforms the Five Phases, transcends creation,
Nature connects the Nine Turns—spring arises naturally.

V. Truly a man of single-minded cultivation,
When has he known sorrow, known toil?
The primal elixir congeals the mysterious treasure,
A grain of millet hides the pearl beyond the world’s spring.

**To Old Man Sha of Ninghai**
Delighting in his walled garden, a man of refined taste,
When has he known sorrow, known toil?
Able to gather the White Tiger’s flawless elixir,
Skilled to guide the Green Dragon—grotto’s spring abides.

**To Master Zhou of Wenshan**
A man in straw cloak and staff, carefree and idle,
Heart opened wide, loath to speak of toil.
Who would believe the grotto-heaven’s paradise,
Where no flowers bloom, no willows sway—yet spring abides.

**Again**
Wealth, lust, wine, and beauty most harm men,
The fiery household seethes with bitter pain.
Often they fret not for autumn’s coming scene,
Blindly clinging to spring before their eyes.

**To Li Maochun of Chang’an**
□ days hasten, aging man,
□ suddenly feels suffering, startled by toil.
□ discerns awakening, turns to the Dao,
□ thus, Chang’an’s Li Maochun.

**Again (composing from three characters)**
□□ often calls you a good man,
□□ fears hardship, dreads toil.
□□ knows all stems from filial piety,

**Regulated Verse in Seven Characters**
**[In Gratitude to My Master]**
Master Chongyang, the Wondrous Practitioner of Compassionate Transformation, drew me from the household—thus I compose this poem to thank my master’s mercy.

The mountain rustic mused on past freedom,
Amid the fiery household, worry and sorrow.
Seeking wealth and rank through myriad hardships,
Entangling endless grievances in toil.
Pondering life and death—how to escape?
Serving wife and children—when will it end?
Just as I sought to return, what fortune!
The Immortal of the Wind hooked me out to roam the clouds.

**Again**
The mountain rustic escaped the fiery pit’s woe,
Entering the Dao, no longer harmed by sorrow.
Day by day, carefree in song and chant,
Hour by hour, at ease in joyful praise.
Verdant mist and purple haze ever his companions,
Bright moon and clear wind his eternal peers.
Guiding kind souls to the Great Dao,
Cultivating merit to perfection, he ascends to Penglai.

**At Jiande**
Daoists have no kin yet none are not kin,
Grieving for all things, grieving for oneself.
Heart arises in compassion, enacting great virtue,
Mind devoid of attachment, revealing spirit.
Worldly realms are constantly swept aside,
The flawless garden renews itself daily.
Silently accumulating merit, merit fulfilled,
He rides the clouds to pay homage to the true master.

**Self-Description**
Three topknots—yet not out of piety,
If asked the reason, how could it be told?
Promoting the master’s name, one should bear it on the crown,
Concealing the scholar’s □, the heart remains steadfast.
Who knows that in this world, the mountain rustic,
Yields not to the unicorn immortal of the celestial court?
Today I reveal it plainly to you:
When merit is complete, he will tread the clouds and mist.

**Again**
Myriad entanglements seen through, all return to emptiness,
From this, cultivation bears fruit early.
The horse of the mind struggles against deluded love,
The monkey of the heart easily falls into folly.
Qi and spirit settle, the golden elixir congeals,
Dragon and tiger clarify, the jade nature glows red.
I report to fellow practitioners: rely on wondrous use,
Together we refine and ascend to Penggong.

**Again**
Doting on a wife is no wise man,
Lusting after beauty is truly a fool.
Even slight attachment invites poisonous hands,
The merest thought ensnares one in demonic bonds.
Essence withers, marrow dries, the form grows gaunt,
Qi scatters, spirit wanes, ghosts drag one away.
I awoke, I startled—best to flee early,
Why wait until the funeral drum’s lament?

**Linked Pearls Ode**
My heart ails, my heart heals,
People judge right and wrong—who truly knows?
Searching the wondrous, searching the profound, searching to grasp the true,
No contention, no competition, no forced cultivation.
Ever pure, ever still, ever generating goodness,
Demanding the Dao, demanding practice, demanding salvation from peril.
Cherishing jade, cherishing benevolence, cherishing deliverance,
Rousing the heart, rousing the mind, rousing compassion.

**Regulated Verse**
**Composed at the Request of Attendant Secretary Wanyan**
Attendant Secretary Wanyan remarked: "I did not expect you, Master, would dwell in a thatched hut within walled confines, enduring such carefree simplicity." Thus, I composed this.

Within the Horse Family Alley, the Ma family’s home,
North residence, south garden—nothing to boast.
What glory and splendor are not mere livelihood?
This carefree ease is the finest way of life.
Body and mind depart the vulgar, refining the golden cavern,
Clouds and waters turn to the mysterious, planting jade sprouts.
Suddenly, the world before my eyes feels narrow,
Within the gourd, sun and moon congeal the numinous cinnabar.

**Ode to Autumn Scenery**
The year’s finest scene lies in late autumn,
The Dipper points west, fire’s course flows.
Vital qi gathers essence, revealing wondrous use,
Frost flies to meet the season, responding to true cultivation.
Chrysanthemums bloom, ever evoking Tao Qian’s spirit,
Leaves fall, utterly devoid of Song Yu’s sorrow.
Toward dawn, wind clear, stream bright beneath the moon,
Someone awakens and sets forth for Penglai.

**Presented to Liu Bohu of Gaoling, Awaiting the Palace Examination**
Beyond Pengcheng’s worldly bounds, I search meticulously,
At the moment of awakening, all affairs cease.
Sitting or lying, no hindrance to leading the white deer,
Dwelling or walking, unimpeded in guiding the green ox.
Ever pure, ever still—one must recognize this,
True practice, true merit—decisively complete the cycle.
When the ninefold elixir is perfected, depart for Pengdao,
To specially seek the ancestral master, Liu Haichan.

**Exhorting Disciples**
Cultivation must abandon lust and wealth,
Beware the cup’s temptation, lest calamity arise.
Quickly cast aside the self and others, lay them low,
Hastily strike open the dragon-tiger’s cave.
The elixir forms, snow-white pellets gleam in the golden tripod,
Nature congeals, frost-like spheres radiate on the jade terrace.
White clouds ever fly at the grotto’s mouth,
When merit is complete, ascend to Penglai.

**Again**
Contending for fame, competing for profit—endless toil,
Unnoticed, the visage ages, temples turn gray.
Greed for wife and children brings bodily suffering,
How would one know the Dao’s virtue ever grows?
I hope you swiftly secure spirit and qi,
Learn from me, diligently refining lead and mercury’s frost.
When merit and practice accumulate, true nature manifests,
Together we shall ascend to Pengzhuang.

**Composed Upon Bringing Li Dacheng into the Walled Abode**
In the northwest, by the pavilion stream, a walled abode,
Here one may well conceal this body.
Before my eyes, emerald bamboo—several gentlemen,
Facing green pines—two great men.
Flowing water, artificial hills—mere child’s play,
Clear wind, bright moon—do you comprehend?
If you can grasp my planting of nine,
I, within these walls, plant leeks and scallions—thus I dwell here.
There is a share of numinous light to ascend to the Jade Capital.

**Presented to Zhang Zhengfu of Danxia Abbey in Qiyang**
Daoists have no kin yet none are not kin,

Heart arises in compassion, enacting great virtue,

Worldly realms are constantly swept aside,

**Presented to Li Dacheng, with respects to Abbot Jinggong**

Within encircling walls, most serene,
The Dao’s abode—pure emptiness—claims two rafters.
Deeply I cherish the bamboo’s gentlemanly resolve,
How I admire the pine’s aged, virtuous wisdom.
Eight channels’ limpid waters distill as clear wine,
Five Peaks’ linked summits rise like verdant lotuses.
Though Confucian scholars serve as beneficent friends,
Without the Three Teachings united, no harmony is complete.

**Presented to Master Zhang of Jingyang**

At sixty-four, the hexagrams near their close,
Suddenly awakened, heart reduced to ashes, I wander beyond the mundane.
Seeking me, you submit to true awakening,
Delving into mysteries, probing subtleties, you cultivate with devotion.
Your topknot parted like cloud-and-aurora companions,
Your hands raised like wind-and-moon comrades.
Bowing, you further clarify the precious principle—
Naturally, you shall depart to attend Penglai’s isles.

**Matching Rhymes for the Old Man of the Moon**

Having known the non-dual Dao precedes heaven,
Your tally matches the mountain rustic’s most wondrous words.
Simurgh and phoenix soar to nest in jade caverns,
Tiger and dragon roar to enter golden gates.
Within the gourd, heaven and earth’s marrow is refined,
Within the grotto, the roots of heaven and earth are shaken.
A single millet-pearl cradles sun and moon—
Dim yet luminous, neither dark nor dull.

**Matching Rhymes for Gao Neifeng**

Though you speak of officialdom’s dusty clamor,
Why must you rush through this life in haste?
Swiftly sever the ten thousand entanglements like snapped stalks,
Lest your singular nature drift like floating duckweed.
Emerging from the sea of suffering, the heart awakens,
Dispersing floating clouds, the moon shines clear.
When merit and practice reach perfection, you transcend the upper realms—
Only then do you know Ma Yu’s initiation of cinnabar sincerity.

**Matching Rhymes for Ning Bogong’s Poem on Gifting Silver Dates**

Seven-jeweled, exquisitely wrought, treasures of the hidden realm,
Bearing rare fruits and extraordinary greens.
Externally, powdered husks wholly encase jade,
Internally, water-crystal forms half-veiled in frost.
Refined with civil and martial fires to enhance their savor,
Boiled in pagoda-tree broth to deepen their fragrance.
I imagine you first tasted this delight—
Upon receiving your gift, this mountain rustic welcomes the true yang.

**Visiting Abbot Zhang Detong of Xiulin for the Palace Examination**

Beneath Gui Peak lies Xiulin Village,

Parting clouds to summon cranes, I come to seek instruction,

Wuwei purity—dragon coils, tiger crouches,
The great Dao’s spontaneity—phoenix births unicorns.
If Confucian Zhang and the suffering son awaken,
The Three Teachings shall converse of everlasting spring.

Three gentlemen accompany me on a journey with the Nine Immortals,

Relying on nine-three for wondrous efficacy,

Nurture water and fire well within the furnace,

One day, when the elixir’s work is complete and radiant,

Cease saying one cultivates while in the world,

Cloud companions and rosy friends discourse on longevity.

Heaven and earth wholly return to the golden-jade crucible,

As the years draw near the downward slope,

**Matching Rhymes for Commissioner Zhou Sigong**

Beyond things, carefree, you follow nature,

Vast and unobstructed, you observe the gourd’s inner scenes,
Lush and verdant, you repair the grotto’s heavens.
When merit is complete and practice fulfilled, you ride the clouds away—

**Matching Rhymes for Sun Gongzhidian of Ninghai Commandery**

I wish you would awaken to relinquish the ten thousand entanglements,

In cultivation, there is turning and harmonizing of water and fire,

□ maiden lingers to behold the great elixir,

□ clouds spread earthward, the alchemical furnace blazing,
□ child gazes heavenward, azure eyes radiant.
□ with three lifetimes, you awaken,
□ within, untroubled, you tread mist and rosy clouds.

**Presented to Master Jiang**

The Abbot of Changchun Hermitage in Ninghai, Master Jiang,
Along with fellow Daoist friends, pitying my difficulty in walking,
Constructed a handcart for me.
On the day the work was completed, he came to Fushan to deliver it,
So I composed these words in gratitude.

Blue ox, white deer, and yellow sheep,
Steadily pull the cloud chariot day and night.
Bearing the weight of heaven and earth, ever in union,
Pushing the sun and moon, their light eternally intertwined.
The Dharma wheel resounds, entering the dark cavern,
The cloud carriage jingles, entering the Daoist sanctuary.
If you awaken to the nine revolutions of the elixir,
Naturally you shall succeed Ma Danyang.

**Presented to the Daoist Assembly at the Huanglu Offering in Wendeng County**

On Kunyu’s three-chignon steeds, Ma and Feng sing,
Meeting those who cultivate immortality, weary of worldly affairs.
I dwell in non-action to fulfill my original vow,
While others seek memorial rites, tormented by suffering.
Through empowerment, I assist the offering within these humble walls,
Delivering departed souls to the Great Luo Heaven.
Fortunate are the lingering spirits and solitary souls,
All together transcended in boundless joy.

**Again**

Since first encountering the joy of pure poverty,
Delighted to dwell within these enclosing walls, fearing the dust of the world.
Refining qi, qi harmonizes, spirit clings to qi,
Nurturing spirit, spirit is refreshed, qi settles spirit.
Magistrate Zai invited me to perform memorial rites,
This humble one, with compassionate heart, upholds the good cause.
Delivering departed souls to ascend the upper realms,
All solitary spirits and lingering souls turn toward the True.

**Burning Heart Incense** *(originally titled "Xingxiangzi")*

Husband and wife parted—
Who are you? Who am I?

With their household—originally no kinship,
All through matchmakers’ words, we bound in marriage.
Then fell to folly’s cliff, craving wealth and property,
Only dreading poverty.
You too lost in dust, I too lost in dust.
Managing family ties—burning oneself in fire.
Drawn by their affection, enslaved in my heart and spirit.
Fortunate to meet Master Fengxian,
Parting ways, each cultivating the True.
Going forth to teach on the streets

Master Chongyang, truly a true teacher,
Instructed Ma Yu to live as a beggar.
His livelihood pure and still, his path non-action.
Stroking the heart’s zither, harmonizing dragon and tiger,
Drinking the elixir pellet.
Vowing never to return to Shandong,
For his destiny lay in Guanzhong.
Thus blending light, mingling with the world as time flows.
Idly wielding the bamboo skimmer,
Only wishing others to know.
Hoping not to return too late,
Lest time pass in vain—hasten your practice.

To all fellow disciples

Not yet reaching Danyang,
How dare I claim to be a teacher?
To those of like mind, I reveal a little.
The wondrous place of longevity
Seems to require some effort.
Gathering five-colored clouds,
The qi of the Five Phases, the tablets of the Five Directions.
A rooster born in the west, a rabbit born in the east—
Such is the time of wood and metal’s separation.
In purity, the meaning is grasped;
In clarity, the heart knows.
Wishing for early purity of heart,
Early clarity of intent,
Early practice.

Exhorting Brother Xiang to beg for leftovers

A tumbleweed beyond the world, starving within,
Suddenly hearing the temple bell strike—
Begging for leftovers, praying to the Mysterious Origin.
Remember, those who leave the household
Have no home, no land—Daoist poverty.
Hemp and wheat fill the meal,
Dispelling corpse-worms.
Awakening to an empty heart,
A full belly, harmony within.
The infant rides the tiger, the maiden mounts the dragon.
In the realm of emptiness,
Coming without trace, going without shadow.

**Again**

Sudden enlightenment, carefree—
The causes of leaving the world.
Hearing only of others
Building feast-halls,
One stretches out one’s arms,
Standing at the side—
Begging for leftover broth,
Seeking scraps of rice,
Passing the remnant years.
Shameless, unabashed,
Quenching fire, dispelling smoke.
Then turning the mind
To seek the wondrous, to seek the mysterious,
Unfolding the jade bud,
Gathering the golden lotus.
Feeling qi and spirit clear,
Spirit radiant—
Becoming an immortal.

**For Master Wang the Fifth, Presenting Food Within the Enclosure Wall**
Teach them to remove what should be removed,
Yet they vie to prepare feast-kitchens.
Brothers weary,
Wasting effort in vain.
Better to rest early,
To recognize the primordial origin—
There, seek the root of clouds,
Follow the feet of clouds,
Tread the cloud thoroughfare.
Breathing like a tortoise,
Seeming to exist, seeming not—
Feeling harmony and ease
In coming and going.
Turning mountains and peaks,
Inhaling rivers and lakes.
Giving birth to the immortal embryo,
Forming immortal substance,
Ascending to the immortal capital.

**Chanting Incense**
Not burning aloeswood,
Idly burning the incense of the heart.
Spreading the wind of benevolence,
Everywhere incense is heard.
Each person turns toward goodness,
Each cherishes incense.
Wishing to abide in non-action,
Ever pure and still—
Naturally fragrant.
Wondrous cavern-cloud incense,
Tiger’s roar sprays fragrance.
Moreover, the dragon’s chant
Exhales fragrant scent.
Jade forms the precious talisman,
Gold binds the cinnabar incense.
Attaining the journey to Penglai,
Transcending the Three Realms,
Offering true incense.

**Chanting the Crane**
Though dwelling among chickens,
Like a phoenix amassing down—
Ever since Ding Ling
Manifested thus.
Frost-white feathers, crimson crest,
Jade wings, jade-like flesh.
Feeding on duckweed in Taihu,
Nibbling chestnuts by the pool,
Crying to the clouds and rainbow.
At dawn, playing in the field of mushrooms,
At dusk, drinking from the Jasper Pond.
Awaiting Wang Qiao
To come and rein it in.
Dancing in the market of Wu,
Riding the strange chariot of Wei—
Then pointing toward Penglai,
Morning court in the golden palace,
Ascending to the cinnabar steps.

**Exhortation to the World**
Visage ashen,
Whiskers and temples streaked with gray.
Yet still foolishly deluded,
Envious, greedy, miserly.
Not worrying for oneself,
But caressing wife and children.
Crafty thoughts arise,
No mind to yield,
No heart to relax.
In the waves of the bitter sea,
Ever bound to the fire-house.
Deploying schemes,
Accumulating karma like mountains.
Not seeking the Great Dao,
Ever obstinate and dull.
Who among you knows—
Cultivating immortality is easy,
Nurturing a family is hard.

**Karmic Retribution of Good and Evil**
Those who do evil,
Violent and unmatched—
Carefully considering,
What can they do?
In life, facing official law,
In death, meeting King Yama.
As prisoners in hell,
Pounded in mortars,
Ground in mills.
Those who accumulate goodness,
Reverent, humble, harmonious—
Carefully considering,
They surpass all.
Black ledgers hard to collect,
How could they enter penal courts?
Moreover, divine spirits protect them,
Households prosper,
Descendants multiply.

**Inscribed for Master Wu at the Eastern Gallery**
Sixth month’s severe cold,
Twelfth month’s scorching heat—
This true work,
Clearly inverted.
Within yang, yin reaches its extreme;
Within yin, yang is born.
From the midst of the Five Phases,
Who has walked this path?
I walk the journey.
Myriad golden lotuses,
Ever flourishing in fire.
Within water, beholding
The red flames ascending.
The two gathered together,
One nature perfectly accomplished.
Then wearing the Three Flowers,
Combing the three topknots,
Bowing to the Three Pure Ones.

**For the Two Directors, Zhang and Liu**
I exhort Qinghe,
Urge Pengcheng—
And all gentlemen,
Cease wearying the spirit.
Swiftly leave the fire-house,
Early depart the sea of delusion.
Though roaming with water and clouds,
Return beyond things,
Becoming a person of leisure.
Truly cultivating the Dao,
Washing away the dust of the heart.
With cloud companions,
Rosy friends as kin,
Delving into enduring vision,
Discoursing on longevity.
Then awakening to the mysterious,
Penetrating the wondrous,
Attaining the true.

**Thanks to Elder Li of Xingping County and His Wife for Offering Their Son to Study the Dao**
This offering is no ordinary thing,
The cause of leaving the world.
Forsaking their beloved child,
Entering the Dao to seek the mysterious.
Each person praises their goodness,
Each calls them virtuous.
Then their name spreads far,
Far-spreading fame,
Beyond the land of Qin.
The deep kindness of parents—
To repay it, heed these words:
We must capture
The mind-monkey.
Qi flows through the eight vessels,
Merit fills the three fields.
Saving the Nine Mysterious Lords,
Seven generations of ancestors,
Together becoming immortals.

**For the Traveling Merchant, Master Fan**
The rustic of Three-Topknot Mountain,
Sighs for Master Fan—
Trading alum in the waves
Of the bitter sea.
To dispel afflictions,
Assist with a sail’s wind.
Then abandoning splendor,
Leaving the burning fire,
Exiting the mundane cage.
Truly carefree,
Truly not deluded.
Guarding true purity,
Vying for true merit.
True and true mutually aiding,
True nature crystal-clear.
Then attaining the true wind,
Accomplishing true essence,
Manifesting true countenance.

**For Officer Peng**
Yesterday an officer,
Today a companion of immortals.
Awakening to floating life,
Like bubbles on water.
Suddenly born, suddenly gone,
Hard to preserve, hard to retain.
Then becoming wildly free,
Achieving elegance,
Galloping with the wind.
Heart and mind at ease,
Roaming with clouds and water.
Taking qi, wealth,
Wine, and sensuality as foes.
Dharma name: "Thus Thus,"
Daoist name: "Rest Rest."
Recognizing the original face,
Without coming or going—
A fine cause.

**For Masters Yang and Ma of Fufeng County**
Wishing that each person
Pierce through floating life,
Swiftly withdrawing,
Fiercely abandoning worldly passions.
Leaving wife, parting from children,
Cutting off profit, forgetting fame.
Then suddenly awakening,
Suddenly enlightened,
Instantly clear.
Tigers roar, dragons chant,
Qi fresh, spirit clear.
Engaging in true cultivation,
Refining mercury, cooking lead.
Heart balanced, conduct complete,
Elixir formed, merit accomplished.
Then riding clouds and rainbow,
Morning court before the Jade Emperor,
Dwelling in Penglai.

**Zhang the Supervisor of Qiyang Town Asks About Cultivation**
Do not ask about causes,
Each must cultivate.
The ancients’ words—
Two phrases worth hearing:
Each person has a share,
Each is perfectly luminous.
Only when affairs are sparse,
Heart pure and still,
Is longevity attained.
Primordial qi abundant,
Great Dharma accomplished.
Establishing the initial contemplation,
Sun and moon still.
Radiance shining,
Dragon and tiger balanced.
Feeling the original true,
Ever tranquil,
Forever at peace.

**For Attendant Yan**
This Attendant Yan,
Originally an immortal.
Externally cultivating,
Mistaking the cause.
Hearing my exhortation,
Seeking the hidden, searching the mysterious.
Then abandoning splendor,
Leaving the dusty realm,
Visiting forests and springs.

**Cultivating with Pure Intent**

With pure intent and a clear heart,
Till and sow the Elixir Field.
Ever refining breath,
Soft and unbroken.
The lamp of life shines bright,
The moon of nature full and round.
When merit is complete,
Transcend and ascend,
Attain the heavens.

**For Elder Ziyang of Bai River and Abbot Feng**

Elder Feng of Bai River,
From Fufeng of Ninghai.
With Elder Ziyang’s immortal visit,
Three minds as one,
One will in triple harmony.
Subduing demons and fiends,
Seizing fierce tigers,
Capturing flood dragons.
Worldly cares all forgotten,
True qi harmonious and surging.
Naturally awakened,
Discerning the numinous trace.
Golden Elixir radiant,
Jade nature crystalline.
When merit is complete,
Ascend to the upper realms,
Dwell in Penglai’s palace.

**For Disciple Liu Juji**

I urge you, scholar,
Awaken early to this fleeting life.
Abandon glory,
Roam beyond the mundane.
Without thought, without worry,
Without love, without hate.
Let the idle heart wander,
Seeking cloud companions,
Visiting misty friends.
Ever abiding in truth,
Ever striving for purity.
Through cultivation,
Naturally luminous.
Lead becomes mercury’s medicine,
Mercury the essence of lead.
Refining the Great Elixir,
Ride the phoenix,
Journey to Penglai.

**For the Three Elders of Sanshui**

Suddenly awakened to impermanence,
Cease greed and stinginess.
Break free from the wheel,
No longer clinging to wife and child.
Escape the fiery household,
Cast off indulgence and desire.
Hair like tangled hemp,
Face like grime,
Speech like kindness.
All affairs forgotten,
Resolve to refine in the hermitage.
Eradicating the corpse-worms,
Spreading clouds and mist.
Delving into the subtle,
Aligning with the Dao and virtue.
Then expounding the profound,
Exploring the six and six,
Discoursing on the three and three.

**For Lingyangzi Li Dacheng**

Fully awakened to the Yang Primordial,
Grasp and guide the Yang.
To let Yang and Yang
Pierce earth and penetrate heaven.
Yang traverses the eight vessels,
Yang permeates the three fields.
Sensing the one Yang’s cycle,
The one Yang’s completion,
The one Yang’s wholeness.
Water nurtures the numinous smoke,
Fire nurtures the numinous spring.
Ever numinous,
True excellence transmitted.
Numinous cinnabar without leakage,
Numinous substance firm and steadfast.
Then coalescing numinous light,
Becoming a numinous treasure,
Achieving numinous immortality.

**For Zhang Dawu of Huating**

The greatly awakened,
Able to set the heart at ease.
Forsaking fame and profit,
Beyond the sea of love and mountain of favor.
Eating without seeking fullness,
Dwelling without seeking comfort.
No wild thoughts,
No carelessness,
No high aspirations.
Qi harmonious and flowing,
Sweet dew gentle and slow.
Using oxen and sheep,
Cartloads returned in kind.
Kan and Li conjoined,
Dragon and tiger entwined.
Attaining the utmost subtlety,
Water essence warm,
Fire essence cold.

**For Abbot Wang of the Western Hermitage in Huating County**

Vowing to shun rich flavors,
Delighting in begging for scraps.
With clarity,
Transforming foolishness.
Not dwelling in the abbot’s quarters,
Not residing in ornate halls.
Turning the bathhouse
Into a sleeping chamber,
Curled in repose.
Externally joyless,
Internally nurturing true countenance.
Sighing at the dusty world,
Alone embracing tranquility.
When merit is complete,
Departing the mortal realm,
Toward the Great Brahma Heaven,
The cloud-grotto,
Ranked among the immortals.

**Awakening to Yellow Grain (Originally "Swallow Returns to the Beam")**

The tune was originally "Swallow Returns to the Beam,"
Lacking depth,
Too ordinary.
Missing Master Pure Yang,
Thus renamed,
"Awakening to Yellow Grain."
A hundred years—a fleeting dream,
Upon awakening,
Abandon home.
Ever pure, ever striving,
Abiding in the true constant.
Accumulating merit and conduct,
Journeying to Penglai’s estate.

**Dwelling in a Thatched Hut in Zhongnan #3**

Dong Xuan’s unyielding neck was no common trait,
Like a swallow’s chin,
No misfortune.
A beard grown long in vain—no festering sore,
No broken skin,
What harm is there?
Daoists, poor yet resourceful,
No armpit bags,
Using leather sacks.
Propping the chin, hanging to endure heat and cold,
Within the wrapping,
A myriad fragrances.

**For Master Yang of Xingping**

The principle transmitted in secret is most profound,
Within water,
Gold naturally born.
This person, though mute, can chant,
Able to tread clouds,
Dragging cloud sleeves.
Pondering the ancient and modern path to immortality,
Now as in the past,
Past as now.
Through the ages, rare to meet a kindred spirit,
Those who know the tune,
Seem to match me.

**Warbling the Ugly Slave (Originally "Adding Words to the Ugly Slave")**

At the Purple Ultimate Palace,
Suddenly hearing the cries of the neighboring butcher,
Thus composing this verse.

Daoist followers in Laizhou perform the Yellow Register rite,
Each devout.
All single-minded,
Inviting me to silently recite the sutras,
Aiding the departed spirits.
Alas! The neighboring butcher,
Heedless of the future,
Slaughtering for a living,
The pigs’ pained wails unbearable to hear.
Most heartrending.

**For the Jiao Master Liu Daguan**

**For the Pengcheng Brothers, All in Official Splendor**

The Pengcheng brothers, all of official bearing,
A household of wealth and honor.
Fond of glory and splendor,
Yet slow to turn their hearts and awaken to falling blossoms.
Their path diverges.
If my kin would but seek the profound principle,
Another livelihood awaits.
Furnace-tempered cinnabar,
The great elixir refined, ascending in rainbow hues.
Sailing the immortal raft.

**For Liu Shujian and Ma Changji**

My kin, Shujian and Changji,
Both serving as inspectors.
Unversed in indulgence,
They rush to and fro, greedy for fame and profit.
How foolish they seem!
I urge them to gather their primordial yang early,
Why cling to wife and child?
Erect a cloud hermitage,
A single profound word, no vulgar chatter.
Departing the dust to seek the truth.

**For the Chief of the Laizhou Equality Assembly**

The world tells of the speckled bamboo and the fair one’s tears,
All mere empty talk.
Struck by the Three Corpses,
Blood-stained spots appear—most wondrous indeed.
Ma Feng knows.
Devote yourself to uprightness, wielding no partial staff,
Mock not the humble.
Best to wander idly,
Banishing all demons, the jade nature shines.
Bound for the Jasper Pool.

**Ode to the Bamboo Staff**

I wish you to adorn the carefree traveler,
Knee of crane, ever at his side.
Strolling through clouds and mist,
Laughing proudly in the pure wind by the moonlit stream.
Joy in serenity.
Even the reed of the sea has Lü’s second integrity,
The yang number clearly known.
Harmonious with the Dao,
A fine companion for cloud-roving, wind-footed steeds.
Do not refuse.

**Self-Lament**

**Reflection on the Self**

This body, worn and tattered as a thatched hut,
Dripping with rain, torn by the wind.
It draws fire and summons smoke,
Riddled with rat holes, snake burrows—its pillars askew.
Yet all can be made firm.
Should a master appear, it transforms into a cavern of silver mist,
Restored to a cloud-borne pavilion.
Pearl curtains hang,
And one delights in the radiance of an unending day.
Surely ascension awaits.

**Awakening**

I awoke to refine the treasure within,
No longer flaunting beard or brow.
Only the joy of stillness remains,
Dispensing benevolent winds without bias or favor.
May my resolve stand firm.
I urge others to see through the dream of floating life,
To forsake the allure of ornate carriages.
No need to gaze upon curtains—
Follow me soaring into the grotto-heaven,
To become an immortal.

**Self-Admonition**

Once, in my cups, I grew careless,
Vowing never again to raise the goblet.
Seeing through fleeting wealth,
I no longer contend in vain, nor bury myself in desire.
Thus I avoid calamity.
Again and again, I chance upon the path of cultivation,
Purifying the spirit’s terrace.
I guard the sacred embryo,
Waiting for the luminous pearl to become a child,
Bound for Penglai.

**Karma’s Weight**

In a past life, I sowed no blessings for this one,
Begging in the streets.
Frozen and starving, I wandered in distress,
My heart like a boiling cauldron, seared by suffering.
I prayed for mercy.
Clearly, a single coin given,
Secretly repays the worthy.
The greatest affinity—
Since ancient times, compassion alone makes immortals.
No empty words.

**Tea and Wine, the Affairs of Human Sentiment**

Tea comes, wine goes—mere worldly custom,
Not the root of the Dao.
Only to offer, only to reciprocate,
Wine departs, yet no tea returns in kind.
Thus enmity is born.

To pity the poor and set out congee, seeking no reward,
Is virtue built in secret.
Better still, true cultivation—
Surely one shall gaze upon the Ten Isles in days to come,
Treading the clouds in wander.

**Relieving Hunger, Together Serving Winter’s Congee**

With bowed head, I salute the noble lords,
Who join to set out congee for the starving through three winters.
May each household prosper,
And this small act of compassion—
A measure of rice to succor the poor—
Find goodly favor.

The heart of the Dao abides in constant good deeds,
As nature and destiny merge in harmony.
When the mind is truly open,
It binds the horse, seizes the monkey,
And leads forth tiger and dragon,
Bound for the Peng Palace.

**The World’s Love of Convenience**

Every mortal clings to what seems advantageous,
Vying for gain.
Scheming with cunning,
They win what seems profitable—yet it is loss.
Few understand.

I urge them: set aside this "convenience,"
Build virtue through giving.
Not out of folly,
But to secretly amass vast blessings,
Ascending to the Purple Tenuity,
To become an immortal and return.

**Floating Clouds and Wealth**

Floating clouds gather and scatter like wealth—
Ill-gotten gains,
Do not covet them,
For they bring calamity and invite disaster.
How unwise.

Better to cultivate a mind of equanimity,
Where none are harmed.

**Far Superior to Fasting**

Far superior to fasting,
It ensures one avoids the precipice in days to come.
Bound for Penglai.

**Winter Porridge**

Three winters’ porridge should endure,
Year after year the same.
With steadfast compassion,
One sows true fields of blessing in this life.
No loss for the wise.
Though but a measure of rice is given,
The blessings gained are boundless.
When merit’s work is complete,
One is certain to ascend as an immortal,
Rising to the azure heavens.

**Preparing Offerings**

Before the fast, prepare incense and fire,
Supply the hungry and poor with diligence.
Surely a noble soul lies hidden within—
Do not take them lightly.
I have now received the true message,
And share it with others—one must be reverent,
As solemn as when sacrificing to the gods,
Meeting the true with truth.

**Beggars in the Streets**

Those starving and freezing in the streets,
Receive with joy and pity.
Serve them as you would immortals,
Lest a sage be hidden among them.
Be wholehearted in this.
Better than performing ten grand jiao rites,
Or sowing other karmic seeds.
When virtuous deeds are complete,
One is certain to step upon the azure lotus,
And go to pay homage to the Origin.

**Winter Porridge for the Needy**

Three winters’ porridge should relieve distress,
For the hungry are pitiable.
A fine deed worth spreading—
When others hear of this good cause,
They too will follow.
Relieving poverty and lifting suffering brings merciful blessings,
Merit without end.
Superior to burning sandalwood and aloes,
It ensures one ascends to heaven in days to come,
To become a divine immortal.

**In the Kitchen, Heed Fu Feng’s Admonition**

When cooking porridge, do not make it thin.
Let it be thick and hearty,
Lest you deceive the bellies of others.
Awaken compassion.
Day after day, never weary in heart,
And begin at the proper hour.
Dispel the biting cold,
And never neglect this true merit.
Great fortune shall be yours.

**Compassionate Daoist Friends**

Compassionate Daoist friends take pity on the poor and destitute,
Setting out porridge for three winters.
All shall gain true merit,
And with devout sincerity, see it through to the end.
Year after year, the offering continues.
Kindness without waste—when others hear of it,
They too shall wish for household abundance.
Those who aid the poor
Shall surely not be left empty-handed in days to come,
But ascend to the immortal palaces.

**A Thousand Households, Ten Thousand Doors**

Let all people heed this exhortation,
And cultivate good causes.
Take pity on the hungry,
And together provide porridge for three winters to relieve the poor.
Blessings shall overflow.
A scoop or half a handful of compassionate rice
Holds merit no light matter.
Far greater than reciting scriptures,
A merciful heart reaches the Jade Capital,
And inscribes one’s name among the immortals.

**Wind Like Blades, Snow Like Arrows**

The three winters bring bitter suffering—
Have mercy on the poor children.
No clothes upon their backs,
No food within their mouths, ever gnawed by hunger.
How wretched their plight.
Now is the time for all to perform virtuous deeds,
And awaken compassion.
Rescue the drowning, uphold the faltering,
And provide porridge for a hundred days.
This shall build the ladder to immortality.
*[To Master Sun]*
Setting out porridge in winter brings manifold benefits.
I urge Master Sun, as deputy director, to take care
That it never be discontinued.
With deep gratitude.
I humbly present two short lyrics:

Porridge set out in winter graces temple and abbey,
A virtuous deed that shines.
Cast aside all worry,
And realize that acts of compassion run deepest.
All shall hold you in esteem.
Never grow weary or impatient,
For this surpasses burning sandalwood and aloes.
Seek the wondrous in quiet moments,
Where water and fire give birth to gold within jade,
And ascend to the jasper peaks.

Where does Deputy Director Sun reside?
At the Purple Ultimate Palace.
Receiving guests with humility,
He treats high and low alike, moving his own person—
Like a drawn bow.

I urge the worthy to recognize early the true cultivation,
To revolve the numinous palace.
Cease all excessive reverence,
For the brocade arrow, fine as silk, strikes the precious body—
No bow is needed.

*Departing the Sea of Suffering*
*(Following the rhyme of Master Chongyang)*

By karmic encounter, one departs the sea of suffering,
Cultivating truth in stillness and solitude.
Within the true wind,
Seize the true gale.
Plant jade and jasper,
And true auspices fill the azure sky.
Draw forth the true jade hare,
The true golden rooster—
Naturally, they dissolve all.
Gather further the true dragon and true tiger, coiling around,
For the true image will not spare even the partial.
Truly indistinct, truly manifest,
One sees the true infant and true maiden beckoning.
Seek the true Departure, the true Block, the true place,
To truly, truly aid one another and ingest the numinous sprout.
Suddenly, the primordial true visage coalesces,
Through true purity,
With harmonious effort and power.
Depart for Peng Isle,
To pay homage to Master Chongyang,
And abide in eternal freedom.
