**Scroll Eight of the** *Treasury of Golden Jade from the Grotto Mysteries*
*Cultivating the Dao (Originally titled* **Idle Amidst a Hundred Flowers**)
*Offending the Proper Office*

**Cultivating the Dao (Idle Amidst a Hundred Flowers)**
*Offending the Proper Office*

Strive to cultivate the Dao amidst the common stream,
Strive to break the stubborn and unyielding.
Strive to subdue the heart, forgetting wine and sensual pleasures,
Wealth, qi, self, and others.
Strive not to return home,
Ever striving to awaken to pure poverty,
Passing days in carefree indolence.
Strive to achieve the fruition of success,
Strive to be without the slightest dust,
Refining the true fire of eternal life.
Strive to refine the seven reversals and nine returns,
A radiant elixir pearl.
Strive to rise in compassion,
Ever striving to be free from contention,
Striving early to ride the clouds.

*Grinding the Elixir*
*For Yunzhongzi, Su Xuan*

Yunzhongzi, you are Master Su,
Hear me—do not let your topknot loosen.
Wear the Huayang cap, the Nine Peaks kerchief.
Follow the path of transformation, acting for the mountain folk,
Cloud-roaming the northwest to visit Kongtong.
Expound good affinities, establish the teachings’ wind.
Exhort all fellow Daoists to seek the Dao.

Ma Fengzi, who has not grasped the mysterious,
Whose nature is dull and knowledge dim, not at ease—
Relying on me in vain, wasting your worth.
Hear my counsel, do not delay,
Swiftly leave me to engage in Chan.
Then you will have the Dao, and be upright.

*Departing the Dust*

Depart the dusty net, escape the mundane cage,
Hair disheveled, face grimed, appearing foolish and ignorant.
Eyes like the blind, ears like the deaf.
Gold for arrows, jade for the bow,
The wooden man shoots through the crystal palace.
Proceed to Peng and Ying, the jade path opens.

*For Wuweizi of Zhongtiao Mountain*

Will as the sword, wisdom as the blade,
The stone maiden splits jade to reveal the golden turtle.
Playing upon the blue lotus, leaping the azure waves.
Drinking the elixir pellet, surpassing fragrant wine—
The young master in scarlet robes,
Striking the cloud waist, ten thousand times over.

*For Wang Daizhao of Huazhou, Seeking Lyrics*

Wang Daizhao, skilled in capturing spirits,
Whose daily thoughts and intentions dwell in others.
Forgetting even your own self,
As if awakening, emerging from the sea of delusion,
Passing days in carefree ease—la-li...
Rejoicing in tranquility, attaining true awakening.

*For the Pure and Secluded Adept*

Do not cling stubbornly, do not be foolishly obstinate,
Do not be deluded by false appearances, do not be stingy or greedy.
Do not give rise to sorrow, do not harbor shame.
Hear my counsel, seek the capital,
Passing days in carefree ease, attaining true joy.
Guard purity, congeal the great elixir.

*For Lan Jue of Jingzhao, Xie Jingren*

Do not cling, do not covet,
Do not let idle sorrows arise in your heart.
In dwelling and moving, ever free.
If you can do this, engage in true cultivation,
Seizing the ape, catching the horse, refining the frost orb.
When the practice is complete, proceed to the Ten Isles.

*For Academician Li*

Zhang Duzhi, most harried,
All because of his toiling hands, too entangled.
Entangled, with no recourse.
Hear my counsel, leave your nest,
In leisure, leisure, leisure, refine harmony.
Attain true cultivation, ascend the Great Canopy.

*For Three Daoist Friends of Zhongnan*

Zhang Qiantian, Mu Ziqian,
Li Gongshi and others, attached to family ties—
How may they grasp the wondrous mystery?
Depart the sea of the vulgar, by the waters and clouds,
At the Immortal’s Manor, plant golden lotuses.
When the practice is complete, the moon of nature is full.

*For Jia the Immortal of Sanshui*

Flaming fire, rolling boiling water,
Within, a single point of martial coolness.
Even more exquisite, exceptionally fragrant.
Generating auspiciousness, emitting auspicious light,
Auspicious light and radiance congeal into red frost.
Producing the fetal immortal, manifesting the Jade Sovereign.

*For the Three Bi Masters of Li Springs*

Externally, do not cling; externally, do not seek,
Externally, there are no good causes.
Externally, no truth; external matters, cease.
Internally, it may be mended; internally, it may be cultivated,
Internally, in purity, roaming the waters and clouds.
Internally, luminous; internally, the countenance is complete.

*In Reply to Magistrate Xiao of Longzhou*

Magistrate Xiao of Longzhou asks whether the child to come will be son or daughter,
Whether there will be calamities or misfortunes, and seeks lyrics.

A good nature, a good disposition,
No need for incense or fasting.
Wearing clouds as a wrap, calamities are averted.
Internally cultivate an extraordinary embryo,
Forgetting scheming, cutting off thoughts, shielding from dust.
Producing a numinous child, possessing great talent.

*Linked Pearls*

Conceal your light well, mend your bones,
Bones without flaws, the numinous embryo is firm.
The embryo pure, the child pure.
The child at play, playing cleverly,
Unruly yet fearing sensuality and wealth.
Without wealth and sensuality, buried in the earth.

*For Magistrate Wanyan of Huating*

The magistrate’s daughter, a true maiden,
Approaching sixteen, delighting in natural truth.
Daring to seek, freely seeking truth.
Heaven-endowed nature, yearning for cultivation,
In time, when merit is complete, the inner true self is perfected.
Riding auspicious clouds, paying homage to the highest immortals.

*For Vice Prefect Li of Mizhou, Seeking a Staff*

A staff of divine longevity, to whom shall it be sent?
To Vice Prefect Li of Longxi, to brush aside the red dust.
Clearing the path, departing the bitter ford.
Ever carrying it, forever as a kin,
Seizing the ape, catching the horse, harmonizing qi and spirit,
Lifting the round image to reveal the original true self.

*Again*

A staff of divine longevity, presented to the lady,
To brush aside the world’s net, to clear the dust.
Assisting her steps, emerging from the ford of love.
Striking where needed, leaning as a kin,
Knocking away darkness, forever clarifying the spirit.
Lifting the bright moon, manifesting the utmost truth.

*For the Daoist Assembly of the Five Meetings*

Hearts in equanimity, longevity extended,
Cultivating the seven treasures, gathering the three luminaries.
Awakening to the complete truth, all things forgotten.
Jade flowers bloom, golden lotuses fragrant,
Fragrant flavors filling the fasting bowels.
When the practice is complete, the Jade Sovereign appears.

*For Yu Qingyi of Ninghai Prefecture*

The wondrous within the mysterious, beyond words,
I exhort you: do not let the horse and ape run wild.
Burn heart incense, reach the sages.
The sages rejoice, bestowing good affinities,
In secret, meticulously clearing the root source.
The nature numinous, attaining immortality.

*For Ma Yangao of Wendeng*

The wine of longevity, the cup of peace,
Able to cure a hundred ailments, just in time.
Assisting pure chanting, delighting in the Dao’s return.
Presenting the wine, the phoenix... cup,
At the Fragrant Mountain gathering, cherishing the fragrant hour.
The drunken immortal’s chant, returning beneath the moon.

*For Master Zhang Wuchen*

Seizing the cloud horse, releasing the cloud carriage,
Singing and dancing in unrestrained indulgence.
Letting others laugh at my folly.
Understanding the six sixes, awakening to the three threes,
The three threes and six sixes, tasting fragrant sweetness.

Gathering broadly, not a matter of greed.
*To the Tune of "Immortal by the River" – Harmonizing with Zhao the Palace Examiner*

□ Seeking the bedrock of metal and wood, □ ever youthful in purity.
□ Ah, within and without, attaining carefree ease.
□ The true water’s thread, □ once drawn, returns again.
□ The adept seeks the worthy, yet the worthy remain unseen;
□ My humble hut is honored by your instruction.
□ Cultivation rests within the Three Passes.
□ The person and the true bond align, □ awakening to a heart at leisure.

Dismantling the character *mu* to begin.
*Harmonizing with the Rhyme of the Nameless Master #2*

□ Jade comes and goes, spirit and qi abide;
□ The old man rides steadily upon the azure steed.
□ The wind, the Tan clan, and Liu Qiu.
□ The heart returns to true awakening, □ this very original land of Huanzhou.
□ Fire engenders, lead and mercury conjoin;
□ The person has already attained clarity and seclusion.
□ Soon, they shall ascend to the clouds.
□ Firmly grasp the wind’s reins, □ below, well swallow the hook.

Dismantling the character *jin* to begin.
*The Mirror of Pure Heart* (originally titled *The Distant Red Window*)

In my early days, as abbot,
Diligently I received cloud companions and rosy friends.
From time to time, severing worldly ties,
Gradually, I came to awakening.
When the awakened heart opened, I then encountered
My original master, who sent me
Specifically to transform and deliver.
Expounding the wondrous mystery, dispelling foolish confusion,
I sought to guide them to the Penglai Palace.

Again:
The good sprout grows, as abbot,
All day long, trusting in extraordinary companions.
Naturally attaining fine affinities,
The heart’s awakening unfolds.
Once the heart’s head opens, decisive encounter follows.
Truly, through cultivation, relying further on the master’s deliverance,
Responding to the immortal’s summons, with merit and conduct unblemished,
They ride the clouds to the Purple Palace.

*Attaining Encounter #3*
Encountering the Wind Immortal, discussing what is ever-convenient.

Forsaking wife and children, no longer meet again.
Beyond the mundane, vast and carefree,
Leaving behind the perceptions of sentient beings.
A great person, with courageous resolve—
How could one yield to wine and sensuality,
To qi and wealth, frittering time away?
Wielding the sword of wisdom, severing all attachments,
The immortal embryo appears through cultivation.

Abandoning the home,
Breaking the reins of fame,
Striking the shackles of profit.
Love’s ocean, gratitude’s mountain—
All seen through at once.
Leaving the household’s ties,
The path stretches three thousand leagues,
Like a lone cloud or wild crane.

With a heart of ambition,
Too great by half.
Today, before all,
I must speak plainly:
In desolation, endure humiliation and poverty,
No longer permitting duality.

Delighting in the true wind—
The wind of the Horse, how fine!
Shaking off household entanglements,
Free from vexation and sorrow.
From now on, no more recklessness,
But wholeheartedly devoting to the Dao.

Purifying the spirit furnace,
Cleansing the cinnabar crucible.
Refining mercury, smelting lead,
Warding off yin depletion.
When the first yang arises,
The great elixir shimmers—
One has a share in dwelling on Penglai Isle.

Lamenting past errors,
First leaving home,
Seeking Dao companions.

Like a fierce tiger,
Descending the mountain to roam.
Never having tempered the stubborn heart,
Lightly touched, it roars in fury.
Flaunting many skills,
Boasting fine hands.
Transcribing famous formulas,
Devoted to saving others.
Though *Pingwei San* may be absent,
There is no lack of potent qi medicines.

Rejoicing in this present truth—
The Dharma candle, let it burn as it will.
No self, no other,
Smoke disperses, fire extinguishes.
Devoted to cultivating
The immortal of forbearance,
Willing to forsake distinctions of right and wrong.
No anger, no joy,
Full to the brim with ice and snow.
Naturally, the heart-ground becomes cool,
How could I then grow heated?

**Searching for One’s Faults**
Searching for one’s faults,
Searching for one’s faults.
Since entering the Dao,
There has been no great transgression—
Only that I should not have
Revealed the mystery of the subtle mechanism,
For this is a grievous fault.
Knowing my fault,
Knowing my fault,
To avoid past errors,
I must atone with merit.
Abiding in non-action,
The heart arises in true compassion,
Hoping the sages will forgive my transgression.

**The Ancestral Hut’s Enclosure**
One lotus pond,
Two cloud companions.
Three pines, four cypresses,
Five weeping willows.
Erecting a surrounding wall,
Encircling the distant Cloud Hut,
Shielding the inner retreat from bustle.

The Green Dragon soars,
The White Tiger roars.
Jade maiden and golden infant,
Naturally pure and elegant.
Transcending creation,
The divine pearl is formed,
Awaiting the sages to bring it to fruition.

**Ode to Chang’an**
Speaking of Chang’an,
So many fine things.
Truly, each day,
Three immortals visit the market.
Half the city’s folk
Engage in trade,
The other half cultivate true qi.

Long-lived people,
Most numerous here.
Knowing cause and effect,
They early quiet the heart-ground.
How flourish the good affinities—
Each year, what is the custom?
A thousand Dao gatherings arise.

**Sent to Three Elder Daoist Brothers: Tan, Liu, and Qiu, in Deer Hide**
Elder Brother Changzhen,
Younger Brothers Liu and Qiu.
Long life, long spring,
Dharma kin of the same generation.
Wearing the lazy robe,
Clad in deer hide,
As our original master taught.

Younger brother’s cloud-wrapped topknot,
Elder brother’s forked hair.
Early awakened to the Three Awakenings,
One penetrating bright meaning.
My heart’s wish
Is to universally transform the deluded,
Deliver the inner contents to transcendence.

**To Master Iron Li**
Lord of Longxi,
Painfully parted.
At the sixth-month furnace,
Wielding the hammer to forge iron.
Supporting the whole family
In leisure,
While you alone endure scorching heat.

Fire-burned sores,
Sweat dripping blood.
Ten thousand hardships, a thousand toils—
When will it ever end?
The wind of the Horse,
Entices you to turn your head,
To rest within the gate of the Dao.

**Also**
Awakening to karmic ties,
Fiercely parting.
A man’s resolve,
Cutting through iron like nails.
Roaming water and clouds,
Vowing never to look back,
Fleeing the fiery courtyard’s torment.

Attaining coolness,
No more sweat or blood.
The pure jade flask,
Naturally luminous and clear.
Realizing the primal origin—
A single radiant point,
The heart rests, free from dusty entanglements.

**To Elder Master Cheng**
This Master Cheng,
Suddenly awakened.

A household with six sons—
The number of the six thieves.
Look closely:
All are karmic foes,
Better not to gather together.
Cast off the gauze cap,
Don the proper crown.
Seize the horse and ape,
Tame the dragon and tiger.
Await the day
When the elixir gleams bright—
Mount the auspicious simurgh and depart.

**To Zhou, Seventh Official of Jingzhao**
Zhou, the official—
A household of great wealth.
In Chang’an’s census,
The highest-ranked household.
Yet in ten years,
What has risen or fallen?
Not even a pin’s space remains.
Sighing at fame and profit,
So impermanent.
They turn my heart to ash,
Then stir awakening.
Walk the Great Way,
Unwavering in resolve—
Cultivate the unborn, the unceasing.

**To Brother Qiu of Changchun**
You delight in mountains,
I delight in water.
Delighting in water, delighting in mountains—
What use is it all?
Far better to
Purify the mind, still the heart,
Refine the harmonious true qi.
Kan and Li unite,
Wood and Metal play—
Giving birth to the shadowless infant,
Within the Palace of Five Lights.
Then suddenly,
The elixir coalesces, luminous—
Attaining boundless true joy.

Once, playing in the water,
I swiftly saw my error.
Thus I compose this verse
To show those below the hall—
Lest any cling stubbornly.

**To Little Immortal Li**
Li, the fitting monk,
A monk who studies the Dao.
The Dao demands profound subtlety,
Sought daily in inquiry.
Through discussion,
One attains constant purity, constant clarity—
A clear mind and intent are best.
Master the heart well,
Sweep away its dust.
When swept clean,
The secret mystery becomes luminous.
The mystery lies in
Running jade, flying gold—
Gold and jade congeal into the elixir’s treasure.

**To Little Immortal Yang of Hu County**
The cultivator
Must first restrain the eyes.
Seeing other men’s wives,
Do not glance or gaze.
Firmly seize
The mind-horse and heart-ape,
Do not slacken, do not dally.
Remove the self,
Simplify affairs.
Embrace pure poverty, gentle weakness,
Carefree and unconstrained.
Strictly follow
The laws of the land, the decrees of heaven—
Never transgress, never transgress.

**To Abbot Li of West Hermitage**
Abbot Li,
Hear my counsel:
Cease grieving for others,
First rescue yourself.
Trim the lamp of the heart,
Make its light true and bright,
To illumine the central palace.
When the Great Elixir is complete,
The work perfected,
The wakeful, radiant youth
Will naturally appear.
Await the purple script,
The jade summons—
To visit the Jasper Terrace, the Penglai Gardens.

**To Master Yan**
A true man,
A man of resolute virtue.

Steel your resolve, unyielding as iron,
Single-minded, without duality.
In cultivation’s path,
Vow never to return home—
When peril and hardship arise, strengthen your will.
In purity and stillness,
The profound mystery reaches its peak.
Sun and moon exchange their radiance,
Tiger and dragon converge in their hour.
Drink the elixir’s measure,
Nurture the divine cinnabar,
To fulfill the esoteric intent of Double Yang.

**To Mistress Hou Mingyi**
Mistress Hou,
Your heart awakens to enlightenment.
At sixty-nine,
Only now do you begin your repairs.
Though many say,
“The hour is late,”
The horse of the Dao is not yet dusk.
Qi unbroken,
Spirit may yet be secured.
First seize
The mind-horse and heart-ape,
Exert your effort to capture them.
Then naturally,
Life and nature will stabilize,
And you shall ascend as an immortal, returning home.

**Quanzhen Hermitage of Jingzhao**
Immortal Pi Zhang,
Master of construction.
One body, two duties—
Also serving as alms-collector.
Building the hermitage,
A single chamber raised alone,
He entreats the patrons of Chang’an.
On cultivation,
Distinguish guest and host.
Grasp the qi and spirit,
Let them master the body.
Swiftly resolve
The root of life and nature,
To become the master of Penglai’s grotto.

**To Master Li of Chang’an**
Master Li,
Too stubborn, too obstinate.

Beneath the Hall of Complete Perfection,
The hardest to instruct and guide.
In learning cultivation,
They scorn the plow, yet claim,
“The Dao is our sole delight.”
Again and again I urge,
Again and again I warn:
Recognize the five-colored auspicious clouds,
And naturally till the Dao.
Cultivate purple mushrooms,
Radiant with numinous light,
And you shall return to Peng Isle.

**To Xue Daoqing**
In cultivation,
Search and refine with care.
The pure family tradition
Is the wondrous Dharma of the Great Vehicle.
Practice non-action,
The true work of non-doing,
Polishing the mirror of the heart.
Naturally bright,
Naturally enlightened,
You shall save and deliver
The nine generations and seven ancestors.
Toward Peng and Ying,
Vast and carefree,
Your crown and robes shall resemble those of a bodhisattva.

**To Master Liu**
A black ox,
Leading a white calf,
Deep in Caoxi’s valleys,
They follow one another.
Often lying beneath the moon,
Sleeping amid clouds,
Detached from the grasses and trees of the mortal world.
Feasting on the three yang,
Joining the nine beasts,
Mother and child in gentle harmony,
Spared the labor of herding.
Await the day
You ascend to Peng and Ying,
Revealing your original face.

**To Madam Wei the Wind**
Madam Wind,
Bearer of secret mysteries,
Mind pure and heart clear,
Every word is the Dao.
Naturally attaining
True joy, true delight,
Without a trace of vexation.
No flattery,
No arrogance,
Amid jade blossoms,
Gold treasures take form.
Then await
The purple edict’s summons,
To bear the title of Illuminated Immortal.

**To Sun Keda**
Master Sun,
Able to let go,
Steadfast and free,
Penetrating truth, discarding falsehood.
In heart and mind,
Impartial toward all things,
Without a hint of flattery.
Delighting in purity,
Attaining refinement,
Drawing near the numinous youths,
Clear-eyed and unburdened.
Now is the time
To forge good karmic ties,
Roaming as clouds and water, transforming all.

**On Hearing of the Passing of the Wu Brothers, Scholars of the First Rank**
Alas, this floating life,
Heart turned to ashes.
The Wu brothers, scholars of the first rank,
Youthful and pure in their prime.
Who could have known
That in half a month’s time,
They would together meet their end?
Let others awaken,
Let others reflect:
Cast aside worldly ties,
Preserve life and nature in full.
Truly pure,
They speak of escaping rebirth,
Attaining eternal life with certainty.

**Guo the Laywoman of Xingping Joins the Hall of Complete Perfection to Cultivate the Dao**
Laywoman Guo,
With the resolve of a man,
Shears worldly passions,
Fearing life and death.
Far from her husband,
She sews shut the yin gate,
Unmatched in ancient or modern times.
Vigilant to the end,
As at the beginning,
Sages and worthies
Shall secretly uplift you.

Amid non-action, in purity from head to toe,
Dwelling with Ma Gu.

**Master Lu of Pucheng**
Alas, this man,
Broken and worn.
Heedless of peril and ruin,
He toys with the gates of the Dao.
Still, by his own doing,
Unmindful of past transgressions,
How shall he escape great calamity?
Hear my words, cast off entanglements:
Worldly love and dusty passions,
Sever them with a single blade.
Dissolve past karma,
Resume cultivation,
And the winds of Ma Feng shall watch over you.

**Another**
Hair like tangled hemp,
Face like filth.
All affairs forgotten,
The heart free of dust and grime.
Indolent and unrestrained,
Lost in sloth and indulgence,
Begging for scraps with outstretched hands.
Fortunate to know nothing,
Why cling to something?
Embrace the void beyond void,
The elixir of no-leakage.
Seek Penglai,
When merit fills three thousand,
You shall don cloud-sleeved robes.

**Bodhisattva Bo Awaits Inquiry**
Bodhisattva Bo,
Skilled in sculpting,
Boasts of wondrous hands and marvelous craft,
Never ceasing.
Expending spirit,
Muddying water and dragging through mire,
All for the sake of feeding his family.
Yet does the heart awaken?
Does the nature comprehend?
In idle offerings,
To the true Father and Mother.
In purity and clarity,
The elixir is forged,
To ride the green phoenix and depart.

**Yang Awaits Inquiry**
Yang the Craftsman,
Sculpts with skill,
Playing with mud and water,
Never nurturing the vast.
Cease the clamor,
Cease begging for poems,
Turn your heart toward the Dao.
Delve deeply, probe thoroughly,
In purity and clarity,
The mysteries shall reveal themselves.
Qi, spirit, essence—
The elixir of no-leakage complete,
Ride the clouds to Penglai’s isles.

**Elder Bo of Shaohua Seeks [a Response]**
Elder Bo, Elder Bo.

At eighty-four years,
Why awaken the heart to cultivate and nurture?
Reading Chongyang’s *Complete Works of the True*,
Some savor is found.
Speak not of age,
Nor of lifespan’s appearance.
Externally hoary,
Internally unconstrained.
Qi unbroken—
Cultivation remains possible,
Swiftly settling the mind is paramount.

**To Ma Shouqing**
Ma, the Maiden,
Returns once more.
In daily use, non-action,
Leisurely nurturing simplicity.
Cease discourse
On the maiden, the infant, the youthful,
Or where tiger and dragon contend.
Sever worldly ties,
Attain true delight.
Fire extinguished, smoke dispersed,
Qi and spirit firm.
Within, cloud-wandering—
Merit fills the Three Fields,
Ascend Penglai’s immortal path.

**Internal Cultivation: To Master Xu of the Garden**
Alone and steadfast,
Tending the garden.
Treading furrows, pacing ridges,
Yet not walking in vain.
Grasping the jade crucible,
Reversing the flow of numinous waves—
When were hands ever raised?
Watering frequently,
Sprouts and shoots emerge.
Gradually fragrant,
The garden brims with splendor.
From the Palace of Jeweled Petals,
Radiant clouds burst forth,
Emulating the divine elder’s return.

**Gathering the Medicine: To Elder Tian of Longzhou**
To learn cultivation
Is like gathering herbs.
Carrying a basket of purity,
Unstained by defilement.
Wandering deep
Amid white clouds—
When was a hoe ever used?
Summoning the green phoenix,
Beckoning the white crane.
Treading upon the sacred land,
Naturally resplendent.
Beholding the ninefold transmutation,
A single elixir pill complete—
Then gather it into the azure vault.

**Internal Plowing: To Master Mu Zhang**
Dwelling in solitary clarity,
Internally plowing and sowing.
Heart and intent at ease,
Unshaken, unmoved.
In profound obscurity,
A golden ox appears,
Plowing deep in the valley’s fields.
Clear rain descends,
Purple mushrooms rise.
Red phoenix and dark turtle
Come forth to behold the offering.
Hemp and wheat bear
Divine pearls of millet,
Ascending the azure heavens in tribute.

**To Abbot Wang**
When nurturing the family,
What was the state of affairs?

Harried by wife and sons,
As if afflicted in heart.
Chasing profit and fame,
Toiling back and forth—
Too weary, too weary.
Since turning to the Dao,
Ever open and at ease.
Beyond the twin words "nature and life,"
No other deluded thoughts arise.
Seizing tranquility,
Freely roaming and carefree—
How unbounded, how unbounded.

**[Illness Among the Daoist Assembly]**
While dwelling on Mount Zhongnan,
I lived within bare walls,
Legs bared, feet unshod,
Without fire or lamp,
For six years in all.
Suddenly stirred in heart,
I wandered the clouds at will,
Westward to Huating,
Seeking shelter in Shenkan.
By chance, I contracted the Central Plains’ *jin-huo* toxin,
Coughing blood and gasping—
The illness struck with great urgency.
Fellow Daoists offered medicine;
I bowed and received it,
Yet dared not taste.
They urged me:
"Eat raw scallions with strong vinegar
To dispel the poison."
I pondered again and again:
When a Daoist falls ill,
None can heal but oneself.
One must refine the supreme treasure within the body,
And the malady will naturally fade.
Thus I composed a short lyric, *The Mirror of Clarity*,
And respectfully presented it to the assembly,
Hoping for your kind regard.

*Ma feng-feng*, five score and six.
Drifting like cloud and water,
Alone and serene.
Riding the celestial wind,
Swaying the luminous radiance,
Ever brightening the candle of inherent nature.
Arriving at Tingchuan,
I lodged in a cellar.
Unawares, I encountered
The Central Plains’ *jin-huo* toxin.
To dissolve the disharmony of the four impermanent forms,
Refine the gold and jade within the body.

**Treating Illness**
When qi does not flow,
The feet and knees suffer.

Mica ointment should be applied and kept ready at all times. For tetanus from wounds, what remedy is there? Grind *huaruishi* finely and sprinkle it.

**Treating Heart Maladies**
*Qingshen* powder. For obstinate dispositions, *fuzi*; for harmonizing the center, *lizhong* pills. If *Lingbao* elixirs are taken in excess, even the bones and marrow may transform.

**To Ju Deyi of Hezhou**
Ju of Hezhou, listen to my words. Cast aside all these techniques and methods. The great Dao of spontaneity and non-action—how could it lie in meticulous manipulation? The *Mirror of Clarity* ever gleams pure, illuminating the myriad conditions, beyond birth and extinction. This original luminous essence shines as bright as the autumn moon.

**To Master Ma**
How free and unburdened, how open and expansive! In sitting, lying, dwelling, and walking, carefree and at ease. Reflect deeply: those entangled in fame and profit—how could they know this flavor? In leisure, cultivate and nurture. Temper that single luminous pearl of spirit until it gleams resplendent. Count thrice the seas’ transformation to mulberry fields—this is but a moment for the immortals.

**To the Ten Palace Examiners of Huating**
Yin Yuqing, Fan Zuxun, Ming Zhongji Meng, Zi Xun, Zi Run, Han Qing, and Xin Zhong the official—all of the Qinghe clan. Cheng Derong, Li Hanchen: ten of our fellowship, all refined and talented. I urge you, gentlemen, to let fame and profit turn to ash and attend early to the perfection of nature and life.

**To Lingyangzi Li Dacheng**
Lingyangzi, you come to bid farewell. Parting is not like the time of welcome. Hear my counsel: travel with purpose, and tend closely to your widowed mother. For us, when the smoke and fire of worldly desires are extinguished, never forget your original resolve—steadily deepen your determination. Walk the great Dao, unfold the primal truth, and summon the clear wind and bright moon.

**To Young Master Liu**
One green ox, two tails. Three eyes surveying above and below. Four hooves white as silver, frolicking through the five directions. The six desires and seven emotions all abandoned. Drinking the eight-flavored nectar, radiance suffuses the body. Within the nine tripods, it transmutes into divine elixir—tenfold perfection complete.

**To Jiranzi**
Practitioners of the Dao, listen closely.

Fasting fare must not be made exquisite beyond measure. What need is there for exotic delicacies of many kinds? A single flavor suffices. In tranquil partaking, contentment is ever found. The ten thousand spirits harmonize in bliss, the alchemical pair rejoices in union. Naturally, the golden elixir coalesces—claiming one’s place among the immortals of Penglai and Yingzhou.

**Daoist Companions Ask About Cultivation**
Cloud companions inquire, rosy friends respond. The matter of nature and life is grave—one must surely deliver oneself. The turning wheel of rebirth is decided in this very life; search diligently, scrub thoroughly. When the blue lotus blooms and the white lotus unfolds, within the lotus canopy the alchemical pair gazes above and below. Proceeding upon the road to Penglai, they dance the *liuma* of eighteen movements.

**To Abbot Yan of Huating’s Yinyuan Cloister**
Liu Ziwen, of penetrating nature, saw three generations of his family—father and sons—all take the tonsure. No longer entangled in outward practices, they recognized the wondrous Dharma of non-doing. Within, all was pure and clear, a numinous treasure pagoda. Jade elephants and golden lions encircled it sevenfold. Suddenly, a resounding *ding-dang* arose, revealing the bodhisattva of wondrous sound.

**Daoist Companions Ask of What Household I Am**
Daoist companions inquire, “Of what household are you?”
I answer: “Pure and still, with no contrivance.”
They laugh and say, “This is mere obstinate emptiness—where do you grasp it?”
To grasp it, I tell you this: the mind-steed and heart-ape must be firmly captured. Naturally, the earth wells forth with sweet springs, and heaven descends with sweet dew.

Again—
Sweet springs well forth, sweet dew descends. Ascending and descending without cease, they naturally moisten the three fields, where purple灵芝 unfurl in abundance. Benevolent sprouts arise, wisdom shoots emerge. Blazing and radiant, they illuminate the jade path. Then they transform into a single divine pearl, pointing the way to Penglai and Yingzhou.

**Exhortation to Disciples**
Avoid vain pretenses, avoid vain pretenses. Do not lean upon non-leaning, nor trifle with the Dao. Preserving nature and life is no ordinary matter—strike decisively and settle it completely. O child of the homeless life, display your skill. Take all former attachments and suddenly, fiercely sever them. With single-minded resolve and unyielding determination, cultivate steadfastly to join the company of immortals.

**To Pei Daqi**
Practitioners of the Dao must keep the heart kind. Yet karmic obstructions and demonic illusions assail them relentlessly. In the twelve hours, the unruly steed and frenzied ape give rise to unceasing evil thoughts. Steel your resolve, temper it constantly. Exterminate them without trace, and war shall never arise again.

**Harmonizing Qi and Spirit, the Elixir of Purity Forms—**
The Embryonic Immortal emerges in manifestation.

**To Li Fei, the Great Recluse**
Practitioner of the Dao, avoid missteps.
Ponder carefully: external joy cannot compare to inner joy.
In constant purity, pure delight arises of itself—
this is the original, true exultation.
No sorrow, no attachment,
free and unbound, qi and spirit blaze radiantly.
When merit is perfected and the Embryonic Immortal revealed,
you shall dance your way back to the Azure Heavens.

**The Melon and Plum Parable**
Beware the floating water-caltrop, fear the sinking plum.
See through the floating caltrop,
and the principle becomes self-evident.
From this moment on, cease flaunting literary arts,
and no longer need you expound on rites.
Wander like clouds upon water, far from your homeland.
Do not cultivate outward appearances—
cultivate only the inner.
Stabilize your breath, attain eternal harmony,
and drink the immortal elixir of longevity.

**Again**
The bitter melon’s stem, the fragrant sweet plum:
abandon bitterness for sweetness,
and the supreme principle becomes clear.
Extinguish ignorance, blend with the world while shining,
and for now, perform worldly rites at leisure.
Seek the ancient capital, traverse the locust groves.
Let the heart dwell beyond things,
let qi gather to replenish the inner.
In the void, nurture the infant spirit,
and drink the celestial elixir of spontaneity.

**Again**
This scholar, surnamed Li in the world,
awakened to the pure stillness of non-action—
the profound principle of spontaneity.
Summoned by the Jade Emperor,
he vied for first place among immortals,
surpassing Kong Li’s inquiry into rites.
Hear my words, return to your homeland.
Dwell once more within the encircling walls,
and diligently cultivate the inner.
When the jade peaches ripen,
the nectar shall flow of itself—
mocking Shen Sheng’s draught of sacrificial wine.

**Again**
Mustard greens are heavy, plums are precious.
Awakened to the suffering of birth and death,
weary of delving into texts and principles.
Diminish flavors, distance yourself from sights and sounds,
and grow tired of studying the *Zhou Rites*.
Gather the Three Lights, release them into the Three Li.
Recognize the discourse of the Three Topknots—
in purity, both inner and outer.
Qi and spirit, the Three Treasures—
when the elixir is formed,
the Three Pure Ones shall bestow their nectar.

**Resolute Determination**
O child of the homeless life, be decisive.
Bite through ignorance with a single snap,
as the fire-drill of delusion bores in.
In all matters of the Dao, temper your resolve with unyielding steel—
then you may be called a man of iron.
Let your will not waver, your heart not stray.
Discern the ancient and modern,
the immortal’s public records.
Through accumulated merit and practice,
fear no hardship—
await the direct crossing to the other shore.

**Thus I Show Fellow Cultivators the Resolute Path to Immortal Fruition**
O child of the homeless life, be decisive.
Sever all ten thousand dusty entanglements at once.
Forget cunning, cut off thoughts, and cultivate immortality—
settle the matter of nature and life completely.
Outwardly foolish, inwardly radiant,
in voice and laughter, bearing the guise of a simpleton.

Rejoice in poverty, sing and dance before the streets,
delight in spreading mats and holding bowls.
O cultivator, take heed—do not err.
Ponder carefully: outer joy cannot compare to inner joy.
In stillness and clarity, true joy and true bliss arise,
as smiles bloom like flowers.
Free from sorrow, free from attachment,
qi and spirit harmonize in ascent, the heart holds no resentment.
Give rise to great goodness, deliver the deluded and lost,
together ascend to the azure heavens.

When encountering foes, seek reconciliation.
Wine, lust, temper, and wealth—forever renounce, forever abstain.
Walk the great Dao, sever the ten thousand entanglements,
and you shall be utterly without hindrance.
Do not deceive the heart, nor fabricate strange deeds.
Recognize the ever-constant, roam freely and at ease.
Abide in non-action, yet let compassion arise in the heart—
such merit and practice are unmatched.

**To My Fourth Younger Brother, Ma Yunfu**
Live in harmony with others, avoid brawls.
Beware of delusion—gambling, gaming, and drinking.
The hidden winds of illness terrify those nearby—
hasten to their rescue.
To banish sickness, shake your sleeves free.
Cultivate beyond the mundane, pristine and pure from the outset.
There is yet another true and eternal Chang’an—
await its fulfillment in time.

**Against Fabricating Strange Deeds**
Feigning madness, shedding worldly burdens—
do not act wildly, nor cast off family ties.

Freed from family entanglements, keep the mind-ground pure.
Do not feign strangeness, nor pretend to be good;
cease reckless talk of spirits and ghosts.
Cold and heat—know to avoid them.
In pursuing the Dao, do not be ashamed
of coarse clothes and simple fare.
Follow the laws of the land, transgress no heavenly precepts—
such is the livelihood of one who cultivates immortality.

**Against Powdering and Washing the Face**
A monastic, craving fine delicacies,
heedless of waste, powders and washes the face.
Eating vegetarian dumplings, pretending they are turtle soup—
what dignity is there in this?
Indulging the palate brings no lasting benefit.
Coarse tea and plain rice suffice to fill the trench.
Delight in poverty, roam in tranquil simplicity—
this is a different kind of insight.

**To Those Who Prepare Noodles**
Noodle-maker, heed my words:
knead firmly, roll thin, slice with care.
At the stove and hearth, do not delay—
add fire and candlelight without pause.
When fragrance arises and it is well-cooked,
season sweetly and harmoniously, filling the hollow with substance.
After the meal, guard against wild thoughts—
preserve the original, unadorned face.

**Admonition to the Drunken**
Do not indulge in drunkenness, do not indulge in drunkenness.
How could a worthy dare act so before officials?
In cultivating the Dao, superior persons do not contend—
truly, I bear you no ill will.
Do not give free rein to desire, do not give free rein to desire.
Refrain from craving the cup; early on, exalt good deeds.
Take hold of your nature and life, perfect them wholly—
pursue the livelihood of an immortal.

**On the Disciples of the Three Teachings**
The reckoning of the Nine Yangs, thoroughly understood—
disciples of the Three Teachings, just emerged from the nest.
In the depth of spring, by good fortune we meet—
what a different kind of joy this is.
No words, no speech,
grasping hands and laughing without end.
Body and mind—no longer like Cold Mountain—
this life is truly reclaimed.

**Truthful Words**
No scholar chases fame, no talk of profit.
Wine, sex, temper, wealth—no thought is given to them.
Worldly affairs—none concern the heart;
seek instead another livelihood.
To preserve the true, one must cultivate qi.
Within purity and clarity, tiger and dragon play.
Attaining the natural, the inner workings turn—
a celestial embryo is born, an immortal emerges.

**Exhortation to Monks and Daoists for Harmony**
Daoists slander monks, monks slander Daoists—
I urge monks and Daoists: cease this mutual defamation.
What should those who have left the household truly be like?
Resolve the matter of nature and life early on.
Strive for unity, delve into the profound.
Refine the spirit and qi, coalesce them into the Three Treasures.
In the realm of True Suchness, ascend to the Tusita Heaven—
in radiant clarity, journey to Peng Island.

**Against Luxury**
Monastic, listen carefully:
in dwelling, be cautious—
do not build grand and splendid structures.
To construct gardens and pavilions pleasing to the eye—
how does this differ from the ways of the worldly?
If asked, "What is it?"
Bamboo fences and thatched huts,
a broken wooden gate,
patched robes of paper and hemp—
this is the livelihood of the Daoist.

**To Master Zhao**
Monastic, temper yourself.

Each one seeks to subdue self and others,
yet how can past karmic debts—deep and profound—
be torn asunder in an instant?
May the heart open, may delusion shatter early.
All things are empty—why contend?
Refining the self’s form *is* the practice;
it will surely bear fruit in time.

**Exhortation to Disciples Seeking the Dao**
In cultivation, dispel false thoughts.
Ponder carefully, and gradually fine conditions will arise.
Leave the self behind early—
seek the Dao, inquire into Chan—
I cannot be your reliance.
In Chang’an, there are those of lofty conduct:
Master Gu Yue, the ancient moon,
and Teacher Yang Pi, the sheepskin-clad.
Serve them with utmost reverence,
learn a measure of self-cultivation.

**To Dharma Master Guo**
Wild and unrestrained,
he wandered idly,
passing through Jingyuan Town,
where archers and soldiers detained him,
seizing him as a spy
without allowing explanation.
Once angered, no remedy remained.
Bound in Guo Lue, he endured imprisonment.
Had it not been for Lord Guo, the prefect’s grace,
when would this ordeal have ended?

**Lament for the World**
Alas! How shallow is human perception—
those who possess ten thousand strings of cash
deem themselves richer than those with a thousand.
Do they ever consider the great limit that looms,
crushing mountains and shattering eggs alike?
If awakened, cast aside worldly ties.
Turn beyond the material—
no more scheming, no more calculation.
Refine spirit and qi until radiant,
to become an immortal companion on Penglai.

**Again**
Xi Shi’s beauty, Pan An’s looks—

Those who understand see it and laugh.
Though the great wind shapes earth and water into form,
in the end, none escape the pit and grave.
May you awaken, may you comprehend.
What use is an imposing, dignified exterior
if within there is nothing profound to cultivate and perfect,
nothing to grasp the nature of life and destiny clearly?

**To Master Zhang**
Master Zhang, named *Wu Yu* ("Without Desire"),
his virtue-title *Wu Zheng* ("Without Contention"),
naturally free from vulgarity.
Further befitting his Daoist name, *Wu Chen* ("Without Dust"),
he delights in pure poverty and solitary lodging.
Jade within gold, gold within jade—
gold and jade in harmonious balance,
exotic fragrance rich and lush.
When the great elixir is complete,
he will ride the cloud-chariot in ease,
enjoying the immortal blessings of Penglai.

**Lament for the World**
Alas! How recklessly people rush.
When fortune favors, they mock those who have lost it.
How can they know that those who now lack fortune
once enjoyed it as you do?
Alas for hollow fame, alas for fleeting profit—
like floating clouds, no lasting plan.
Ponder life and death, seek the Dao, inquire into Chan,
cultivate longevity and enduring vision.

**To Song the Dharma Master of Wendeng**
He performs the talismanic rites, relieving suffering and illness.
Truly, his noble family’s deep and illustrious practice is known.
Even more, he should hasten to cultivate the true,
recognizing the ancestral origin of qi and spirit.
Refine mercury and lead, harmonize dragon and tiger.
Between wood and metal lies the barrier;
the path flows through midnight and noon.
When naturally the luminous pearl coalesces,
he will point the way to Penglai and return.

**To Li Jin of Yidu Prefecture**
Lord of Longxi, named *Qu Bing* ("To Shed Illness"),
his heart’s virtue-title *Qu Hua* ("To Shed Ornament"),
his Daoist name *Qu Chen* ("To Shed Dust")—most essential.
Once awakened, he will shed all things,
and then cultivate and perfect his nature and destiny.
His mind ever clear, his intent ever pure,
his Dharma name further resonates with the Valley Spirit.
The name *Tong Yi* ("Through Unity") is also fitting,
his style *Xian Qing* ("Immortal Minister") well-matched.

**Lament for the World**
Alas! How foolish people’s schemes.
They vie for the hollow fame of a snail’s horn,
the paltry profit of a fly’s head.
Yet once they gain a mere grain’s height,
they laugh at those beneath.
They bicker over right and wrong, vent idle grievances—
how could they awaken to cultivation,
transcend the mundane, and leave the world behind?
With but a little effort in mastering nature and destiny,
they might claim a place among Penglai’s immortals.

**Again**
Those who tend to family—
not one of them understands.

Each parades their cleverness, yet clings to stinginess and greed.
Though Heaven bestows great gifts—startling to relinquish—
dare they not cherish their own lives?
This life, so vital to the body:
one breath failing, the body becomes dirt and dung.
May they awaken swiftly, hasten to cultivate and preserve,
consolidate their qi and spirit—then immortality is assured.

**To Ma Yandu**
Two in-laws, each enlightened.
What they once cherished,
now see as fierce tigers.
Recognize the wuwei, the pure and tranquil family way,
where nothing is contrived.
No stinginess, no joy or anger.
Regulate the breath evenly, continuously nurture within.
Await the day when merit is complete, the work fulfilled—
together they will ascend on clouds.

**To Ling Yi Zi**
Master He, listen closely.
Before your hair is bound in a topknot,
first wear it in twin buns.
Nor has the time come to beg for scraps—
wait until awakening grants them to you.
Attain samadhi and prajna, enter the first ground.
Rely on non-defilement, non-attachment,
the wuwei livelihood.
With a mind pure and clear, penetrate the wondrous and profound—
then the eternal covenant of immortality is yours.

**Why Master He Went to Ninghai to Compose a Lyric for His Fellow Villagers**
Urge your fellow villagers to awaken.
Fleeting profit, fleeting fame—
neither firm nor enduring.
Wife and children are but walking corpses,
the self but stinking rot.
Turn back early, seek the true path.
Learn from Ma’s example,
joyfully return.
Beyond the material world, till the field of the heart—
become companions to the immortals.

**To Master Wei**
□ is pure, □ plays with fire.
□ in empty stillness, tigers rest with dragons.
□ lotus blooms, surpassing all flowers,
□ in karmic deeds of aid.
Awakening, truly rejoice.
□ the wuwei secret of purity,
naturally penetrates the mysteries.
□ self-attained, cease further pursuit—
□ others need not fear death.

**White Guanyin, Originally Named White Crane Child**

**To Wu Zhigang**
His playful name belies diligence,
for he is one who nurtures simplicity.
To dress, he’s too lazy to raise his arms;
to eat, too indolent to part his lips.
When his face is grimy, he merely seeks water;
his topknot unkempt, he can’t be bothered to wrap a cloth.
No longer does he dream of worldly toil—
he has awakened to the truth within.

**Again**
The method for long life and eternal vision
requires forgetting all things.
Guard the monkey-mind—it’s easily subdued;
restrain the horse-intent—its wildness is hard to curb.
Draw the tiger to dwell in the dragon’s cave,
tame the dragon to reside in the tiger’s den.
When the two become one,
mount the crane and journey to Penglai’s estate.

**Yanling’s Wondrous Formula, Originally Named Twin Swans**

**Respectfully Following Master Chongyang’s Rhyme**
Fortunate to meet Fengxian, parting from the eastern land.
No entanglements, freely roaming the clouds.
True joy and delight, singing with abandon.
These worldly ties—
one day, they will cease.
Emulating Tian Dan’s fire-oxen strategy,
harnessing metal and wood,
reversing the flow.
The great elixir’s radiance shines—no need to cling to cultivation.
For those lost in the ford,
it becomes a ferryboat.

**Five Numinous Immortals**

**Borrowing the Willow Lyric’s Rhyme**
Ma’s wind in Ninghai, Chongyang at eighteen.
Foolishly, yet with cunning.
The six dusts severed.
Though carefree and at ease, open-hearted and expansive,
cloud-roaming and water-crossing, the jade-jewel path slick as ice.
Mending Heaven’s rift.
Exert effort to gather the five hues, managing the living snow.
Regulate dragon and tiger, strike the pass and surge through the nodes.
Attain true joy.
Seeing the clear sky’s crystalline purity,
round and upright,
radiant and bright—
it is the moon of one’s own heart.

**To the Penglai Scatterer**
May your worthy years increase, your family’s wealth disperse.
Children and grandchildren filial—
all cunning.
Yet all transcend.
Emulating the Peng and Xu families,
the whole household suddenly awakens,
together crossing to the other shore.
The path of long life, smooth and clear.
The rabbit’s horn rift.
Come and go, playfully observe—
heavenly flowers, auspicious snow.

The golden stem flourishes, loftily free of branches and nodes.
Within, joy abounds.
This is the numinous youth responding to purity,
□□ true bliss—
no sorrow to untie,
only chanting the wind and moon of the crimson dawn.

**To Master Zhao the Eighth**
Horse Wind’s lyrics bow in homage,
to True Tranquility’s Zhao the Eighth.
Ever pure and still—
within, clever and astute.
Horse and ape severed.
Abiding in non-doing, non-making,
penetrating the mysterious and wondrous,
drinking jade nectar,
fragrant and sweet, smooth to the taste.
No excess, no lack.
Naturally, spirit and qi robust,
sleeping on ice, reclining in snow.
Defying cold and heat—
unbound by seasons.
Such joy!
From the heart’s knowing and understanding,
hard to speak, hard to tell,
carefree and unobstructed,
clearly beholding the true moon of the grotto-heaven.

**To Master Dan of Fufeng County**
Awakened, he descended to my presence,
begging eight coins before the street.
In a whirl of motion—
seeming foolish, seeming dim.
All entanglements severed.
In pure clarity, drinking freely,
blade and spoon drunk to intoxication,
the numinous terrace bright and spotless,
naturally lucid and smooth.
Originally without lack.
Within the jade crucible and golden tripod,
yellow sprouts and white snow.
True dragon and tiger—
coiling around the nodes of the pass.
The joy of the alchemical infant.
Bearing Kunlun’s summit,
bursting through clouds and mist,
heaven knows no day or night—
ever revealing one luminous moon.

**To All Daoist Friends**
Horse Wind earnestly implores,
all noble friends of the Dao.
Do not be deluded by the false—
within, what is worthy endures.
Seek longevity.
Employ true effort wholly in
purifying the heart, stilling the mind,
capturing the ape, seizing the horse—
do not let them wander even briefly.
Attain the leakless.
Qi and spirit unite,
cinnabar congeals.
From nothingness—
naturally, the mouth opens.
Discoursing on non-being.
This profound mystery,
joyfully realized and understood—
it turns out the true master
has secretly transmitted it.

**Playing with Cinnabar (Originally titled "Huanxi Sha")**
**In Praise of Perfected Master Yuchan Puming Chengji, Upon His Ascension**

Dwelling in simplicity, embracing emptiness,
what care for south or north, east or west?
Cinnabar exists only in laughter and conversation.
Life and destiny are not governed by heaven and earth.
With one precious word, bidding farewell to the mountain recluse,
the feathered wheel swiftly carries him to Penglai’s palace.

**Arousing Compassion #2**
Ma Yu often relies on Buddhist practice,
from the heart of non-doing, arousing compassion,
responding to cries of suffering as conduct.

All women and men as one’s parents,
seeing their lives and deaths in dire peril—
one must establish a ladder to heaven.

**Establishing the Ladder**
Erecting the true heavenly ladder,
formless, shadowless, without foundation,
a swift path entering non-doing.
At ease, carefree—
true livelihood,
ever pure, ever still, delighting in the subtle.
Naturally, heaven and earth all return.

**To Master Yu**
The candle of nature shines, illuminating the jade flask,
the incense of the heart wafts fragrantly in the golden crucible,
drinking the blade and spoon to intoxication in true suchness.
Before the Flower Calyx Tower, a horse gallops sideways,
in Huayin County, a donkey is ridden backward—
the youth of the Five Spirits holds the divine pearl.

**To Master Hao**
Great awakening—floating life, no attachment to home,
the great vehicle’s essence, unadorned,
great penetration of the mysterious and wondrous, without boasting.
Great virtue establishes true livelihood,
great elixir refined—a fine livelihood,
great merit accomplished, stepping into mist and clouds.

**To the Daoist Under the Hall**
Idle right and wrong must not be heard,
how can one daily engage in self-discourse?
Secretly harming merit and conduct, damaging the subtle vapors.
The tongue is the root of disaster—firmly seal it,
ordinarily, restrain the opening of misfortune’s gate,
naturally, life and destiny endure.

**Self-Recitation**
Breaking precepts, the mountain recluse speaks at length,
enduring others’ shame and humiliation without remorse,
lately, fondly drinking jade nectar.
Mysterious jade, mysterious gold fill the precious tripod,
true man, true woman fill the elixir chamber—
greedily awaiting residence in Penglai’s estate.

**Expressing My Heart**
External pleasures never stir the inner heart,
within, no mouth yet chanting,
each sound pure and elegant, piercing the jade grove.
To truly listen, one must listen yet not hear,
like the deaf and blind—yet can be pursued.
Then, immortals and buddhas become confidants.

**To Masters Gan and Zhang**
Pure and still, non-doing seals the secret mechanism,
golden waves and jade ripples congeal into blade and spoon.
Marvelous! Wondrous! Reaching the most profound subtlety.
Seizing the dim and silent,
able to eat, able to drink, even more able to carry—
from nothingness, nurturing the transformed child.

**To Master Zhu**
One meal of fragrant wild vegetable stew,
facing the stream, bamboo before him, chanting verses,
unfazed by the turning of jia and geng.
What is the Daoist’s true livelihood?
At high noon, striking the third watch,
plowing together with clouds and moon.

**To Yu the Tile of Ninghai**
The water dog spouts smoke, veiling the jade pavilion,
the fire ox enters the sea to plant the magic field,
white lotus blossoms interspersed with blue.
The blue-eyed foreign monk’s brows sweep the earth,
the frost-haired rabbit’s horns pierce the sky—
the Tathāgata’s perfect sign is originally round.

**To the Daoist Under the Hall**
Abandoning family ties, further abandoning the body,
not feeding tigers or saving starving eagles—
seeing through the illusory form, forgetting oneself.
No shame, no disgrace, no defilement,
carefree and unobstructed, qi and spirit clear—
the true buddha within the heart manifests radiance.

**To Li Jichuan of Huating**
Eleven of us comrades came as one,
ten are bound by karma, their hearts not yet extinguished—
