chunks.original_text: 得遇 悟彻须凭遇，得遇须凭做。 做彻清净功，神仙自来度。 叹辽阳高巨才遇而不悟 辽阳高巨才，宁海曾携手。 同日遇风仙，偏他不回首。 隐奥 天有三十六，地有三十六。 天地入宝瓶，七十二候足。 起慈 愿救众生苦，悲心日日多。 上仙知我意，批出马维摩。 达妙 小小秦川道，迢迢近水边。 闲闲成恍惚，得得遇胎仙。 中选 玉液泛金船，玉性结金莲。 玉篆篆金钰，玉韶韶金仙。 通玄 六月婴裹孩，呼霜带雪来。 马风知得也，决定赴蓬莱。 长生 我有长生诀，今朝说与君。 玉炉三涧雪，金鼎一溪云。 仙伴 谁是山侗友，今朝说与贤。 青莲池上客，黄鹤洞中仙。 食韮九九之数也 马风戒断酒，好吃生生韮。 和韮也不吃，自在逍遥走。 叹凌霄花 仰望凌霄花，看来好不好。 时间依势生，势去成枯草。 道友怪予清瘦 瘦则从教瘦，不许皮儿皱。 鹤体与松形，正是林泉叟。 五体皮袋颂 皮皮皮皮皮，我又不识你。 不若清净乎，直究掉了你。 述怀 悟彻是非海，出离生死关。 人无息肩暇，我有终身闲。 陇州环堵至辛平萧防判以诗赠之 临行更相属，坑堑休深斸。 学取马风风，灰心明性烛。 每见道众无不敬奉遂成－绝谢之 偶尔相会面，何须苦敬钦。 路遥知马壮，岁久辨人心。 赠李大乘五言诗攒五字 □□□□李，□□□□憩。 □□□□凭，□□□□惠。 赠门弟子 □□志好志，□□钦常钦，□□口应口，□□心见心。 遇仙亭 □移并斗转，□指遇仙亭。 □与壬会合，□诀醉中醒。 拆星字起。 又 □计非寻俗，□□对茅亭。 □起眉毛见，□谁悟醉醒。 拆生字起。 赠莱州醮首王永暨众道友 受罪 生前奸狡极，死后罪业多。 决入镬汤狱，难逃铁网罗。 追荐 孝子办追荐，亡灵获福多。 决然离地狱，免得面阎罗。 超度 七祖超升广，九玄度脱多。 携云朝玉帝，跨鹤看参罗。 请圣 玉简躬身执，星冠点地多。 青词采青目，黄道布黄罗。 法事 赴醮星冠广，登坛月帔多。 天尊齐和起，法事越修罗。 圆满 满空鸾鹤降，赴会圣贤多。 符总简圆备，云轩上大罗。 冬至日有作 一阳初运动，一线始争多。 渐有春消息，仍无衣薄罗。 积行 修行行行广，积行行行多。 九转丹烹鼎，六铢衣胜罗。 累功 □诀灵根种，玄言功果多。 养成真玉貌，赛过摩罗。 赠李讲师 常令心地善，未解厌尘多。 弃假投玄趣，修真上大罗。 赠莱州王道正 心性常令善，尘情却厌多。 玄中搜妙理，洞裹看参罗。 述怀 每恨行功少，常嫌身影多。 倦开名利眼，不羡相甘罗。 月下吟 开怀明月下，快意清风多。 道复唯麻布，渔巾作酒罗。 改恶修善 恶者从今善，修仙渐渐多。 将来朝玉帝，免得见阎罗。 敬三教 待士非凡俗，崇僧性不凡。 再三须重道，决要敬麻衫。 应祷攒三字 □□天极高，□□伈旱苗。 □□仙应祷，□□霈三朝。 洞玄金玉集卷之四竟 五言长篇
chunks.translated_text:
To attain awakening, one must rely on encounter;
To gain encounter, one must rely on practice.
Practice thoroughly the work of purity,
And immortals will naturally come to deliver you.

**Lament for Gao Jucai of Liaoyang**
Gao Jucai of Liaoyang,
Once walked hand in hand by the Eastern Sea.
On the same day, he met the Wind Immortal,
Yet he alone turned not his head.

**Hidden Mysteries**
Heaven holds thirty-six,
Earth holds thirty-six.
Heaven and earth enter the precious vase,
And the seventy-two seasonal nodes are complete.

**Arising Compassion**
Wishing to save all beings from suffering,
My heart of sorrow grows day by day.
The Supreme Immortals know my intent,
And send forth Ma Weimo.

**Attaining the Subtle**
The small path of Qin Chuan,
Stretches far near the water’s edge.
In leisurely reverie,
One unexpectedly meets the Womb Immortal.

**Chosen Within**
Jade nectar overflows the golden boat,
Jade nature forms the golden lotus.
Jade script inscribes golden treasures,
Jade music heralds golden immortals.

**Penetrating the Mysterious**
In the sixth month, an infant swaddled,
Calls forth frost and brings snow.
The Horse Wind knows this well,
And resolutely sets course for Penglai.

**Longevity**
I possess the secret of long life,
And today I share it with you:
A jade crucible of triple-valley snow,
A golden tripod of single-stream clouds.

**Immortal Companions**
Who are the mountain’s kindred friends?
Today I tell you, O worthy one:
Guests by the green lotus pool,
Immortals in the Yellow Crane Grotto.

**Nine-Nines of Garlic Consumption**
Horse Wind vowed to abstain from wine,
Preferring raw, life-giving garlic.
Yet even garlic he forgoes,
Wandering carefree and at ease.

**Lament for the Chinese Trumpet Creeper**
Gazing up at the trumpet creeper,
It seems fair—yet is it truly so?
For a time, it clings to power,
But when power fades, it withers to dry grass.

**Fellow Daoists Marvel at My Emaciation**
Let me grow thin as I will,
So long as my skin does not wrinkle.
A crane’s frame, a pine’s form—
Just so, the hermit of woods and springs.

**Ode to the Fivefold Skin-Bag**
Skin, skin, skin, skin, skin,
I know not who you are.
Better far to be pure and still,
And utterly cast you aside.

**Expressing My Heart**
Awakened from the sea of right and wrong,
I have emerged from the gate of life and death.
Others have no respite from their burdens,
Yet I possess lifelong leisure.

**To Xiao Fangpan of Longzhou, Upon Parting**
Before you depart, I urge you once more:
Do not dig too deep into pits and trenches.
Learn from the Horse Wind’s way,
And still your heart to illumine the candle of nature.

**On Seeing Daoist Followers’ Undue Reverence**
Should we chance to meet,
Why must you revere me so?
A long road tests the horse’s strength,
The passage of years reveals a person’s heart.

**Five-Character Poem for Li Dacheng**
□□□□ Li,
□□□□ rests.
□□□□ relies,
□□□□ bestows.

**To My Disciples**
□□ Aspire with aspiration,
□□ Revere with reverence,
□□ Mouth answers mouth,
□□ Heart sees heart.

**Encountering Immortals Pavilion**
□ The Dipper shifts and turns,
□ Pointing to the Encountering Immortals Pavilion.
□ With ren and water in confluence,
□ The secret is awakened in drunkenness.

**[Dismantling the Character "Star" to Begin]**
□ Schemes not for the common,
□□ Facing the thatched pavilion.
□ Eyebrows raised in recognition,
□ Who awakens from drunkenness?

**[Dismantling the Character "Life" to Begin]**

**To Wang Yong, Jiao Chief of Laizhou, and Fellow Daoists**

**Enduring Punishment**
In life, deceit and cunning extreme,
In death, karmic sins abound.
Doomed to the cauldron’s boiling hell,
How escape the iron net?

**Deliverance Through Offerings**
A filial child prepares the rites,
And the departed soul gains blessings manifold.
Surely they depart from hell,
And no longer face King Yama.

**Transcendence**
Seven ancestors ascend in glory,
Nine lineages are delivered in full.
Riding clouds to the Jade Emperor’s court,
Mounting cranes to gaze upon the stars.

**Inviting the Saints**
Holding jade tablets with bowed body,
Star crowns touch the earth in multitude.
Green prayers for green-eyed deities,
Yellow paths spread with yellow silk.

**Ritual**
Attending the jiao in star crowns vast,
Ascending the altar in moon robes many.
Heavenly Worthies chant in unison,
The ritual surpasses the Asuras.

**Completion**
From the empty sky, phoenixes and cranes descend,
Saints and sages gather in great number.
Talismans complete, tablets rounded,
Cloud chariots ascend to the Great Network.

**Composed on the Winter Solstice**
The first yang begins its movement,
A single thread strives to multiply.
Gradually, spring’s tidings emerge,
Yet still no thin silken robes.

**Accumulating Practice**
Cultivating practice, practice ever vast,
Accumulating deeds, deeds ever many.
Ninefold elixir simmers in the crucible,
Six-zhu robes surpass silk.

**Piling Merit**
□ The secret of the numinous root planted,
Mysterious words bear abundant fruit.
Nurtured to true jade countenance,
Surpassing even Maheśvara.

**To Lecturer Li**
Keep the heart-ground ever kind,
Yet not weary of the dust’s abundance.
Abandon the false, seek the mysterious,
Cultivate truth to ascend the Great Network.

**To Wang Daozheng of Laizhou**
Keep the heart-nature ever kind,
Yet weary of worldly passions’ abundance.
Search for wondrous principles in the mysterious,
Gaze upon the stars within the grotto.

**Expressing My Heart**
Ever regretful of scant merit,
Ever vexed by the body’s shadow’s excess.
Weary of opening the eyes of fame and gain,
I envy not the sweetness of licorice.

**Chanting Beneath the Moon**
Opening my heart beneath the bright moon,
Delighted by the many fresh breezes.
The Dao is but hempen cloth,
A fisher’s kerchief serves as wine strainer.

**Reforming Evil and Cultivating Good**
Let the wicked turn good from this day,
And immortality’s cultivation gradually increase.
In time, they shall ascend to the Jade Emperor’s court,
And avoid meeting King Yama.

**Revering the Three Teachings**
Treating scholars as no common folk,
Honoring monks with extraordinary nature.
Again and again, one must esteem the Dao,
And decisively revere the hempen robe.

**Responding to Prayer [Composed by Dismantling "Three"]**
□□ The heavens are most high,
□□ The seedlings fear drought.
□□ The immortals respond to prayer,
□□ Abundant rain for three mornings.

chunks.translated_text:
**Vigilance from Beginning to End**

Eleven years since entering the Dao,
Ever searching for faults within.
Should I wish to become an immortal,
How dare I dim the mirror of the heart?
Should I wish to become an immortal,
How dare I tread the crooked path?
Should I wish to become an immortal,
How dare I lose myself in the dusty world?
Should I wish to become an immortal,
How dare I accept reverence and honor?
Should I wish to become an immortal,
How dare I forget my nature and life?
Should I wish to become an immortal,
How dare I neglect merit and conduct?
With merit and conduct unblemished,
Immortals shall come of their own accord.

**[To Li Dacheng]**

While traveling through the northwest, I arrived at Huating,
Where I converted Li Dacheng.
Thus, I borrow Qiao Junzhang’s rhymes to present this,
Also to instruct the Daoist assembly.

□ Heed the Phoenix Immortal’s teachings,
□ Where do you often stray?
□ You wander the earth’s lungs,
□ Far to Peng Isle’s abode.
□ Riding principle, the hundred bones,
□ Radiance gleams in four directions.
□ Shunning wife and foe,
□ Weary of profit and fame’s coils.
□ The silk thread ever your companion,
□ How can worldly affairs bind you?
□ You aid the Dao,
□ First converting the Confucians.
□ Now seeking cloud companions,
□ Seeking crane-like disciples.
□ The hare flies, the crow soars,
□ The seventh stem rises at Geng’s call.
□ Ren sprouts spring willows,
□ You illumine the frozen lake.
□ The numinous dragon-tiger’s den,
□ The pulse of the mystic maiden’s joy.
□ Though the Daoist adept is skilled,
□ How can the nature be fully grasped?
□ Pointing to the mid-autumn moon,
□ Behold the true form’s chart.

*Composed by dismantling characters, borrowing ancient rhymes.*

chunks.original_text: 劝众道友 我虽未达者，常好静与清。 荣华非染着，不羡拥旗旌。 信笔写诗颂，意气常铮铮。 湛湛成恍惚，澄澄生杳冥。 死灰比我心，槁木类我形。 五行传五藏，黑白赤黄青。 烹炼真炉灶，宝结晃神京。 怀玉人难晓，藐视公与卿。 大道不难学，只恐无虔诚。 勤行不可弃，抱守不可轻。 解通玄又玄，众妙入门庭。 不惟龙虎伏，自有鬼神惊。 同志日相访，紫扉永不扃。 灵芝常饱腹，岂比膻与腥。 我因何所得，能固气神精。 期归蓬岛路，鸾鹤来相迎。 玉女奏仙乐，殊无郑卫声。 灵台为静国，云收性月明。 超然成羽化，岂与万物并。 奉劝学道人，不可外经营。 百年如一梦，休恋利与名。 心香常爇起，何必念仙经。 但存平等行，清净自然成。 愿人同我志，何患不长生。 和坊州朝虚子曹瑱韵 大恸悲红叶，大笑喜头陀。 大志脱生死，大愿拯沉痾。 翻身离苦海，远俗免奔波。 有分修灵室，无缘过柰河。 清中清姹舞，净裹净婴歌。 逗引神丹秀，堤防猿马魔。 五言律诗 自述
chunks.translated_text:
Exhort the Fellow Daoists,

Though I have not yet attained,
I ever favor stillness and purity.
Glory and splendor do not stain me,
I envy not those who bear banners and flags.
With trusty brush I write poems and hymns,
My spirit ever resolute and keen.
Profound, I enter the realm of vagueness,
Limpid, I birth the depths of mystery.
My heart is like dead ashes,
My form akin to withered wood.
The Five Phases transmit to the Five Viscera,
Black and white, red, yellow, and green.
Refining in the true crucible,
Treasure coalesces in the radiant divine capital.
He who bears jade is hard to fathom,
I scorn both duke and minister.
The Great Dao is not hard to learn,
Only fear there be no sincerity.
Diligent practice must not be abandoned,
Embrace and guard it, never lightly.
Comprehend the profound and ever-profound,
All wonders enter your gate.
Not only do dragon and tiger submit,
Even ghosts and spirits stand in awe.
Like-minded friends visit daily,
The purple door remains forever unlatched.
Spiritual mushrooms ever fill my belly,
How can they compare to rank flesh and fish?
How did I come by this attainment?
By firming qi, spirit, and essence.
I await the path to Peng Isle,
Where simurghs and cranes come to welcome me.
Jade maidens play celestial music,
Utterly free of Zheng and Wei’s sounds.
The numinous terrace becomes a realm of stillness,
Clouds recede, the moon of nature shines bright.
Transcendent, I become feathered and transformed,
How can I be ranked with the myriad things?

I exhort those who study the Dao,
Do not seek outwardly.
A hundred years are but a dream,
Do not cling to profit and fame.
Let the incense of the heart ever rise,
Why must you recite the scriptures of immortals?
Simply maintain the practice of equality,
Purity and stillness will naturally manifest.
Would that others share my aspiration,
What worry then of not attaining longevity?

Matching the rhymes of Chaoxuzi Cao Tan of Fangzhou:

Great grief for the crimson leaves,
Great laughter for the shaven monk.
Great resolve to cast off life and death,
Great vow to save those sunk in illness.
Turning the body, I depart the sea of suffering,
Far from the vulgar, I escape toil and bustle.
With fate, I cultivate the numinous chamber,
Without affinity, I cross not the River of Nai.
In purity, the mystic maiden dances,
Within stillness, the infant sings.
Enticing the flourishing of divine elixir,
Guarding against the demons of monkey and horse.

chunks.original_text: 心清眠梦少，意净瑞祥多。 灵滟如红锦，丹烟似紫罗。 虎龙生羽翼，猿马罢奔波。 婴姹成真乐，胎仙应物和。 和黄县呼殿试韵 东有古精蓝，西城近道庵。 南山高翠岭，北海大深潭。 霞友玄中问，云朋妙处参。 人能清表裹，默默自然谈。 又 蓑结衣揉蓝，身居物外庵。 道包天地髓，气运虎龙潭。 常有农商至，宁无禅道参。 愿公当掷笔，早早悟清谈。 鄠县宰公高怀远见访求 世网包名利，尘笼罩是非。 采山寻药去，慕道逐云归。 立石闲垂钓，望人早悟机。 若能怀远虑，定是达幽微。 赠京兆杨学正 择术立身法，无过志读书。 读书便及第，争柰忒名虚。 不若搜玄趣，修完大药炉。 功成超达去，跨鹤赴仙都。 和岐阳镇张都监韵 嗟身常作观，地水火风成。 假合难坚固，真修易炼烹。 形神得俱妙，龙虎自然声。 响喨聒天地，心中性月明。 赠姚玄玉 心灰忘富贵，意静乐清贫。 堪作逍遥客，当为自在人。 气中闲养气，神内更颐神。 不着纤毫假，才方得至真。 和岐阳赵公绰殿试 大道勿难求，宜乎一志修。 速当离火院，休要逐波流。 不作蝇蜗客，堪为鸿鹄俦。 自然通妙用，掌握内云游。 赠虢县段先生 物外绝贪求，清中得进修。 木金三间隔，天地两交流。 菩萨为亲眷，神仙作侣俦。 青莲池上客，黄鹤洞中游。 吟二＋首 迷悟吟
chunks.translated_text:
The mind serene, dreams in sleep are few,
The will untainted, auspicious signs abound.
The numinous shimmers like crimson brocade,
The cinnabar smoke drifts like purple gauze.
Tiger and dragon grow wings,
Monkey and horse cease their bustle.
Infant and maiden attain true joy,
The womb-immortal responds in harmony with things.

Matching the rhymes of Huang County’s Hu Dianshi:

To the east stands an ancient monastery,
To the west, near the Daoist hermitage.
Southern mountains rise in emerald ridges,
Northern seas hold vast, deep pools.
Rosy clouds as companions, we inquire in the mysterious,
Misty friends, we delve into the wondrous.
If one can keep purity within and without,
Silently, the natural discourse flows.

Again:

A cloak woven from indigo-dyed straw,
Dwelling in a hut beyond the world’s dust.
The Dao enfolds the essence of heaven and earth,
Qi courses through the tiger-dragon pool.
Often do farmers and merchants arrive,
Yet none seek the Chan or Dao’s depths.
I wish you, sir, would cast aside your brush,
And early awaken to pure discourse.

To Magistrate Gao of Huxian, whose lofty aspirations sought me out:

The world’s net ensnares fame and gain,
Dust’s cage shrouds right and wrong.
Into the mountains I go to gather herbs,
Following the clouds, I return in pursuit of the Dao.
By a standing stone, I idly fish,
Gazing at others, I wish they’d soon grasp the subtle.
If one can hold far-reaching thoughts,
Surely they’ll fathom the profound and obscure.

To Yang Xuezheng of Jingzhao:

In choosing an art to establish oneself,
None surpasses the resolve to study books.
Yet studying books leads to passing exams—
How can one bear the emptiness of fame?
Better to seek the mysteries’ delight,
And perfect the great elixir’s furnace.
When the work is complete, transcend and depart,
Riding a crane to the immortals’ capital.

Matching the rhymes of Zhang Dujian of Qiyang Town:

Alas, the body is ever an object of contemplation,
Composed of earth, water, fire, and wind.
This borrowed union is hard to sustain,
True cultivation is easily refined and tempered.
Form and spirit together attain perfection,
The dragon and tiger naturally resound.
Their clarion echoes shake heaven and earth,
While the moon of the mind’s nature shines bright.

To Yao Xuanyu:

The heart ashen, wealth and rank forgotten,
The will at rest, delighting in pure poverty.
One may become a carefree wanderer,
And ought to be a self-possessed person.
Within qi, leisurely nurture qi,
Within spirit, further cultivate spirit.
Not clinging to the slightest falsity,
Only then can one attain the utmost truth.

Matching the rhymes of Zhao Gongchuo of Qiyang’s palace examination:

The great Dao is not hard to seek,
One should cultivate it with single-minded devotion.
Swiftly leave the fiery court,
No longer chase the flowing waves.
Do not be a fly or worm’s guest,
But rather a companion to swans and cranes.
Naturally, one will penetrate wondrous function,
And wander the clouds within one’s grasp.

To Master Duan of Guoxian:

Beyond things, abandon greed,
In purity, advance in cultivation.
Wood and metal stand threefold apart,
Heaven and earth flow in mutual exchange.
Bodhisattvas become close kin,
Immortals serve as companions.
A guest by the green lotus pond,
A traveler in the Yellow Crane Grotto.

Twenty-two poems in all:
*On Delusion and Awakening*

chunks.translated_text:
**To Yue Kongyue of Fengxiang Prefecture and Daoist Companions**

To raise a family is to endure hardship,
To study the Dao is to ascend as an immortal.
Raising a family seeks without,
Studying the Dao mends within.
Raising a family binds one to the wheel of rebirth,
Studying the Dao frees one from coming and going.
We are all the same in kind,
Only differing in awakening or delusion.

*On Sin and Blessing*

Exhortation to Fellow Daoists:
Raising a family breeds daily greed,
Studying the Dao fosters constant contentment.
Raising a family is for wife and child,
Studying the Dao detaches from worldly dust.
Raising a family forges sinful karma,
Studying the Dao reaps immortal blessing.
Sin and blessing each beckon their own,
Heaven’s halls stand opposite hell’s abyss.

*On Suffering and Joy*

**To Gao Mouke of Fengxiang Prefecture and Master Cheng**

Raising a family brings torment,
Daoist cultivation knows no searing brand.
Family drains the spirit,
Daoist refinement harmonizes the meridians.
Family burdens drag one to the Yellow Springs,
Daoist attainment lifts one beyond the azure vault.
Those who choose family or Dao,
Themselves invite suffering or joy.

*Enduring Chant*

**To Lin Tao Prefecture’s Magistrate Wu Gong of Wulin**

Family ties may seem worth clinging to,
Yet why bear the name of a fiery court?
If the Dao cannot be cultivated,
Even the sea toad seeks glory.
May one awaken to this soon,
And study the Dao for lasting ease.
Beyond things, delight in tranquility,
Refine and restore the original face.

*Leaving the Dust*

**To Li Qingchang of Yufeng and Fellow Senior Daoists**

The golden fetters shatter upon awakening,
The jade bonds break upon vigilance.
With skillful hands, untie the snare of fame,
With reverence, strike the lock of profit.
No longer will the ford of delusion ensnare,
Nor the waves of desire sweep me away.
Become one who leaves the dust,
And beyond things, cultivate the immortal fruit.

*On the Joy of Encounter*

**To Zhao Gongchuo of Qiyang’s Palace Examination and Fellow Daoists**

Do not let the horse gallop wildly,
Nor the monkey play unchecked.
The heart’s intent will naturally settle,
Self and others will effortlessly subside.

chunks.original_text: 修炼身中真，断制身为假。 东遇重阳师，西整丹阳马。 逍逼吟 临洮府推高武功，遣人赉书来终南祖庵邀请。 予誓不乘骑，加之路遥，不克趋赴。 作此以赠之。 因遇无羁绊，通玄养慧苗。 心神常坦坦，云水任飘飘。 疏散横担醁，优游懒系腰。 不唯身自在，更得性逍遥。 行道吟勉门人 皓月照林霜，华轩放彩光。 玉炉生宝篆，金鼎酿琼浆。 礼数无拘束，平和得异常。 岂思为家计，行道万缘忘。 三奇吟自谕 勘破这尸骸，须当救度壳。 直饶五马荣，难牧三奇朴。 涤虑灭三彭，洗心按三角。 人皆贵名高，我独惊超卓。 证修吟 劝门人宁贴办道
chunks.translated_text:
**Cultivating the True Within the Body**

Cultivate the true within the body,
Sever and restrain the false of form.
Eastward, I met Master Chongyang,
Westward, I attended Danyang’s horse.

*Roaming Free*

**To Magistrate Gao of Wugong in Lintao Prefecture, Who Sent an Envoy with a Letter Inviting Me to the Ancestral Hermitage on Zhongnan**

I vowed never to ride,
And the road is far—
I cannot hasten to attend.
This I compose in reply.

Encountering no fetters,
I penetrate the mysterious and nurture wisdom’s sprout.
Heart and spirit ever at ease,
Clouds and waters drift as they will.
Unburdened, I shoulder a flask of wine,
Leisurely, I loosen my sash.
Not only is the body at liberty,
But the nature, too, roams free.

*Walking the Dao*

**Exhorting Disciples**

Bright moon illumines the frosted forest,
A splendid carriage radiates its glow.
The jade crucible births sacred talismans,
The golden tripod brews nectar fine.
Rites know no constraint,
Serenity attains the extraordinary.
Why ponder household affairs?
Walking the Dao, all ties are forgotten.

*Three Marvels*

**Self-Admonition**

See through this corpse-shell,
And you must save the mortal frame.
Though five steeds bring glory,
They cannot herd the three marvels’ simplicity.
Wash away cares to extinguish the Three Peng,
Purify the heart to still the Three Horns.
All prize fame and high renown—
I alone marvel at the transcendent.

*Attaining Cultivation*

**Encouraging Disciples to Devote Themselves to the Dao**

Devote yourselves steadfastly to the Way.

chunks.original_text: 辨铅须灭汞，得汞却生铅。 证佛得无量，修仙道有玄。 仙佛归一趣，道德在两全。 谨谨心宁贴，行持忘要坚。 真一吟 赠凤翔府迎祥观众大师 命清得长生，性静能久视。 命乃气之名，性乃神之字。 气是神之母，神是气之子。 子母成真一，真一脱生死。 述怀吟 赠华亭居环堵灵阳子李大乘 食乞且糊口，身投清净户。 四攸不成真，一气堪为主。 能将性月修，解把心琴抚。 灭尽尸与虫，免教苦中苦。 日用吟 赠华亭传灯子张大悟暨众师兄 朝也防心动，暮也防心动。 炼气做生涯，颐神为日用。 常交龙虎调，不使马猿弄。 堪为睡觉人，兔作梦中梦。 固本吟 赠陇州佑德观王道正 识破四假身，修炼个真身。 欲要成灵物，须当固本根。 清闲无一事，疏散绝纤尘。 已作逍遥客，兼为自在人。 无为吟　自咏 术法我不会，打坐我不爱。 终日乐逍遥，终日占自在。 观天行大道，自然得交泰。 本师传口诀，无为功最大。 清净吟 赠华亭县宰明威 锻炼这顽心，锻炼这俗意。 心死情不生，意灭精自秘。 心清气自调，意净神自喜。 人能常清净，决证神仙位。 自然吟 赠陇州萧防判 顿觉万缘空，顿觉心开悟。 心猿自然停，意马自然住。 龙虎自然调，神气自然固。 金丹自然结，神仙自然做。 落魄吟 赠真阳子来灵玉 一身放落魄，衣挂两三索。 脱了妻男雠，免受利名缚。 坐卧无羁绊，住行无依托。 谁知落魄人，内隐踏云脚。 圣功吟 赠陇州李镇国 我有修仙术，说破人惊骇。 净裹撮乾坤，空中安鼎鼎。 扳倒昆仑山； 托起大阳海。 山海变桑田，性命久长在。 全真吟 借山堂吟韵 全真日兮金乌飞，全真月兮玉兔归。 青龙戏兮投虎溪，是不是兮孰得知。 颂 无有颂
chunks.translated_text:
**Discerning Lead and Mercury**

Discern lead to extinguish mercury,
Obtain mercury to revive lead.
Attaining Buddhahood gains the boundless,
Cultivating immortality holds profound mystery.
Immortal and Buddha converge in one pursuit,
Virtue and power achieve dual perfection.
With utmost care, settle the heart,
In practice, forget not steadfast resolve.

**True Unity**

*Presented to the Masters of Yingxiang Abbey, Fengxiang Prefecture*

Destiny purified attains longevity,
Nature stilled enables enduring vision.
Destiny is the name of qi,
Nature is the word of spirit.
Qi is the mother of spirit,
Spirit is the child of qi.
Mother and child form true unity,
True unity transcends life and death.

**Expressing Aspirations**

*Presented to Layman Li Dacheng of Lingyang, Huating, Dwelling in Simplicity*

Begging food but to fill the mouth,
Body lodged in purity’s abode.
The four concerns fail to attain truth,
One qi alone may serve as master.
Cultivate the moon of nature,
Know how to pluck the heart’s lute.
Extinguish corpse and worms entirely,
To spare oneself the bitterest of suffering.

**Daily Practice**

*Presented to Zhang Dawu of Huating, Bearer of the Lamp, and Fellow Masters*

At dawn, guard against the heart’s stirring,
At dusk, guard against the heart’s stirring.
Refining qi becomes one’s livelihood,
Nurturing spirit is daily practice.
Ever harmonize dragon and tiger,
Let not horse and ape play wanton.
Worthy is the sleeper awake,
Who escapes the dream within a dream.

**Strengthening the Root**

*Presented to Wang Daozheng of Youde Abbey, Longzhou*

See through the four false bodies,
Cultivate the one true form.
To become a numinous being,
One must strengthen the root.
Leisurely, without a single care,
Detached, free from the slightest dust.
Already a wanderer of freedom,
Also one of perfect ease.

**Non-Action**

*Self-Reflection*

I know not arts and methods,
I care not for seated meditation.
All day I delight in freedom,
All day I claim perfect ease.
Observing heaven’s great Dao,
Naturally attains harmony.
The master’s oral transmission:
Non-action yields the greatest merit.

**Purity**

*Presented to the Magistrate of Huating County, Mingwei*

Temper this stubborn heart,
Temper this worldly intent.
When the heart dies, passions do not arise,
When intent vanishes, essence remains secret.
Heart pure, qi naturally harmonizes,
Intent clear, spirit naturally rejoices.
One who abides in constant purity
Shall surely attain the immortal’s rank.

**Spontaneity**

*Presented to Magistrate Xiao of Longzhou*

Suddenly all concerns dissolve,
Suddenly the heart awakens.
The heart-ape naturally stills,
The intent-horse naturally halts.
Dragon and tiger naturally harmonize,
Spirit and qi naturally consolidate.
Golden elixir naturally coalesces,
Immortality naturally unfolds.

**Falling into Disrepute**

*Presented to Zhenyangzi, Lai Lingyu*

Body cast into disrepute,
Clothes hanging by two or three threads.
Freed from the enmity of wife and child,
Spared the bonds of profit and fame.
Sitting and lying without restraint,
Dwelling and moving without dependence.
Who knows this fallen man
Conceals feet treading clouds within?

**Sacred Merit**

*Presented to Li Zhenguo of Longzhou*

I possess the art of immortality,
Its revelation startles all who hear.
Within purity, gather heaven and earth,
In emptiness, set the tripod firm.
Upend Kunlun Mountain,
Uplift the vast ocean of the sun.
Mountain and sea transform to mulberry fields,
Nature and destiny endure forever.

**Perfection of Truth**

*After the Rhyme of Mountain-Dwelling Hall*

Perfection of truth—day, the golden crow flies,
Perfection of truth—moon, the jade hare returns.
Green dragon plays, leaping into tiger’s stream,
Is it so or not? Who can truly know?

chunks.original_text: 不悟无无迷有有，争知有有却无无。 人皆着物物非物，我独如愚愚不愚。 通玄颂 得遇投真修妙果，玄中通晓些儿个。 寻思性命不由天，斡运阴阳全在我。 见性颂 一点灵光晃太虚，丹青妙手莫能摹。 休将明月闲相比，有缺因缘怎类吾。 和坊州曹解元次子曹守志 赛过庞公胜陈七，俄惊生死忻然出。 愿贤守志莫忘初，定是前程子得一。 和完颜尼福海所闻空中颂四章 口不念经经自念，足不登楼楼自上。 家乡悟彻好离乡、心田耕了更无田。 又 行也同时坐也同，大悲手段绝听闻。 救拔滞魄与孤魂，出离地狱入天门。 又 大道身中物外求，火裹青莲滴珠露。 长在宝瓶为供具，慈悲心起常坚固。 又 无乡无里，有乡有里。 起慈起悲，普挈普提。 赠华事张四机宜 不染不着，无为无作。 常清常净，真欢真乐。 赠凤翔府灵童张守清 道大道大，无毁无坏。 悟者得之，性命长在。 赠苗－官人 脱尘离俗，通三悟六。 养气全神，永占仙福。 赠陇州小麻先生 清心净意，养气全神。 功昭行着，得做仙人。 赠陇州染赵先生 恶死离死，好生修生。 真清真静，性住命停。 示门人 酒色财气，攀缘爱念。 忧愁思虑，非道识见。 又 清闲无事，逍遥自在。 不染不着，得超三界。 又 心清意静，气和神定。 真息绵绵，灵光莹莹。 又 无为无作，不染不着。 命变霜球，性通丹药。 赠于内奉先生 道眼不明，心地不灵。 别无他事，行道不精。
chunks.translated_text:
**On Not Awakening**

Not awakening to Non-Being, one strays into Being;
How then can one know that Being reverts to Non-Being?
All cling to things, yet things are not things—
I alone seem foolish, yet this folly is no folly.

**Hymn of Penetrating the Mysterious**

Having met the true, one cultivates the wondrous fruit,
A few within the mysterious attain clarity.
Pondering: life and destiny are not heaven’s decree,
The turning of yin and yang rests entirely with me.

**Hymn of Seeing Nature**

A single spark of numinous light illumines the great void,
No master of brush and ink could ever capture it.
Do not idly compare it to the bright moon—
How could its flawless cause resemble that which wanes?

**In Reply to Cao Shouzhi, Second Son of Cao Jieyuan of Fanzhou**

Surpassing Lord Pang and outshining Chen Qi,
Suddenly startled by life and death, yet joyfully emergent.
May the worthy Shouzhi hold fast to his resolve, never forgetting his beginning—
Surely his future will attain the One.

**Four Hymns Harmonizing with What Perfect Man Nifuhai Heard in the Void**

Mouth does not chant the sutra, yet the sutra chants itself;
Feet do not climb the tower, yet the tower ascends of its own.
Having awakened to the homeland, best to depart the homeland—
The field of the heart plowed, no more fields remain.

**Also**

Walking or sitting, all is simultaneous and the same,
The hand of great compassion employs means beyond hearing.
Rescuing stagnant souls and lonely spirits,
They emerge from hell and enter heaven’s gate.

**Also**

The great Dao is sought beyond the body yet within the self,
Amid fire blooms the blue lotus, dripping pearls of dew.
Ever present in the jeweled vase as an offering,
When the heart of compassion arises, it remains steadfast.

**Also**

No homeland, no village—
Yet homeland, yet village.
Rising compassion, rising sorrow,
Universally lifting, universally awakening.

**Presented to Zhang Siji of Huashi**

Unstained, unattached,
Non-action, non-creation.
Ever pure, ever tranquil,
True joy, true bliss.

**Presented to the Divine Youth Zhang Shouqing of Fengxiang Prefecture**

Great is the Dao, great is the Dao,
Unharmed, unbroken.
Those who awaken attain it—
Life and destiny endure forever.

**Presented to Official Miao Yi**

Shedding the dust, leaving the俗,
Penetrating the Three, awakening to the Six.
Cultivating qi, preserving spirit,
Forever securing immortal blessings.

**Presented to Master Xiao Ma of Longzhou**

Purify the heart, still the intent,
Cultivate qi, preserve spirit.
Merits manifest, conduct illustrious—
You shall become an immortal.

**Presented to Master Zhao the Dyer of Longzhou**

Shunning death, departing death,
Cherishing life, cultivating life.
Truly pure, truly still—
Nature abides, destiny endures.

**Instructions to Disciples**

Wine, sex, wealth, and temper,
Clinging, attachment, love, and thought.
Worry, sorrow, contemplation—
None of these are the Dao’s insight.

**Also**

Leisurely and carefree,
At ease and self-so.
Unstained, unattached—
Attain transcendence of the Three Realms.

**Also**

Heart pure, intent still,
Qi harmonized, spirit settled.
True breath, unbroken,
Numinous light, radiant.

**Also**

Non-action, non-creation,
Unstained, unattached.
Destiny transforms like frost and orb,
Nature connects to the elixir.

**Presented to Master Yu Neifeng**

The Dao-eye unclear,
The heart-ground unillumined.
Nothing else to do—
One’s practice of the Dao is not refined.

chunks.translated_text:
**Collected Verses on Resolving to Cultivate Immortality**

To cultivate immortality together,
All worldly ties are cast aside.
Never forget your original resolve—
With each step, strengthen your determination.
To the very end, hold fast,
And see it through to completion.
Life is like a pure breeze,
Nature like the bright moon.

*End of Volume Five of* **The Cave of Mystery: Gold and Jade Collection**
*Volume Six of* **The Cave of Mystery: Gold and Jade Collection**

**Six-Character Poems**

**On the Pavilion of Contented Aging**
I have a cup of fragrant wine,
To share with a kindred spirit.
Gazing upon the bustling world,
None compare to the carefree rustic elder.

**Also**
Fallen into dissipation, indulging in wine,
Drunk and sober—such states have been.
If one asks my lineage,
My ancestral home is in Fufeng, the elder of Shen.
My ancestor’s name was Jue, styled Shen-sou.

**Matching the Previous Rhyme in Tribute to Wei, Magistrate of Longzhou**
Fond of drinking the immortal’s wine of longevity,
Fond of seeking the "something" within "nothing."
Fond of revering the heart as one’s teacher,
Fond of becoming a transcendent elder beyond the mundane.

**Following Master Hu’s Rhyme**
□Zhang’s words are wondrous,
□All worldly chatter.
□Better to say nothing,
□In silence, the marvelous speech.

*(Lines begin with the character "口" [mouth], deconstructed.)*

**In Praise of Master Shi**
Master Shi encountered his fate,
Encountered Chongyang.
Chongyang transmitted the teaching,
Transmitted the Mystery and the Yellow.
The profound principle of Mystery and Yellow,
Never to be forgotten.
Within, he upheld cultivation,
Without, he severed worldly heat and cold.
Water and fire achieved harmony,
Sun and moon conjoined their light.
The dragon chants in the Li position,
The tiger roars in the Kan chamber.
Wood and metal stand apart,
Infant and maiden unite in round and square.
The elixir pellet is savored,
Its flavor known, its fragrance perceived.
The divine elixir coalesces in perfection,
Gleaming with crystalline radiance.
The immortal of the wind comes to ferry him,
Manifesting auspicious signs.
For three days they sang and danced,
Then bid farewell to the streets and lanes.
Only saying, "I depart,
Hastening to Peng’s estate."
Returning to the hermitage,
He suddenly passed away.
Onlookers gathered in crowds,
For the event was extraordinary.
His true nature, one and numinous,
Took its place in the ranks of immortals.

**Song**

**Song of Salvation** *(To the tune of Su Dongpo’s verse)*

chunks.original_text: 我无去就心何处，不摇不动三阳宇。 一志超然不外求，万事俱忘常内顾。 自衒无拘落魄人，逍遥坦荡乐清贫。 身如野鹤无萦击，意似孤云无点尘。 无功无法心打坐，闲是闲非耳边过。 人来请我求追荐，再三再四难阻面。 环墙结夏应加持，日祷一斋非下贱。 真经默念起慈悲，救苦咄开地狱门。 孤魂滞魄脱枷锁，狂歌狂舞乱纷纷。 承斯功德得迁转，祥云引赴瑶池宴。 我观世事忒煞空，又把世人当酷劝。 求财求财须重义，不义之财如刀利。 不如照破事情疏，猛弃妻男大丈夫。 莫忘初志休生退，日就月将如我辈。 视无所见听无声，不视不听得视听。 法体无形形自现，法鼓无声声自鸣。 出门入户自迎送，迎送往来通妙用。 重阳传授与山侗，我今转付与诸公。 自然霞彩通车轼，自然准望神仙职。 到此不分西与东，何愁无分继扶风。 人还悟此玄玄理，方信蓬瀛指顾中。 慈惠歌藏头拆字 □然幸遇重阳仙，□我俱忘半拖袂。 □冠不整效师家，□羊不食非边裔。 非边裔，□诀传来十三岁，□戟心肠久已无，□灭烟消三吉髻。 □行大善起慈悲，□念哀人懃劝世。 □灵无染永清清，□气调匀常细细。 常细细，□种丹田仙踵继。 □绵紬绢敌风霜，□惠贫人任破敝。 □笔不侵利与名，□舌奚言犬与彘。 □来灵物吐红辉，□显教门诗曲缀。 □有鹤疏来请予，□宁对我专发誓。 □其追荐救亡灵，□志可怜慈可惠。 □神默祷本师真，□此申闻阴府诣。 □下孤魂滞魄苏，□天超度如舟济。 □声歌咏九皋禽，□有青鸾赤凤唳。 拆人字起。 普救歌藏头拆字 □色水流梁栋间，□乌月兔来处。 □诚守道得真欢，□意常清通妙语。 通妙语，□论传玄锺与吕。 □诀复授王风仙，□侗得遇获深趣。 □观玉姹洞中歌，□喜金婴空裹舞。 空裹舞，□年陕右居环堵。 □来月往猿停马，□灭烟消龙缠虎。 □然牒发到山东，□德人来祷内补。 □冠重整来追荐，□之加持报乡土。 □齐魂魄出黄泉，□历云游归紫府。 归紫府，□之云鹤不我拒。 □哉普救免轮回，□子超升仙尽与。 发叹歌 芝阳道友访文登，非是寻芳觅翠荣。 具说宰公投尺牍，邀予掌醮救亡灵。 救亡灵，事最好，有些小事当分剖。 惟恐后进相效颦，赶斋赴醮不修道。 不修道，怎了仙，了仙须炼气绵绵。 倒卷辘轳灯树落，斡旋宇宙性灵圆。 性灵圆，当积行，引人回首归清净。 慈悲援溺布桥梁，恻隐扶危立梯隥。 立梯隥，作渡舟，度人物外做真修。 柰何道友求追荐，孜孜祷我救阴囚。 救阴囚，如何是，予乃无为清净士。 未尝趁醮和天尊，不会登坛行法事。 行法事，请黄冠，洁己登坛作内观。 予应加持处环堵，默祷本师天仙官。 天僖官，重阳也，发叹起慈行悯化。 千重地狱枷锁开，一切亡灵罪情舍。 罪情舍，暨孤魂，同游紫府入仙门。 不夜乡中得真乐，长春洞裹捧金蹲。 和胡讲师韵 重阳真人寻友，东游宁海。 三髻懒汉选仙，西访长安。 长安大道，如何者哉。 堪放落魄，宜弃婴孩。 既通玄趣，当补形骸。 抽添运用，次叙挨排。 飞乌走兔，双戏俱皑。 烟消火灭，锐挫强摧。 断除烦恼，洗涤尘埃。 心无染着，齿免。 金花要赏，玉树栽培。 火生慧草，水长灵荄。 常教灵焰泼泼，无令神水溃溃。
chunks.translated_text:
I harbor no mind of going or staying—where then could it dwell?
Unshaken, unmoved, within the realm of the Three Yangs.
With single intent transcendent, seeking nothing without,
All affairs forgotten, ever turning inward in reflection.
A carefree soul unbound, a man of fallen fortunes,
I roam at ease, content in pristine poverty.
My body like a wild crane, untouched by snares,
My mind like a lone cloud, unstained by dust.
No merit, no dharma—my heart sits in meditation,
Idle chatter and baseless talk pass by my ears.
When people come beseeching me for rites of deliverance,
Again and again, I cannot turn them away.
Encircled by walls, I observe the summer retreat, applying blessings,
Daily prayers and a single meal—no lowly act.
Silently reciting the true scripture, I arouse compassion,
Rescuing the suffering with a shout, flinging open hell’s gates.
Lonely souls and stagnant spirits shed their shackles,
Singing wildly, dancing in chaotic joy.
By this merit they gain rebirth,
Auspicious clouds guide them to the Jade Pool feast.

I see worldly affairs as utterly hollow,
Yet I admonish mortals with stern exhortation:
"Seek wealth, seek wealth—but hold fast to righteousness,
For unrighteous wealth is sharp as a blade.
Better to see through worldly entanglements,
Boldly forsake wife and child, be a true man.
Never forget your original resolve, nor falter in retreat,
Day by day, month by month, follow my example.
Seeing yet seeing nothing, hearing yet hearing nothing,
Not seeing, not hearing—yet attaining true sight and sound.
The Dharma-body is formless, yet form manifests,
The Dharma-drum is soundless, yet sound resounds.
Exiting and entering doors, I am welcomed and sent off,
In welcoming and sending, the wondrous function is revealed.
Master Chongyang transmitted this to Shantong,
Now I pass it on to you all.
Naturally, rosy clouds stream from the chariot’s crossbar,
Naturally, one gazes toward the office of immortals.
At this point, east and west are no longer divided,
What worry is there of lacking a share in Fufeng’s lineage?
If one awakens to this profoundly profound principle,
Then Penglai and Yingzhou lie within a glance’s reach."

**Song of Compassion** *(Hidden-Head Acrostic)*
□ At last, fortunately meeting Chongyang’s immortal,
□ I forgot all, half-dragging my sleeves.
□ My cap askew, emulating my master’s way,
□ Like a sheep that eats not, no border outcast.
No border outcast,
□ The secret method transmitted at thirteen,
□ My heart of halberds long since dissolved,
□ Smoke extinguished, the three auspicious topknots gone.
□ Practicing great goodness, arousing compassion,
□ Mindful of the grieving, diligently exhorting the world.
□ The numinous remains unstained, forever pure,
□ Qi harmonized, ever so gently.
Ever so gently,
□ Planting in the cinnabar field, the immortal’s heels follow.
□ Silk and fine cloth resist wind and frost,
□ Bestowing on the poor, tattered though it be.
□ The brush never encroaches on profit or fame,
□ The tongue need not speak of dogs or swine.
□ A numinous object appears, spitting crimson radiance,
□ Revealing the teachings through poems and songs.
□ A crane arrives, sparse and distant, to summon me,
□ How could it refuse me, who vows so earnestly?
□ Thus I perform rites to deliver the departed,
□ Their resolve pitiable, their compassion worthy.
□ Silently praying to my original true master,
□ I report this to the underworld’s courts.
□ Below, lonely souls and stagnant spirits revive,
□ Above, they are ferried across like boats on water.
□ Their voices sing like birds of the nine marshes,
□ Where green simurghs and red phoenixes cry.

*(The acrostic begins with the character "人" [person].)*

**Song of Universal Salvation** *(Hidden-Head Acrostic)*
□ Colored waters flow between beams and pillars,
□ Where the crow and hare of sun and moon come.
□ Sincerely guarding the Dao, attaining true joy,
□ My intent ever pure, my wondrous words flow.
My wondrous words flow,
□ Profound discussions transmit the mystery to Zhong and Lü.
□ The secret method again passed to Wang, Feng, and the immortals,
□ Shantong, having met them, gained deep delight.
□ Gazing at the jade maiden singing in the cave,
□ Rejoicing as the golden infant dances in the void.
Dances in the void,
□ For years in Shaanxi’s right, dwelling in humble walls.
□ Months passed like monkeys halting, horses pausing,
□ Smoke extinguished, dragons entwining tigers.
□ Suddenly, a decree arrived in Shandong,
□ Virtuous people came to pray for inner blessings.
□ My cap straightened, I performed rites of deliverance,
□ Applying blessings to repay my homeland.
□ All souls and spirits rise from the Yellow Springs,
□ Wandering through clouds to return to the Purple Court.
Return to the Purple Court,
□ Where cloud-cranes do not reject me.
□ Ah! Universally saved from the wheel of rebirth,
□ All children ascend as immortals, none left behind.

**Song of Sighing**
Zhiyang’s Daoist friend visited Wendeng,
Not to seek blossoms or chase emerald splendor.
He spoke of Magistrate Zai sending a letter,
Inviting me to preside over rites to save the departed.
To save the departed—
A most noble task,
Yet some small matters must be clarified.
I fear later generations will imitate in vain,
Rushing to feasts and rites without cultivating the Dao.
Without cultivating the Dao,
How can one attain immortality?
To attain immortality, one must refine qi ceaselessly,
Reverse the waterwheel, let the lamp-tree fall,
Whirl through the cosmos, perfecting the numinous nature.
When the numinous nature is perfected,
One must accumulate merit,
Turning people’s heads to return to purity.
With compassion, rescue the drowning, build bridges,
With empathy, aid the perilous, erect ladders.
Erecting ladders,
Becoming a ferryboat,
Ferrying beings beyond, engaging in true cultivation.
Yet why do Daoist friends seek rites of deliverance,
Diligently praying for me to save the imprisoned dead?
To save the imprisoned dead—
What is this?
I am a man of non-action, of purity and stillness,
Never chasing rites or invoking the Heavenly Worthy,
Unskilled in ascending altars to perform rituals.
Performing rituals—
Summoning the yellow-crowned,
Purifying myself to ascend the altar, turning inward in contemplation.
Where I apply blessings, encircled by walls,
I silently pray to my original master, the Heavenly Immortal Official.
The Heavenly Joy Official—
Chongyang himself—
Sighing, he arouses compassion, transforming with pity.
A thousand layers of hell’s shackles open,
All departed spirits’ sins are forgiven.
Sins forgiven,
Together with lonely souls,
They roam the Purple Court, entering the gates of immortals.
In the Land of No Night, they attain true joy,
In the Cave of Eternal Spring, they hold golden cups.

**Matching Hu the Preceptor’s Rhyme**
The Perfected of Chongyang sought a friend,
Traveling east to Ninghai.
The lazy man with three topknots chose immortality,
Journeying west to Chang’an.
The great road of Chang’an—
What is it like?
Fit for the carefree,
Apt for abandoning the infant.
Having grasped the profound essence,
One should restore the body’s form.
Drawing and adding, employing and arranging,
Next in sequence, step by step.
Flying birds and running hares,
Both play in pristine whiteness.
Smoke vanishes, fire extinguishes,
Sharpness blunted, strength subdued.
Severing afflictions,
Washing away dust.
The heart unstained,
Teeth free from decay.
Gold flowers to be admired,
Jade trees to be cultivated.
Fire nurtures the grass of wisdom,
Water nourishes the sprouts of the numinous.
Ever let the numinous flame blaze,
Never let the spirit-water overflow.

His true nature, one and numinous,
Took its place in the ranks of immortals.

chunks.original_text: 常教命灯明朗，无令性烛沉埋。 寻访同心同德，讲论有倚有挨。 三尸拜降方寸，六贼难会九垓。 要斡旋壶中日月，须倒颠洞裹山隈。 得自然爱欲星散，得自然人我星。 大药清灵于玉鼎，胎仙歌舞于瑶台。 堪叹利名之切切，堪叹生死之哀哀。 好把尘缘大家勘破，休教走骨时暂狂乖。 决要炼形如同槁木，决要降心有若死灰。 异日丹成九转，携云同赴蓬莱。 立身法 立身之法，分明说破。 意马牢擒，心猿紧锁。 戒断悭贪，伏降人我。 节慎语言，堤防口过。 莫起风波，休生烟火。 忙裹偷闲，闹中趖躲。 修仁蕴德，消灾灭祸。 退己进人，亦成仙果。 〔说十了〕 十了功乃内事，非眼前境界，真清真净，自然得之。 项中霞彩流，眼中光明流，耳中冲和流，鼻中玉柱流，口中甘津流，心中真火流，脐下黄河倒卷流，木金随波运转流，自然天地两交流，十分功满性风流。 联句 摆脱名缰三岛客，掣开利锁十洲仙。
chunks.translated_text:
Keep the life-lamp ever bright and clear,
Never let the nature-candle sink and fade.
Seek those of like heart and like virtue,
Discussing with support and sequence in turn.
The Three Corpses bow and submit within the square inch,
The Six Bandits struggle to reach the Nine Heavens.
To turn the sun and moon within the pot,
One must invert the mountains within the cave.
Attaining the natural, desires scatter like stars,
Attaining the natural, self and others dissolve like stars.
The great elixir, pure and numinous in the jade crucible,
The fetal immortal sings and dances on the Jasper Terrace.
How lamentable is the clamor of fame and profit,
How lamentable the sorrow of life and death.
Best to thoroughly examine worldly ties together,
Lest the walking skeleton briefly stray in madness.
Resolve to refine the form like withered wood,
Resolve to subdue the heart like cold ashes.
One day, when the ninefold elixir is complete,
Ride the clouds to Penglai together.

**Method of Establishing the Body**
The method of establishing the body is clearly revealed:
Firmly restrain the horse of intent,
Tightly lock the monkey of the heart.
Sever stinginess and greed,
Subdue self and others.
Be cautious in speech,
Guard against faults of the mouth.
Do not stir up waves,
Do not kindle smoke and fire.
Steal moments of leisure amid busyness,
Hide within the clamor.
Cultivate benevolence and accumulate virtue,
Dispel calamities and extinguish misfortunes.
Yield to others and advance the self—
This too bears the fruit of immortality.

**[On the Ten Perfections]**
The ten perfections are internal matters,
Not phenomena before the eyes.
Truly pure, truly still,
They are naturally attained:
A flowing rosy glow in the nape,
A radiant light in the eyes,
A surge of harmony in the ears,
A jade pillar in the nose,
Sweet nectar in the mouth,
True fire in the heart,
The Yellow River flowing backward below the navel,
Wood and metal turning with the waves,
Heaven and earth naturally conjoined,
The ten perfections complete—nature becomes effortlessly refined.

**Linked Verses**
Breaking free from the reins of fame, the guest of the Three Isles,
Wrenching open the lock of profit, the immortal of the Ten Continents.

chunks.original_text: 长生路径当修补，不死根芽好炼烹。 修心要厂长生客，炼性当为活死人。 炼气气和神踊跃，修真真净性玲珑。 专心学道须通道，坚志修仙决遇仙。 谁知神秀过才秀，我觉心明胜眼明。 心没攀缘神彩秀，气无凝滞性灵圆。 水中焰迸三丹结，火裹莲生一性灵。 学道男儿无我相，修仙烈士没人情。 忘上博来心上悟，道中通得妙中玄。 梦裹曾收无影剑，法中去了有情心。 尘中无染心中悟，道上通玄性上灵。 阴裹藏阳阳烜赫，命中养性性玲珑。 学道须凭心决烈，修仙全在志坚刚。 石女吹箫鸾凤舞，泥牛入海虎龙和。 玲珑玉姹敲龙角，惺洒金婴跨虎腰。 瑶池殿下青鸾舞，阆苑宫中白鹤飞。 袖裹青蛇三尺剑，腹中白虎九还丹。 青霞宫裹收红雪，碧玉岩前赏赤松。 心清意净天堂路，意乱心荒地狱门。 斡旋决仗无为力，造化全凭清净功。 一袖拂开沙世界，三丹结正大罗仙。 捉住亘初灵底物，得观元始本来真。 六六阴消丹灿灿，三三阳聚性灵灵。 云根水骨归金鼎，汞髓铅精聚玉炉。 速把我人山放倒，急将龙虎穴冲开。 踏碎龟蛇真活计，和调龙虎好生涯。 若要姹婴双戏鼎，须教日月两同宫。 鼎内精金生五彩，炉中美玉结三光。 兔走乌飞投气海，龙吟虎啸入神京。 心猿紧锁丹无漏，意马牢擒性自明。 降住天关并地轴，斡旋坎虎与离龙。 猿颠马劣难成道，虎远龙蟠易见真。 心中事少忧愁少，性上尘多疾苦多。 有有有中非有有，无无无裹有无无。 〔归山操〕

chunks.original_text: 钰因与僧烛律师、殿试范寿卿，於郡城之北三教堂，一日焚香宴坐，有王大师抱琴而来鼓之。 日昃，作琴操《归山操》，盖钰有归真之意也。 能无为兮无不为，能无知兮无不知。 知此道兮谁不为，为此道兮谁复知。 风萧萧兮木叶飞，声嗷嗷兮雁南归。 嗟人世兮日月催，老欲死兮犹贪痴。 伤人世兮魂欲飞，嗟人世兮心欲摧。 难可了兮人间非，指青山兮当早归。 青山夜兮明月飞，青山晓兮明月归。 饥餐霞兮渴饮溪，与世隔兮人不知。 无乎知兮无乎为，此心灭兮那复疑。 天庭忽有双华飞，登三宫兮游紫微。 〔委形赞〕 癸卯岁，师父丹阳真人，一日俄肆笔而书，名曰《委形赞》。 是岁果蝉蜕，故集於是。 卫身之光，照耀非常。 卫身之兽，风云前后。 大哉登真，委形而寿。 绀发青眉，红颊素肌。 如龙换骨，如蝉蜕皮。 不作易性，奚为空衣。 兀然若睡，卧篑而归。 大哉登真，路入青溟。 麟随绛节，凤牵朱軿。 呜鸾佩玉，履虚步云。 超受真诰，上登玉宸。 天路何长，天人飞翔。 摐金拊石，散花烧香。 声动三界，众来十方。 群魔钦仰，六丁惊遑。 灵颖斯成，幸无灾螟。 却顾松栢，非为遐龄。 山有时崩，海有时田。 长地久，永为列仙。 洞玄金玉集卷之六竟 洞玄金玉集卷之七
chunks.translated_text:
Yu, together with the monk Master Zhulü and Palace Examination graduate Fan Shouqing, once burned incense and sat in quietude at the Three Teachings Hall north of the prefectural city. Master Wang arrived bearing a qin and played it. As the sun slanted westward, he performed the qin melody *Returning to the Mountain Melody*, for Yu harbored the intent to return to the True.

"To be capable of non-doing is to be capable of all-doing;
To be capable of non-knowing is to be capable of all-knowing.
Who would not pursue this Dao once they know it?
Yet who truly understands it when they pursue it?

The wind sighs, sighs—leaves take flight;
The wild geese cry, cry—southward they return.
Alas, the world of men—days and months hasten;
Age nears death, yet still they cling to folly.

Grieved, the human world—my soul would take wing;
Alas, the human world—my heart would shatter.
Hard to resolve—this world is not my home;
I point to the green mountains—best to return early.

By night, the green mountains—bright moon soars;
By dawn, the green mountains—bright moon returns.
Hunger fed by rosy clouds, thirst slaked by streams;
Cut off from the world—none know me.

No-knowing, no-doing—
This heart extinguished, what doubt remains?

Suddenly, twin blossoms fly in the celestial court;
Ascending the Three Palaces, I wander the Purple Tenuity."

**[In Praise of Shedding the Form]**
In the *guimao* year, the Master’s Father, Perfected One Danyang, one day took up his brush and wrote, calling it *In Praise of Shedding the Form*. That very year, he indeed shed his mortal coil, and so it is collected here.

"The light that guards the body shines with uncommon radiance;
The beast that guards the body—wind and clouds attend before and behind.
Great is the ascent to Perfection—shedding the form to attain longevity.

Azure locks, green brows,
Crimson cheeks, pale skin.
Like the dragon, he changes his bones;
Like the cicada, he sloughs his skin.
Not altering his nature—why leave behind an empty robe?

Still as if asleep, he lies upon the mat and departs.
Great is the ascent to Perfection—the path leads into the azure depths.

Unicorns follow the crimson regalia,
Phoenixes draw the vermilion carriage.
The simurgh’s cry, jade pendants tinkling,
Treading the void, stepping upon clouds.
Exalted, he receives the true decrees,
Ascending to the Jade Celestial Court.

How long the celestial path—
The immortals take flight.
Striking metal, tapping stone,
Scattering flowers, burning incense.
The sound stirs the Three Realms,
Multitudes gather from the ten directions.
All demons revere him,
The Six Dings are startled and flee.

The numinous embryo now complete,
Fortunate to be free of calamity and blight.
Yet gazing back at the pines and cypresses—
Not for the sake of distant years.
Mountains may crumble in time,
Seas may turn to fields.
Long earth, enduring heaven—
Forever ranked among the Immortals."

*The Sixth Scroll of the* Treasury of Daoist Gold and Jade *is complete.*

chunks.original_text: 论恩 天地日月父母恩，不能使我脱沉沦。 弟兄姊妹暂相识，妻妾儿孙愈不亲。 幸遇风仙传秘诀，致令马钰得良因。 断情割爱调龙虎，绝虑忘机产凤麟。 玉内生金丹结宝，水中养火气安神。 师恩深重终难报，誓死环墙炼至真。 词 十报恩本名瑞鹧鸪 山侗一愿报师恩，物外生涯世罕闻。 锻炼玉炉三涧雪，修完金鼎一溪云。 蛟龙宜向火中溉，猛虎堪於水裹焚。 一粒神丹光透璧，不神神彩独超群。 又 山侗二愿报师恩，立誓修行志炼心。 火焰灭除火养木，水银枯尽水生金。 木金三间通玄路，水火同流结宝岑。 久视大丹成不漏，携云归去绝升沉。 又 山侗三愿报师恩，锻炼灵胎在玉京。 铅汞烹煎先有验，虎龙交媾岂无声。 三光并秀超三昧，五岳同峰出五行。 三五丹成真造化，自然云步访蓬瀛。 又 山侗四愿报师恩，天地收来入宝瓶。 日月山川添壮观，虎龙婴姹得安宁。 清轻浊重阴阳正，博厚高明品物灵。 赫赤丹成全性命，超然跨鹤过天庭。 又 山侗五愿报师恩，酒色气财誓不侵。 便把日乌先赶退，次将月兔更牢擒。 月轮重显无圆缺，日色增辉没缩沉。 功满丹成何处去，得超云汉绝阳阴。 又 山侗六愿报师恩，坦荡逍遥不惹尘。 识破假躯端的假，研穷真性的端真。 方知可道非常道，始觉不神所以神。 清净丹成乘赤凤，大罗天上赏长春。 又 山侗七愿报师恩，掌握虚无死水银。 满目牛羊当道卧，一轩风月证人纯。 清清净净难迷假，净净清清易见真。 龙虎丹成无九转，自然永永做仙人。 又 山侗八愿报师恩，返覆阴阳仗炼烹。 火降水升抛雪浪，龙吟虎啸发雷声。 玉炉瑞雪重重结，金鼎祥光霭霭生。 无价丹成无老死，长生路上法身轻。 又 山侗九愿报师恩，意净心清路坦平。 便把无为为造化，不凭有作作经营。 恰如逗引龙和虎，还似般调姹与婴。 活乐丹成蓬岛去，和公师叔远来迎。 又 山侗十愿报师恩，劈碎金柳玉枷情。 久视门中修久视，长生路上得长生。 昏昏默默澄澄湛，杳杳冥冥净净清。 响晓丹成蓬岛去，重阳师父远来迎。 述怀#1 利名场上没萦牵，人我丛中绝焰烟。 举意游山山岭上，兴心乐水水云边。 往来飘逸孤如鹤，去住安闲静似蝉。 据此逍遥能有几，从教人道活神仙。 上街求乞 人人休惜一文钱，好与贫儿且结缘。 暗暗还贤增万倍，明明助我养三田。 舍悭自是开心地，割爱方能达妙玄。 一日悟来离苦海，逍遥物外共修仙。 勉门人 道人活计不相侵，各自衣餐各自寻。 莫为闲言闲斗气，休争俗事俗萦心。 搜玄绝虑龙随虎，索隐忘机水养金。 清净色身全法体，一炉丹熟步瑶岑。 道友问在家能修行否 神仙要做恋妻男，忙裹偷闲道上参。 清净门庭无意认，淫情术法入心贪。 欲求家道两全美，怎悟寂寥一着甘。 莫待酆都追帖至，早归物外住云庵。 赠李校尉 一身便做个丹丘，於内常常云水游。 离坎交宫真子午，甲庚易位没春秋。 五行四象皆无用，三岛十洲却有由。 功行无亏云鹤引，大罗天上列仙俦。 遇禁烟道友索 禁烟禁火禁心猿，真息调来永永绵。 云水不游芳草径，身心岂着杏花天。 为人勿作坟中鬼，学我能修物外仙。 异日大丹成九转，腾空何必打秋千。 赠泾阳张书表 六旬有四卦将休，猛悟灰心离俗游。 访我搜真归正觉，搜玄索隐做持修。
chunks.translated_text:
**On Gratitude**

The grace of heaven and earth, sun and moon, father and mother,
Cannot lift me from the depths of sinking.
Brothers and sisters—brief acquaintances,
Wives and children—even less akin.
Fortune met the Wind Immortal, who transmitted secret formulas,
Enabling Ma Yu to attain good causes.
Severing passions, cutting attachments, harmonizing dragon and tiger,
Abandoning cares, forgetting schemes, birthing phoenix and qilin.
Within jade, gold is born; the elixir coalesces as treasure,
In water, fire is nurtured; qi settles the spirit.

The master’s grace runs deep—impossible to repay,
I vow to circle the walls in death, refining the utmost truth.

---

**Lyrics: Tenfold Gratitude (Originally "Auspicious Partridge")**

**First Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Beyond the world’s dust, a life rare to hear of:
Tempering the jade furnace with snow from three ravines,
Perfecting the golden tripod with clouds from a single stream.
Dragons ought to bathe in fire,
Fierce tigers may burn in water.
A single grain of divine elixir shines through jade,
Its numinous radiance peerless, transcending all.

**Second Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
I swear to cultivate, resolve to refine the heart:
Fire’s flames extinguished, fire nurtures wood,
Mercury exhausted, water gives birth to gold.
Wood and gold in three realms open the mysterious path,
Water and fire flow as one, forming a treasure peak.
With enduring vision, the great elixir is complete, never leaking,
Bearing clouds, I depart, free from rising and sinking.

**Third Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Refining the numinous embryo in the Jade Capital:
Lead and mercury simmer—first come signs,
Tiger and dragon mate—how could there be no sound?
Three luminaries shine together, surpassing the three meditations,
Five peaks merge as one, issuing from the five phases.
When the three-five elixir is complete, true creation is achieved,
Naturally stepping upon clouds to visit Penglai.

**Fourth Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Heaven and earth gathered into the treasure vase,
Sun and moon, mountains and rivers enhance its splendor,
Tiger and dragon, infant and maiden find peace.
Light and clear, heavy and turbid—yin and yang aligned,
Vast and deep, lofty and bright—all things imbued with spirit.
The radiant red elixir completes nature and life,
Transcendent, riding a crane across the celestial court.

**Fifth Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
I swear never to be tainted by wine, lust, anger, or wealth.
First, I drive away the solar crow,
Then firmly seize the lunar hare.
The moon’s wheel shines anew, without wax or wane,
The sun’s brilliance intensifies, without dimming or sinking.
When merit is full and the elixir complete, where shall I go?
Beyond the cloudy Han, free from yin and yang.

**Sixth Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Unfettered, carefree, untouched by dust:
Seeing through the false body as truly false,
Probing the true nature as truly real.
Only then knowing the Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao,
Only then realizing the unspiritual is the source of the spiritual.
With the pure elixir complete, I ride the red phoenix,
In the Great Luo Heaven, savoring eternal spring.

**Seventh Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Grasping emptiness, stilling the mercury of death:
Cattle and sheep fill the path, lying in my way,
A pavilion of wind and moon proves one’s purity.
Clear and pure, hard to be deceived by the false,
Pure and clear, easy to perceive the real.
When the dragon-tiger elixir is complete, no nine revolutions needed,
Naturally, eternally, I become an immortal.

**Eighth Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Reversing yin and yang, relying on refinement and cooking:
Fire descends, water ascends, casting snow-like waves,
Dragon’s roar, tiger’s howl, unleashing thunderous sounds.
The jade furnace’s auspicious snow layers upon layers,
The golden tripod’s propitious light softly arises.
The priceless elixir complete, no aging or death,
On the path of long life, the dharma-body is light.

**Ninth Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Mind pure, heart clear, the path smooth and level:
Using non-action as creation,
Not relying on effort for enterprise.
Just like luring dragon and tiger,
Or harmonizing maiden and infant.
With the elixir of living joy complete, I depart for Penglai Isle,
Where Master He and my teacher come from afar to welcome me.

**Tenth Vow to Repay the Master’s Grace**
Shattering the golden willow, the jade shackles of emotion:
In the Gate of Enduring Vision, cultivating endurance,
On the Path of Long Life, attaining longevity.
Dim and silent, limpid and deep,
Vast and obscure, pure and clear.
At dawn, the elixir complete, I depart for Penglai Isle,
Where Master Chongyang comes from afar to welcome me.

---

**Expressing Feelings #1**
No entanglements in the realm of profit and fame,
No flames of self and others in the crowd.
With intent, I wander mountains—upon their ridges,
With joy, I delight in waters—beside their clouds.
Coming and going, drifting like a solitary crane,
Staying or leaving, serene as a cicada.
How many can attain such carefree ease?
Let others say I live as a divine immortal.

**Begging in the Streets**
Spare a coin, good people, to aid the poor and forge karmic ties.
Silently, it returns a hundredfold,
Openly, it nurtures my three fields.
Abandoning stinginess opens the heart’s ground,
Severing attachment unlocks the wondrous mystery.
One day, awakened, I leave the sea of suffering,
Carefree beyond the world, cultivating immortality together.

**Exhorting Disciples**
The Daoist’s livelihood does not intrude,
Each seeks their own clothing and food.
Avoid idle words and quarrels,
Let go of worldly affairs and worldly cares.
Probe the profound, abandon thoughts—dragons follow tigers,
Seek the hidden, forget schemes—water nurtures gold.
Purify the colored body to preserve the dharma-body,
When the elixir in the furnace is ripe, step upon the jade peak.

**A Daoist Friend Asks If One Can Cultivate at Home**
To be an immortal yet cling to a wife is folly,
Stealing moments from busyness to seek the Dao.
The gate of purity remains unrecognized,
Lustful desires and deceptive arts seize the heart.
Seeking both family and Dao to be perfect—how?
How to savor the sweetness of solitude?
Do not wait for Fengdu’s summons to arrive,
Return early beyond the world to dwell in a cloudy hermitage.

**Presented to Marshal Li**
Make your body a cinnabar mound,
Within, ever wandering clouds and waters.
Li and Kan palaces exchange as true midnight and noon,
Jia and Geng positions shift, erasing spring and autumn.
The five phases and four images are all without use,
Yet the three isles and ten continents have their reasons.
With merit and conduct unblemished, clouds and cranes guide you,
In the Great Luo Heaven, ranked among the immortals.

**Meeting Daoist Friends During the Cold Food Festival**
Cold food forbids fire, restrains the mind-monkey,
True breath regulated, eternally continuous.
Not roaming clouds and waters along fragrant grass paths,
How could body and mind cling to the apricot blossom sky?
Do not become a tomb-bound ghost,
Learn from me to cultivate as an immortal beyond the world.
One day, the great elixir completes its nine revolutions,
Ascending the void—why need to swing on a swing?

**Presented to Zhang Shubiao of Jingyang**
At sixty-four, the hexagrams near their end,
Suddenly awakened, heart like cold ashes, leaving the worldly.
Seeking me to probe the true and return to right awakening,
Probing the profound, seeking the hidden, practicing cultivation.

chunks.original_text: 头分丫髻云霞友，手显擎拳风月俦。 稽首更明珍重理，自然得去赴瀛洲。 赠段先生 □公物外好生涯，□火相逢结大砂。 □女盘桓看大药，□牛哮吼戏灵葩。 □云铺地丹炉赫，□子观天碧眼华。 □有三生君省悟，□中无事步烟霞。 拆段字起。 〔赠姜公〕 宁海长春庵主姜公，同众道友怜予行步艰难，造一奚车。 工既成日，就福山来投，故作是词以报焉。 青牛白鹿与黄羊，稳驾云舆昼夜忙。 运载乾坤常会合，推般日月永交光。 法轮响喨投玄窟，云辂玎珰入道场。 九转功夫如省悟，自然得继马丹阳。 文登县黄箓醮赠道众 昆嵛三髻马风歌，得遇修仙厌事多。 我处无为酬本愿，人求追荐苦相魔。 加持助醮居环堵，救拔亡灵上大罗。 滞魄孤魂诚有幸，一齐超度喜无过。 又 一从得遇乐清贫，忻住环墙怕惹尘。 炼气气和神恋气，颐神神爽气安神。 宰公请我求追荐，小子慈心奉善因。 救拔亡灵超上界，孤魂滞魄总朝真。 爇心香本名行香子 夫妇分离#2 你是何人，我是何人。
chunks.translated_text:
**Presented to Master Duan**

Brow parted like forked chignons, companion of cloud and rosy dawn,
Hands revealed in clasped fists, comrade of wind and moon.
Bowing deeply to clarify the principle of cherishing,
Naturally one may depart to attend Penglai Isle.

**Presented to Master Jiang**
*Breaking the character "段" (Duan) to begin*

Beyond the world, Master □ enjoys a fine livelihood,
With □ fire meeting to congeal the great cinnabar.
□ maiden lingers to behold the great elixir,
□ ox roars in play with numinous blossoms.
□ clouds spread earthward, the alchemical furnace blazing,
□ child gazes heavenward, azure eyes radiant.
□ with three lifetimes, you awaken,
□ within, untroubled, you tread mist and rosy clouds.

**Presented to Master Jiang**

The Abbot of Changchun Hermitage in Ninghai, Master Jiang,
Along with fellow Daoist friends, pitying my difficulty in walking,
Constructed a handcart for me.
On the day the work was completed, he came to Fushan to deliver it,
So I composed these words in gratitude.

Blue ox, white deer, and yellow sheep,
Steadily pull the cloud chariot day and night.
Bearing the weight of heaven and earth, ever in union,
Pushing the sun and moon, their light eternally intertwined.
The Dharma wheel resounds, entering the dark cavern,
The cloud carriage jingles, entering the Daoist sanctuary.
If you awaken to the nine revolutions of the elixir,
Naturally you shall succeed Ma Danyang.

**Presented to the Daoist Assembly at the Huanglu Offering in Wendeng County**

On Kunyu’s three-chignon steeds, Ma and Feng sing,
Meeting those who cultivate immortality, weary of worldly affairs.
I dwell in non-action to fulfill my original vow,
While others seek memorial rites, tormented by suffering.
Through empowerment, I assist the offering within these humble walls,
Delivering departed souls to the Great Luo Heaven.
Fortunate are the lingering spirits and solitary souls,
All together transcended in boundless joy.

**Again**

Since first encountering the joy of pure poverty,
Delighted to dwell within these enclosing walls, fearing the dust of the world.
Refining qi, qi harmonizes, spirit clings to qi,
Nurturing spirit, spirit is refreshed, qi settles spirit.
Magistrate Zai invited me to perform memorial rites,
This humble one, with compassionate heart, upholds the good cause.
Delivering departed souls to ascend the upper realms,
All solitary spirits and lingering souls turn toward the True.

**Burning Heart Incense** *(originally titled "Xingxiangzi")*

Husband and wife parted—
Who are you? Who am I?

chunks.original_text: 与伊家、元本无亲。 都缘媒妁，遂结婚姻。 便落痴崖，贪财产，只愁贫。 你也迷尘，我也迷尘。 管家缘、火裹烧身。 牵伊情意，役我心神。 幸遇风仙，分头去，各修真。 上街化导 师父重阳，真个真师。 教马钰、专做贫儿。 生涯清净，活路无为。 应抚心琴，调龙虎，饮刀圭。 誓不山东，缘在关西。 且和光、混俗随时。 笊篱闲把，惟望人知。 愿不蚤归，休空过，疾修持。 示众师兄 未至丹阳，怎敢为师。 对同流、说破些儿。 长生妙处，似有施为。 聚五彩云，五行气，五方圭。 酉雉生东，卯兔生西。 是木金、间隔之时。 净中意会，清裹心知。 愿早清心，早净意，早行持。 劝象师兄求乞残余 物外飘蓬，馁在其中。 蓦然闻、撞动斋钟。 残余求乞，祷告玄宗。 念出家儿，无家地，道家穷。 麻麦充餐，消灭尸虫。 觉虚心、实腹和冲。 婴儿跨虎，姹女骑龙。 在虚无中，来无迹，去无踪。 又
chunks.translated_text:
With their household—originally no kinship,
All through matchmakers’ words, we bound in marriage.
Then fell to folly’s cliff, craving wealth and property,
Only dreading poverty.
You too lost in dust, I too lost in dust.
Managing family ties—burning oneself in fire.
Drawn by their affection, enslaved in my heart and spirit.
Fortunate to meet Master Fengxian,
Parting ways, each cultivating the True.
Going forth to teach on the streets

Master Chongyang, truly a true teacher,
Instructed Ma Yu to live as a beggar.
His livelihood pure and still, his path non-action.
Stroking the heart’s zither, harmonizing dragon and tiger,
Drinking the elixir pellet.
Vowing never to return to Shandong,
For his destiny lay in Guanzhong.
Thus blending light, mingling with the world as time flows.
Idly wielding the bamboo skimmer,
Only wishing others to know.
Hoping not to return too late,
Lest time pass in vain—hasten your practice.

To all fellow disciples

Not yet reaching Danyang,
How dare I claim to be a teacher?
To those of like mind, I reveal a little.
The wondrous place of longevity
Seems to require some effort.
Gathering five-colored clouds,
The qi of the Five Phases, the tablets of the Five Directions.
A rooster born in the west, a rabbit born in the east—
Such is the time of wood and metal’s separation.
In purity, the meaning is grasped;
In clarity, the heart knows.
Wishing for early purity of heart,
Early clarity of intent,
Early practice.

Exhorting Brother Xiang to beg for leftovers

A tumbleweed beyond the world, starving within,
Suddenly hearing the temple bell strike—
Begging for leftovers, praying to the Mysterious Origin.
Remember, those who leave the household
Have no home, no land—Daoist poverty.
Hemp and wheat fill the meal,
Dispelling corpse-worms.
Awakening to an empty heart,
A full belly, harmony within.
The infant rides the tiger, the maiden mounts the dragon.
In the realm of emptiness,
Coming without trace, going without shadow.

**Again**

chunks.original_text: 悟道翛然，出世因缘。 但闻人、修建斋筵。 长舒臂膊，立在傍边。 便乞残羹，觅残饭，度残年。 无耻无羞，灭火消烟。 便留心、搜妙搜玄。 阐开玉蕊，攒结金莲。 觉气神清，精神秀，做神仙。 赠王五先生送环墙内饮膳 教去当除，争办斋厨。 弟兄懑、错用功夫。 不如休歇，早认元初中便觅云根，寻云脚，履云衢。 喘息如龟，似有如无。 觉仲和、来往宽舒。 斡旋山岳，呼吸江湖。 得产仙胎，成仙质，赴仙都。 咏香 不爇沉香，闲爇心香。 布仁风、处处闻香。 人人向善，个个崇香。 愿处无为，常清净，自然香。 妙洞云香，虎啸喷香。 更龙吟、吐出馨香。 玉为宝篆，金结丹香。 得赴蓬瀛，超三界，献真香。 咏鹤 虽处鸡群，如凤积毸。 自丁令、化现如斯。 霜毛朱顶，玉羽琼肌。 唼太湖萍，潭鼻栗，唳云霓。 朝戏芝田，夕饮瑶池。 待王乔、来控当归。 舞昊市显，乘卫轩奇。 便指蓬壶，朝金阙，赴丹墀。 劝世 颜貌苍苍，髭鬓斑斑。 愈愚迷、嫉妬贪悭。 不忧自己，抚谓妻男。 便巧心生，无心肯，放心闲。 苦海波中，火院常耽。 运机谋、积业如山。 不求大道，一向痴顽。 算有谁知，修仙易，养家难。 善恶报 造恶之人，凶横无过。 细寻思、最易柰何。 生遭官法，死见阎罗。 向狱儿囚，确儿捣，硙儿磨。 积善之人，恭顺谦和。 细寻思、却总输他。 难收黑簿，怎入刑科。 更神明佑，家门庆，子孙多。 题仵先生东廊 六月严凝，腊月炎蒸。 这真功、颠倒分明。 阳中阴极，阴裹阳生。 出五行中，谁行到，我行程。 万朵金莲，火裹常荣。 水中看、红焰升腾。 两般攒聚，一性圆成。 便戴三花，梳三髻，礼三清。 赠张刘二都料 奉劝清河，酷告彭城。 暨诸公、休苦劳神。 速离火院，早出迷津。 纵水云游，归物外，作闲人。 端的修行，洗涤心尘。 以云朋、霞友为亲。 研穷久视，讲论长生。 便悟玄玄，通妙妙，得真真。 谢兴平县李公翁母布施一子学道 布施非凡，出俗因缘。 舍娇儿、入道搜玄。 人人称善，个个称贤。 便远扬名，名扬远，出秦川。 父母深恩，要报听言。 我人除、擒捉心猿。 气通八脉，功满三田。 救九玄尊，七祖父，共成仙。 客人樊公索 三髻山侗，叹个樊公。 贩淄矾、苦海波中。 要除烦恼，助一帆风。 便弃繁华，离燔火，出凡笼。 真个逍遥，真不迷蒙。 守真清、真争真功。 真真相济，真性玲珑。 便得真风，成真趣，显真容。 赠彭官人 昨日官人，今日仙俦。 悟浮生、水上浮沤。 忽生忽灭，难保难留。 便做风狂，成风雅，骋风流。 心意清闲，云水遨游。 以气财、酒色为雠。 法名得得，道号休休。 认本来如，无来去，好来由。 赠扶风县杨公马公 但愿人人，识破浮生。 速抽身、猛弃尘情。 休妻别子，绝利忘名。 便洒然惺，豁然悟，顿然明。 虎啸龙吟，气爽神清。 做真修、汞炼铅烹。 心平行满，丹结功成。 得跨云霓，朝玉帝，住蓬瀛。 岐阳镇张同监问修行 休问因缘，各做修行。 古人言、两句堪听。 人人有分，个个圆明。 但事情疏，心清净，达长生。 元气盈盈，大法成成。 创初观、日月停停。 光辉莹莹，龙虎平平。 觉本真真，常寂寂，永宁宁。 赠阎知宫 此个知宫，本是神仙。 外修持、错了因缘。 听予劝化，索隐搜玄。 便弃繁华，离尘境，访林泉。
chunks.translated_text:
Sudden enlightenment, carefree—
The causes of leaving the world.
Hearing only of others
Building feast-halls,
One stretches out one’s arms,
Standing at the side—
Begging for leftover broth,
Seeking scraps of rice,
Passing the remnant years.
Shameless, unabashed,
Quenching fire, dispelling smoke.
Then turning the mind
To seek the wondrous, to seek the mysterious,
Unfolding the jade bud,
Gathering the golden lotus.
Feeling qi and spirit clear,
Spirit radiant—
Becoming an immortal.

**For Master Wang the Fifth, Presenting Food Within the Enclosure Wall**
Teach them to remove what should be removed,
Yet they vie to prepare feast-kitchens.
Brothers weary,
Wasting effort in vain.
Better to rest early,
To recognize the primordial origin—
There, seek the root of clouds,
Follow the feet of clouds,
Tread the cloud thoroughfare.
Breathing like a tortoise,
Seeming to exist, seeming not—
Feeling harmony and ease
In coming and going.
Turning mountains and peaks,
Inhaling rivers and lakes.
Giving birth to the immortal embryo,
Forming immortal substance,
Ascending to the immortal capital.

**Chanting Incense**
Not burning aloeswood,
Idly burning the incense of the heart.
Spreading the wind of benevolence,
Everywhere incense is heard.
Each person turns toward goodness,
Each cherishes incense.
Wishing to abide in non-action,
Ever pure and still—
Naturally fragrant.
Wondrous cavern-cloud incense,
Tiger’s roar sprays fragrance.
Moreover, the dragon’s chant
Exhales fragrant scent.
Jade forms the precious talisman,
Gold binds the cinnabar incense.
Attaining the journey to Penglai,
Transcending the Three Realms,
Offering true incense.

**Chanting the Crane**
Though dwelling among chickens,
Like a phoenix amassing down—
Ever since Ding Ling
Manifested thus.
Frost-white feathers, crimson crest,
Jade wings, jade-like flesh.
Feeding on duckweed in Taihu,
Nibbling chestnuts by the pool,
Crying to the clouds and rainbow.
At dawn, playing in the field of mushrooms,
At dusk, drinking from the Jasper Pond.
Awaiting Wang Qiao
To come and rein it in.
Dancing in the market of Wu,
Riding the strange chariot of Wei—
Then pointing toward Penglai,
Morning court in the golden palace,
Ascending to the cinnabar steps.

**Exhortation to the World**
Visage ashen,
Whiskers and temples streaked with gray.
Yet still foolishly deluded,
Envious, greedy, miserly.
Not worrying for oneself,
But caressing wife and children.
Crafty thoughts arise,
No mind to yield,
No heart to relax.
In the waves of the bitter sea,
Ever bound to the fire-house.
Deploying schemes,
Accumulating karma like mountains.
Not seeking the Great Dao,
Ever obstinate and dull.
Who among you knows—
Cultivating immortality is easy,
Nurturing a family is hard.

**Karmic Retribution of Good and Evil**
Those who do evil,
Violent and unmatched—
Carefully considering,
What can they do?
In life, facing official law,
In death, meeting King Yama.
As prisoners in hell,
Pounded in mortars,
Ground in mills.
Those who accumulate goodness,
Reverent, humble, harmonious—
Carefully considering,
They surpass all.
Black ledgers hard to collect,
How could they enter penal courts?
Moreover, divine spirits protect them,
Households prosper,
Descendants multiply.

**Inscribed for Master Wu at the Eastern Gallery**
Sixth month’s severe cold,
Twelfth month’s scorching heat—
This true work,
Clearly inverted.
Within yang, yin reaches its extreme;
Within yin, yang is born.
From the midst of the Five Phases,
Who has walked this path?
I walk the journey.
Myriad golden lotuses,
Ever flourishing in fire.
Within water, beholding
The red flames ascending.
The two gathered together,
One nature perfectly accomplished.
Then wearing the Three Flowers,
Combing the three topknots,
Bowing to the Three Pure Ones.

**For the Two Directors, Zhang and Liu**
I exhort Qinghe,
Urge Pengcheng—
And all gentlemen,
Cease wearying the spirit.
Swiftly leave the fire-house,
Early depart the sea of delusion.
Though roaming with water and clouds,
Return beyond things,
Becoming a person of leisure.
Truly cultivating the Dao,
Washing away the dust of the heart.
With cloud companions,
Rosy friends as kin,
Delving into enduring vision,
Discoursing on longevity.
Then awakening to the mysterious,
Penetrating the wondrous,
Attaining the true.

**Thanks to Elder Li of Xingping County and His Wife for Offering Their Son to Study the Dao**
This offering is no ordinary thing,
The cause of leaving the world.
Forsaking their beloved child,
Entering the Dao to seek the mysterious.
Each person praises their goodness,
Each calls them virtuous.
Then their name spreads far,
Far-spreading fame,
Beyond the land of Qin.
The deep kindness of parents—
To repay it, heed these words:
We must capture
The mind-monkey.
Qi flows through the eight vessels,
Merit fills the three fields.
Saving the Nine Mysterious Lords,
Seven generations of ancestors,
Together becoming immortals.

**For the Traveling Merchant, Master Fan**
The rustic of Three-Topknot Mountain,
Sighs for Master Fan—
Trading alum in the waves
Of the bitter sea.
To dispel afflictions,
Assist with a sail’s wind.
Then abandoning splendor,
Leaving the burning fire,
Exiting the mundane cage.
Truly carefree,
Truly not deluded.
Guarding true purity,
Vying for true merit.
True and true mutually aiding,
True nature crystal-clear.
Then attaining the true wind,
Accomplishing true essence,
Manifesting true countenance.

**For Officer Peng**
Yesterday an officer,
Today a companion of immortals.
Awakening to floating life,
Like bubbles on water.
Suddenly born, suddenly gone,
Hard to preserve, hard to retain.
Then becoming wildly free,
Achieving elegance,
Galloping with the wind.
Heart and mind at ease,
Roaming with clouds and water.
Taking qi, wealth,
Wine, and sensuality as foes.
Dharma name: "Thus Thus,"
Daoist name: "Rest Rest."
Recognizing the original face,
Without coming or going—
A fine cause.

**For Masters Yang and Ma of Fufeng County**
Wishing that each person
Pierce through floating life,
Swiftly withdrawing,
Fiercely abandoning worldly passions.
Leaving wife, parting from children,
Cutting off profit, forgetting fame.
Then suddenly awakening,
Suddenly enlightened,
Instantly clear.
Tigers roar, dragons chant,
Qi fresh, spirit clear.
Engaging in true cultivation,
Refining mercury, cooking lead.
Heart balanced, conduct complete,
Elixir formed, merit accomplished.
Then riding clouds and rainbow,
Morning court before the Jade Emperor,
Dwelling in Penglai.

**Zhang the Supervisor of Qiyang Town Asks About Cultivation**
Do not ask about causes,
Each must cultivate.
The ancients’ words—
Two phrases worth hearing:
Each person has a share,
Each is perfectly luminous.
Only when affairs are sparse,
Heart pure and still,
Is longevity attained.
Primordial qi abundant,
Great Dharma accomplished.
Establishing the initial contemplation,
Sun and moon still.
Radiance shining,
Dragon and tiger balanced.
Feeling the original true,
Ever tranquil,
Forever at peace.

**For Attendant Yan**
This Attendant Yan,
Originally an immortal.
Externally cultivating,
Mistaking the cause.
Hearing my exhortation,
Seeking the hidden, searching the mysterious.
Then abandoning splendor,
Leaving the dusty realm,
Visiting forests and springs.

chunks.original_text: 净意清心，耕种丹田。 更常常、炼息绵绵。 命灯灿烂，性月团圆。 待行功成，超达去，得升天。 寄白水冯公淄阳长老 白水冯公，宁海扶风。 更淄阳、长老仙访。 三人一意，一志三通。 便剿妖魔，擒猛虎，捉蛟龙。 俗虑俱忘，真气和冲。 得自然、晓达灵踪。 金丹灿烂，玉性玲珑。 待行功成，超上界，住蓬宫。 寄柳巨济学录 奉劝书生，早悟浮生。 舍荣华、物外游行。 无思无虑，无爱无憎。 便纵闲心，寻霞友，访云朋。 常处常真，常争常清。 做修持、自是灵明。 铅为汞药，汞乃铅精。 炼大丹成，乘鸾去，赴蓬瀛。 赠三水三老先生 猛悟无常，频绝悭贪。 脱轮回、恋甚妻男。 出离火院，放肆婪耽。 更头如蓬，面如垢，语如慈。 万事俱忘，志炼行庵。 灭尸虫、敷布云昙。 幽微穷究，道德相参。 便讲玄玄，搜六六，论三三。 赠灵阳子李大乘 悟彻阳元，便把阳牵。 要阳阳、彻地通天。 阳穿八脉，阳透三田。 觉一阳周，一阳就，一阳全。 水养灵烟，火养灵泉。 更灵灵、真秀相传。 灵砂无漏，灵物牢坚。 便结灵光，成灵宝，做灵仙。 赠华亭张大悟 大悟之人，能放心闲。 弃利名、爱海恩山。 食无求饱，居不求安。 更不狂思，不下忽，不高攀。 协气横横，甘露珊珊。 用牛羊、车载循还。 坎离交结，龙虎盘桓。 得至精微，水精热，火精寒。 华亭县西庵主王公请住方丈 誓戒肥甘，欣乞余残。 以惺惺、变作痴憨。 不居方丈，不住华轩。 把浴堂来，为睡室，且弯跧。 外乐无心，内养真颜。 叹尘中、独占清闲。 将来功满，离了凡间。 向大罗天，云霞洞，列仙班。 悟黄粮本名燕归梁 词名本是燕归梁，无理趣、忒寻常。 马风思忆祖纯阳，故更易，悟黄粮。 百年一梦暂时光，如省悟，弃家乡。 常清常争处真常，累功行，赴蓬庄。 终南居环堵#3 董宣强项岂寻常，如燕颔，即非殃。 掀髯虚长不名疮，无破处，又何妨。 道家贫后计多方，无腋袋，用皮囊。 支颐悬挂度炎凉，裹面有，万般香。 赠兴平杨先生 密密相传理最深，向水裹，自生金。 个人无口解哦吟，能云步，曳云襟。 寻思今古修仙道，今如古，古如今。 古今难得遇知音，知音者，似予合。 战掉丑奴儿本名添字丑奴儿 紫极宫加持，忽闻左右宰褚之声，因作是词。 莱州道众修黄箓，各各虔诚。 无不专精，邀我加持默念经。 救亡灵。 柰何邻舍屠魁刽，不顾前程。 宰杀为生，猪痛哀鸣不忍听。 最伤情。 赠醮首刘大官#4
chunks.translated_text:
**Cultivating with Pure Intent**

With pure intent and a clear heart,
Till and sow the Elixir Field.
Ever refining breath,
Soft and unbroken.
The lamp of life shines bright,
The moon of nature full and round.
When merit is complete,
Transcend and ascend,
Attain the heavens.

**For Elder Ziyang of Bai River and Abbot Feng**

Elder Feng of Bai River,
From Fufeng of Ninghai.
With Elder Ziyang’s immortal visit,
Three minds as one,
One will in triple harmony.
Subduing demons and fiends,
Seizing fierce tigers,
Capturing flood dragons.
Worldly cares all forgotten,
True qi harmonious and surging.
Naturally awakened,
Discerning the numinous trace.
Golden Elixir radiant,
Jade nature crystalline.
When merit is complete,
Ascend to the upper realms,
Dwell in Penglai’s palace.

**For Disciple Liu Juji**

I urge you, scholar,
Awaken early to this fleeting life.
Abandon glory,
Roam beyond the mundane.
Without thought, without worry,
Without love, without hate.
Let the idle heart wander,
Seeking cloud companions,
Visiting misty friends.
Ever abiding in truth,
Ever striving for purity.
Through cultivation,
Naturally luminous.
Lead becomes mercury’s medicine,
Mercury the essence of lead.
Refining the Great Elixir,
Ride the phoenix,
Journey to Penglai.

**For the Three Elders of Sanshui**

Suddenly awakened to impermanence,
Cease greed and stinginess.
Break free from the wheel,
No longer clinging to wife and child.
Escape the fiery household,
Cast off indulgence and desire.
Hair like tangled hemp,
Face like grime,
Speech like kindness.
All affairs forgotten,
Resolve to refine in the hermitage.
Eradicating the corpse-worms,
Spreading clouds and mist.
Delving into the subtle,
Aligning with the Dao and virtue.
Then expounding the profound,
Exploring the six and six,
Discoursing on the three and three.

**For Lingyangzi Li Dacheng**

Fully awakened to the Yang Primordial,
Grasp and guide the Yang.
To let Yang and Yang
Pierce earth and penetrate heaven.
Yang traverses the eight vessels,
Yang permeates the three fields.
Sensing the one Yang’s cycle,
The one Yang’s completion,
The one Yang’s wholeness.
Water nurtures the numinous smoke,
Fire nurtures the numinous spring.
Ever numinous,
True excellence transmitted.
Numinous cinnabar without leakage,
Numinous substance firm and steadfast.
Then coalescing numinous light,
Becoming a numinous treasure,
Achieving numinous immortality.

**For Zhang Dawu of Huating**

The greatly awakened,
Able to set the heart at ease.
Forsaking fame and profit,
Beyond the sea of love and mountain of favor.
Eating without seeking fullness,
Dwelling without seeking comfort.
No wild thoughts,
No carelessness,
No high aspirations.
Qi harmonious and flowing,
Sweet dew gentle and slow.
Using oxen and sheep,
Cartloads returned in kind.
Kan and Li conjoined,
Dragon and tiger entwined.
Attaining the utmost subtlety,
Water essence warm,
Fire essence cold.

**For Abbot Wang of the Western Hermitage in Huating County**

Vowing to shun rich flavors,
Delighting in begging for scraps.
With clarity,
Transforming foolishness.
Not dwelling in the abbot’s quarters,
Not residing in ornate halls.
Turning the bathhouse
Into a sleeping chamber,
Curled in repose.
Externally joyless,
Internally nurturing true countenance.
Sighing at the dusty world,
Alone embracing tranquility.
When merit is complete,
Departing the mortal realm,
Toward the Great Brahma Heaven,
The cloud-grotto,
Ranked among the immortals.

**Awakening to Yellow Grain (Originally "Swallow Returns to the Beam")**

The tune was originally "Swallow Returns to the Beam,"
Lacking depth,
Too ordinary.
Missing Master Pure Yang,
Thus renamed,
"Awakening to Yellow Grain."
A hundred years—a fleeting dream,
Upon awakening,
Abandon home.
Ever pure, ever striving,
Abiding in the true constant.
Accumulating merit and conduct,
Journeying to Penglai’s estate.

**Dwelling in a Thatched Hut in Zhongnan #3**

Dong Xuan’s unyielding neck was no common trait,
Like a swallow’s chin,
No misfortune.
A beard grown long in vain—no festering sore,
No broken skin,
What harm is there?
Daoists, poor yet resourceful,
No armpit bags,
Using leather sacks.
Propping the chin, hanging to endure heat and cold,
Within the wrapping,
A myriad fragrances.

**For Master Yang of Xingping**

The principle transmitted in secret is most profound,
Within water,
Gold naturally born.
This person, though mute, can chant,
Able to tread clouds,
Dragging cloud sleeves.
Pondering the ancient and modern path to immortality,
Now as in the past,
Past as now.
Through the ages, rare to meet a kindred spirit,
Those who know the tune,
Seem to match me.

**Warbling the Ugly Slave (Originally "Adding Words to the Ugly Slave")**

At the Purple Ultimate Palace,
Suddenly hearing the cries of the neighboring butcher,
Thus composing this verse.

Daoist followers in Laizhou perform the Yellow Register rite,
Each devout.
All single-minded,
Inviting me to silently recite the sutras,
Aiding the departed spirits.
Alas! The neighboring butcher,
Heedless of the future,
Slaughtering for a living,
The pigs’ pained wails unbearable to hear.
Most heartrending.

**For the Jiao Master Liu Daguan**

Forever at peace.

**For Attendant Yan**
This Attendant Yan,
Originally an immortal.
Externally cultivating,
Mistaking the cause.
Hearing my exhortation,
Seeking the hidden, searching the mysterious.
Then abandoning splendor,
Leaving the dusty realm,

chunks.original_text: 彭城兄弟皆官样，富贵之家。 酷好荣华，未解回心悟落花。 路途差。 吾亲若肯搜玄理，别有生涯。 炉炼丹砂，大药烧成进彩霞。 泛仙槎。 赠刘叔建马长吉 吾亲叔建并长吉，两个同监。 未解婪耽，来往奔波名利贪。 似痴敢。 劝他早把元阳整，恋甚妻男。 卓个云庵，一句玄言匪俗谈。 离尘参。 赠莱州平等会首 世传斑竹佳人泪，语话皆非。 因击三尸，血染斑斑事最奇。 马风知。 专投正直无私杖，休笑轻微。 最好闲携，屏尽妖魔玉性辉。 赴瑶池。 咏筇杖 愿君妆点逍遥客，鹤膝同随。 闲步云霓，笑傲清风明月溪。 乐希夷。 海芦尚有吕二节，阳数明知。 与道相宜，好伴云游风马儿。 莫推辞。 自叹
chunks.translated_text:
**For the Pengcheng Brothers, All in Official Splendor**

The Pengcheng brothers, all of official bearing,
A household of wealth and honor.
Fond of glory and splendor,
Yet slow to turn their hearts and awaken to falling blossoms.
Their path diverges.
If my kin would but seek the profound principle,
Another livelihood awaits.
Furnace-tempered cinnabar,
The great elixir refined, ascending in rainbow hues.
Sailing the immortal raft.

**For Liu Shujian and Ma Changji**

My kin, Shujian and Changji,
Both serving as inspectors.
Unversed in indulgence,
They rush to and fro, greedy for fame and profit.
How foolish they seem!
I urge them to gather their primordial yang early,
Why cling to wife and child?
Erect a cloud hermitage,
A single profound word, no vulgar chatter.
Departing the dust to seek the truth.

**For the Chief of the Laizhou Equality Assembly**

The world tells of the speckled bamboo and the fair one’s tears,
All mere empty talk.
Struck by the Three Corpses,
Blood-stained spots appear—most wondrous indeed.
Ma Feng knows.
Devote yourself to uprightness, wielding no partial staff,
Mock not the humble.
Best to wander idly,
Banishing all demons, the jade nature shines.
Bound for the Jasper Pool.

**Ode to the Bamboo Staff**

I wish you to adorn the carefree traveler,
Knee of crane, ever at his side.
Strolling through clouds and mist,
Laughing proudly in the pure wind by the moonlit stream.
Joy in serenity.
Even the reed of the sea has Lü’s second integrity,
The yang number clearly known.
Harmonious with the Dao,
A fine companion for cloud-roving, wind-footed steeds.
Do not refuse.

**Self-Lament**
